To whom it may concern,
     From the scientific American article I read on this substance, Kratom  doesn't seem dangerous. All recorded deaths linked to Kratom are of the cocktail nature. Where an individual takes a cocktail of drugs that all combined leads to death.  As an American we are lead to believe that we live in a society of liberty and freedom. Yet this is not the case.  I have never used Kratom and know no one that does, yet I cannot condone a schedule 1 classification. If the sea chooses to classify this as a schedule 1 drug, this is what's going to happen. A pharmaceutical company pick this up, break the plants components down into a much more potent drug. Then sell it to the people that are addicted to opiates, fixing the problem they created. Please do not classify natural plants as schedule 1 drugs. It's in ethical and un American. Please keep banning synthetic drugs these pose a real threat to society.

documents.commentText:
My name is Laura Seltzer and I am 35 years old and live in Salem, Oregon. I am a Case Management Coordinator at the Department of Human Services. I have used kratom for Restless Legs Syndrome and Irritable Bowel Syndrome since 2008. Before finding kratom I tried every prescription drug that is on the market for both of my chronic conditions. Every single medicine I tried was ineffective, or the side effects were so bad I was unable to continue treatment. In fact, the anti-Parkinson's medication my doctor prescribed for my Restless Legs Syndrome actually made my symptoms worse (this is a common side effect called "augmentation").

I am a law-abiding citizen (I had to pass a background check to be employed at my current job), and I respect the law greatly, and one of the main reasons I chose kratom (like the hundreds of other people I have talked to in the kratom community), is because it is LEGAL, and because it does not alter who I am as a person like some of the medications I used to take for my chronic health conditions. It does not impair me, or alter my thinking or behavior, or affect my judgment. 

The DEA may think it's as simple as choosing not to use kratom anymore if the ban goes into effect. But I have two serious chronic illnesses that have been successfully managed with kratom for more than 8 years now. I can sleep at night and not crash my car when I'm driving because a Restless Legs Syndrome flare up happens all of a sudden, because my Restless Legs Syndrome is helped greatly by kratom. I can focus at work because my Restless Legs Syndrome symptoms are under control. I can not wake up every morning sick to my stomach and throw up every day before I go to work, because my Irritable Bowel Syndrome disappears completely when I take kratom. 

Most kratom users respect the law like I do, and are not criminals. We don't abuse illegal drugs, most of us don't even drink alcohol or use other prescription drugs. We are moral, ethical people by and large. But we also have chronic illnesses that require treatment, and kratom is the only thing we have found that works. It has given us our lives back. That is why you will find such passion among us. We are literally fighting for our lives.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

My name is Ana.  I have scoliosis and have been suffering from chronic back pain for many years. In addition, I was diagnosed with anxiety and depression.  After seeking treatment for all these conditions, I've got severely addicted to opiate painkillers as well as benzodiazepines, all of these legally prescribed to me by my doctors and taken at the correct dosage.  My life began to spiral out of control; I lost my job and ended up in a rehab.  After a 28 day program plus some follow up I returned back to normal life but of course still had back pain and mental issues.  That's when I discovered kratom by pure accident and decided to give it a try.  I am not very religious but still consider this plant to be a gift from God- the way it worked for me was nothing short of amazing.  My back pain subsided considerably and was manageable even on the days when I couldn't get to a chiropractor.  I no longer had panic attacks and in general was much happier with life.  I've got myself a decent job in customer service (something that I never thought I could do due to anxiety) and excelled in it.  Most importantly, I was no longer craving any prescription drugs, and in fact when my dentist urged me to take a Vicodin prescription after a root canal, I refused since I no longer was interested in it; I would've never said "no" in the past.   Now, I took kratom on a nearly-daily basis but never experienced any side effects other than an occasional constipation (that I was prone to all of my life anyways), and whenever I ran out, I never suffered from any withdrawal symptoms.   My tolerance never went up either, and I am still taking the same dose as 3 years ago when I first discovered it.  Quite often I don't take any kratom for days just because I'm already feeling fine (no back pain, etc), but if this wonderful herbal supplement actually gets banned, that would be devastating.  My back pain would then need to be managed by prescription painkillers again, a route that I REALLY don't want to ever take, but I don't want to be in constant pain either.  My anxiety and depression would most likely come back as well,  implying a possible job loss and severe financial debt (currently I have no health insurance and can't afford to go to a doctor).  In other words, my life would become much less manageable, and now, with a family to support, this could have way more severe consequences than the last time around.  I would also like to mention that I've introduced several other people also suffering from chronic ailments to kratom, and that changed their life for the better (two other people were able to beat their opiate addictions as well).  Banning this herb would result in grave consequences for them too, not to mention millions of other kratom users in the USA.  None of us are taking it for "recreational purposes" since kratom is not something that makes you "high" or causes any kind of inebriation; it is infinitely more similar to coffee or chamomile tea than to heroin or cocaine.  I urge you to reconsider the scheduling, and while I agree that there should be a minimum age limit for kratom purchase as well as quality control, I firmly believe that more harm than good would come out if it ever was banned.

documents.commentText: I am 41 years old. I developed an opiate addiction beginning with prescription pain medication around the age of 23 (1998). I first lost a job due to my addiction at the age of 26; I then went to jail for possession of drugs at the age of 27. At that time, I honestly couldn't understand why my life was going downhill. I was arrested for drug possession 3 times in a 6-month span in 2002/2003. My addiction left me unemployed between 2002 and 2007. I finally began trying to clean up my life in 2006 - I've held steady employment at most times since then, BUT I've relapsed in 2008 (which sent me to prison) and again in 2012 (again, sent me to prison). I discovered Kratom in 2014. Since then, I've stayed clean and been a stable presence in my 2 children's lives. I've held a job in the mining industry for close to 2 years. If I were to relapse, I would lose both my job and my kids. Kratom has taken away all cravings and helped me handle the stress that used to lead me to relapse. It's basically allowed me to turn my life around. I still work a recovery program, and look forward to eventually phasing kratom out of my life. Until then, I know it helps. I know it helps many others whose addictions are even worse than mine. It's natural, safe and a life saver.

Hello, thank you for allowing us submit our thoughts on Kratom.

My name is Jake Chatterton, 22 years old, and a resident of Meridian Idaho.

I am in favor of keeping Kratom fully legal for those of adult age. 

I am against any restrictions that would prevent responsible adults from purchasing and using Kratom.

I was introduced to Kratom about a year ago. 

I use Kratom a couple times a week. 

It helps with my stress levels, anxiety and depression.

Previously, I was prescribed several SSRI antidepressant medications: Prozac, Effexor, Cymbalta and several anti-anxiety prescription mediations: Valium, Klonopin and Xanax. Those are the ones that I remember. I have been prescribed more than I can remember. 

All of them had to be used on a daily basis which forced an unwanted dependency to the medication. I didn't like them, they either changed my personalty or made me very fatigued. Some of the medications also made very forgetful and school became much more difficult.

Kratom, for me, is more mild but works better than all of those and I don't have the need or desire to use Kratom more than a couple of times a week after a stressful day.

Since discovering Kratom, I have gotten my mind back and I am doing much better in school. I can't tell you how much this has helped me. 

It's not that Kratom has a huge effect on my performance, but rather that I don't need to take powerful pharmaceutical medications that had side effects that I had no choice but to endure. I don't want to be on those.

Please reconsider the Kratom ban.

It helps so many people and has brought nothing but positive things to my life.

Thank you very much,
Jacob Chatterton

documents.commentText:
Robert Anderson
Occupation: Biomedical Engineer, Small Business Owner
Education: Bachelor of Science in Biomedical Engineering, Master in Healthcare Innovation
Ex-Prescription Opiate Addict, Regular Kratom User, Avid Supporter of Naturopathy and Natural Supplements
Mesa, AZ
Age 31

I have been using kratom on a daily basis for roughly 5 years.  I began using kratom as a means of reducing anxiety/depression and improving concentration while starting my business.  It worked, and I've been using it ever since.  

I didn't even know that it would help me kick my lingering prescription addiction until after I started using it.  At the time I began using kratom, I had been using tramadol (mild opiate with SSRI properties) for the previous 2 years.  Before that, I had been addicted to prescription opiates since I was 19 when I was in a car accident.  Overall, over the last 10 years or so, I have gone from prescription opiates for pain to prescription addiction to tramadol to kratom.  

Kratom is the healthiest, most effective option for treating pain, opiate addiction, anxiety (social and chronic), depression, and concentration that I have encountered.  

I have used kratom (which I've purchased) to treat 5 friends who were addicted to opiates, ranging from vicodin to oxycontin and heroin.  3 out of 5 kicked their addictions completely.  The other 2 went back to opiates, because (I believe) they didn't have a computer to purchase large quantities online and there aren't any wholesalers locally.  The 3 that kicked their addictions have stayed clean for the last 2+ years.  However, 1 recently went back to opiate addiction, because local dealers refused to sell after the imposed DEA ban.  Since then, I've contacted her and got her back on her regimen, and, once again, she's going on 2 weeks clean.  A friend of mine who served 3 tours in Iraq also uses it for PTSD and pain caused by shrapnel. 

For me, kratom has been more effective at relieving my friends (and my) opiate cravings and withdrawals than anything else (including methadone and suboxone).  My veteran friend also threw out his prescription medications from the VA, because kratom works better.  In a country that is plagued by opiate addiction, I can't understand why the DEA would want to ban (to me) the single most effective option for relieving opiate cravings/withdrawals.  I also believe that the Veterans Administration should start supplementing kratom to veterans that they have gotten hooked on prescriptions (it's truly a shame...my mother works at the VA, she's ashamed of it too).

Kratom is not a drug, it's a plant - a leaf - that has been used for thousands of years with no documented deaths attributed (solely) to overdose.  Please, consider that I've used kratom for years and have a biomedical education...and I know kratom is less dangerous than the many well excepted and commonly used drugs (such as aspirin, which can cause liver damage).

The DEA banning kratom is like "friendly fire."  They should be using it to treat addiction.  Medical establishments should also be encouraged to use it to treat everything from pain to depression.

Thank you for allowing us to comment.  I hope that you hear reason, to keep it legal.

Respectfully, 

Robert Anderson

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

CC: Chuck Rosenberg


My name is Michelle Meadows. I am a former CPhT. I am also a 28 year old mother, student, wife, employee, and recovering addict. I am writing this letter in regards to the DEAs intent to schedule the alkaloids in kratom, Mitragynine and 7-OH-Mitragynine. I will aim not repeat the arguments of others or persuade the DEA. I will not speculate about kratom without evidence. I will not insult those with differing opinions. And I will not write beyond the scope of what my knowledge and education enables me to write. What I will do is cite scientific data and share my own experience with the plant in question, kratom.


To ensure my message is articulated in its entirety, some background information is necessary.

I began abusing drugs when I was 13 to cope with severe depression and anxiety, because I did not even know how to articulate what was wrong. I continued abusing things like cannabis and alcohol, and experimented with other drugs. I quickly found that I had an enormous affinity for opioids. I enjoyed drugs like pentazocine and propoxyphene just as much as I enjoyed morphine or any other C-II. I did not develop an addiction to opioids until I began taking them on a regular basis at age 22; even then it was a psychological addiction. Yet, despite the lack of symptoms of physical addiction, and under duress, I was placed on Suboxone. I tried numerous times to get clean. After discontinuing Suboxone, I experienced physical withdrawal for the first time, and the intense psychological cravings continued. When I was 25, I used intravenous heroin for the first time. I tried to get clean many times. I tried in-patient and out-patient therapy. I tried methadone and suboxone. I tried pure abstinence. Even jail did not abate the pull opioids had on me. I would do just about anything to get them and maintain my addiction.


By early May 2015, I had been raped, lost custody my child, ruined my career, and dropped out of school. I couldnt get or keep a job. I woke up every morning exhausted and in pain. I decided that life was no longer worth living. I thought I had screwed up so badly that the world was better off without me. I tried to intentionally overdose on heroin, but instead that just sparked a binge. Towards the end of that three week binge, I wanted to get clean. I had tried kratom months earlier as a recreational substitute and found it to be a waste of time, but I remembered stories I had heard about people using it to recover. I decided that it was worth a try. That was June 14, 2015. Presently, I am now employed. I am back in school pursuing a degree in neuropharmacology and have maintained straight As. I have a healthy, fulfilling relationship with my child. I have a will to live. I have relief from overwhelming pain. And I have been clean since the day I began taking kratom. This plant has been instrumental in my recovery and my ability to be a responsible productive member of society. My professional opinion is that placing this plant in any schedule would only serve to worsen the current opioid epidemic, and I humbly beseech the DEA to consider this and all other comments in the scheduling process.

documents.commentText:
Even after the FDA recommendation is received, to schedule a substance off of one agency's findings does not allow for scientific due process. Whether positive or negative, the FDAs findings must be corroborated with a larger body of research in order to justify legislative action, particularly on the federal level. 

The DEA website provides that "Schedule I drugs, substances, or chemicals are defined as drugs with no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse" (Drug Scheduling), but what true evidence do we currently have for abuse potential and/or medical use of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine beyond anecdotal? In its Intent to Schedule Kratom notice, the DEA notes it "...is aware of 15 kratom-related deaths between 2014 and 2016" (Intent to Schedule). However, given that the gross majority (14) of those deaths revealed systemic presence of other drugs/substances at time of death (Silverman, "Kratom Gets Reprieve"), kratom can hardly be considered as correlated, much less causal. Yes, there are risks inherent to allowing kratom to remain available for recreational use, but given that we have yet to understand what level of risk we actually face, to schedule the drug in such an extreme way seems an overreaction. The body of proof available currently simply isn't compelling one way or the other. There is more work to be done.

In order to truly understand the actual risks and rewards we face with this drug, we need to allow research to run its course, which is historically difficult if not impossible on schedule I drugs and substances. 

Sources:

"Drug Schedules". US Drug Enforcement Administration. Retrieved 29 November 2016. https://www.dea.gov/druginfo/ds.shtml.

"DEA Announces Intent to Schedule Kratom: SE Asian drug is imminent hazard to public safety". US Drug Enforcement Administration. 30 August 2016. Retrieved 29 November 2016. https://www.dea.gov/divisions/hq/2016/hq083016.shtml.

Silverman, Lauren. "Kratom Gets Reprieve from Drug Enforcement Administration". NPR, 12 October 2016. Retrieved 29 November 2016. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/10/12/497697627/kratom-gets-reprieve-from-drug-enforcement-administration.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to you to express my extreme dismay and concern over the possibility that the
natural plant Kratom is being considered by the DEA for banning, as a dangerous drug of
addiction. As a mother of three, I am willing to offer my personal testimony to kratom, and how it has improved my life.  Let me explain some of the actions and known effects of Kratom (Mitragyna Speciosa):
 
 Kratom is a tree native to Southeast Asia, whose leaves have been used as a natural therapeutic supplement for thousands of years.
 In small doses it provides an energy boost  its a botanical cousin of coffee, but in higher doses have an analgesic (pain relieving) effect.
 Thousands of testimonials have been written about kratom's efficacy in helping:
chronic pain, diabetes, fatigue, depression, lack of energy, withdrawal symptoms of opiate and alcohol addiction
 Kratom is non-addictive, and has few side effects
 Users report that it is less addictive than coffee, with those in middle-age being the most frequent and enthusiastic proponents of kratom's benefits.
 
 
Despite all these wonderful effects, this plant is in danger of being banned in the US by the DEA and FDA.  Ironically their reason for banning this wonderfully safe medicine is that it poses a health risk. Kratom is used recreationally by some people, and recent scares surrounding the synthetic drug 'bath-salts' have led to increased scrutiny on a number of legal substances and plants. This age-old plant is being lumped in with dangerous, unknown synthetic substances, and is under threat of criminalization. If this criminalization occurs, countless sufferers of illness and pain could lose access to a vital natural remedy that they have been using safely for years. Like any plant or medicine, when one regularly ingests excessive amounts of a substance there is a potential for harm. This is true of countless products available for sale in pharmacies and liquor stores today, but few would argue that this means they should be outlawed. If kratom is abused  taken daily in very high doses  it can be mildly addictive, and can also cause nervousness, sleeplessness, loss of libido, constipation and the darkening of skin complexion.  However, there have been no recorded deaths due to the use of kratom, which highlights its safety.
 
A case can certainly be made for the restriction of sale of kratom to minors, and responsible vendors have called for self-policing and an industry code of conduct. Senator A.G. Crowe recently withdrew a proposal to outlaw the sale of kratom in Louisiana after hundreds of people signed a petition against the plan, however he plans to put forward legislation to instate a minimum age of 18 for anybody purchasing the leaf  a move that is presumably not opposed by the majority of those who responsibly use kratom.  We have seen time and time again that prohibition simply worsens the social impact of drug use, causing further health risks for users and providing criminal gangs with money that could instead be directed towards tax coffers. 
 
Public health should be not seen through a lens so narrow that it that disregards practically all alternatives to Western medicine and pharmaceutical drugs. We call upon citizens, policymakers, and politicians to support the reform of archaic drug policy for the benefit of society, and to respect people's innate right to use all natural plants and herbs.
 
Thank you for your time and my prayer is that you help join the fight to regulate not prohibit the use of this natural herbal tea.
 
Shea Anderson
(34 year old Mother of Three, Masters in Education and Finance)

My name is Larkin O'Donoghue, I am a 49-year-old female.  I am begging you not to Kratom a schedule 1 controlled substance.  It is not heroin, cocaine, ecstasy, or LSD.  It is not something we need to be protected from.  I believe in what you do to try and keep all of us safe, but vilifying Kratom should not be any part of it.

I was fully disabled in a car accident several years ago.  Since then, I have been on large doses of doctor prescribed medications; not just for chronic pain and depression, but also for all the side effects of the drugs the doctors have given me.  In the last year, I have had to come-up reasons not to either start drinking, seek out illegal drugs, or just kill myself.
I first heard of Kratom four months ago, when I was searching the internet for something herbal that I could take to offer any help.  This tea has given me back a quality of life that I thought was lost forever.  I can now go to a movie and sit through the entire picture without pain.  I can meet with friends and not feel like a drugged-out zombie.  Best of all, I wake in the morning without wondering how to get through another day.

Please dont make Kratom illegal.  Dont rob my life of what it has returned to me.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

It was the only thing that she could get her hands on to help relive even just a small amount of the pain. If only I had known of kratom at the time... If it is banned, those people will continue to suffer, and without a doubt turn to other extreme methods to find relief. Methods that will likely be harmful, or illegal, or worse. documents.commentText:
I am a 40yr old mother of 4 and computer programmer, gainfully employed professionally (thanks to kratom). In addition to helping ease my chronic sciatica pain, it's the only "medicine" that's ever really helped my bipolar and borderline personality disorders. Most people take kratom as an opiate substitute, but it should be noted that its use in psychological disorders is at least as valid, if not more, as we often have no working alternative drug therapies (not even evil opiates) that actually do any noticeable good - and many have horrible, even fatal side-effects. 

I've suffered from Steven Johnsons Syndrome resulting from a mood stabilizer, which was truly awful despite being a milder case, and I suggest you not google it while eating. Kratom is, for me, far more effective than prescription medication, and unlike other herbal remedies like marijuana, doesn't get me high, and so I'm able to keep my wits about me and work productively while taking it - and has no noticeable side effects beyond mild constipation, which I'll take over SJS any day!

Borderline Personality is non-curable, and very difficult to treat, often with limited success, and most suffers are on long-term disability/welfare due to inability to function in any consistent manner over any reasonable length of time. Kratom has kept me steadily employed for several years now, with jobs lasting longer than ever before in my life. 

I have stopped taking kratom more than once to try and save money or see if I would be alright without it, and although I had no withdrawal symptoms I would start slipping back into my old state of being, having more and more "bad days", within weeks to a couple of months of quitting. No other drugs I've attempted (and there have been many) have worked for this disorder to the degree kratom does. It improves my quality of life tremendously and I'm not sure what I would do without it now, honestly.

My oldest daughter suffers from Asperger's, an Autism Spectrum Disorder. She used to have crippling social anxiety, among other debilitating symptoms, and couldn't even purchase items at a store unaccompanied. After my own experiences with kratom I suggested she try it to see if it helped her as well, since some of kratom's well known effects are to make people fee more open to new experiences, outgoing, more "connected" to others, and generally less anxious and depressed. It seemed fitting.

It's done nothing short of turn her life around. She's now a successfully employed, social and confident college student with a significant other, living a 99% normal life instead of a scared young adult trapped in her own mind. Treating Autism is something I don't believe kratom has even been considered for, with much of its focus on opiate addiction and pain management, and there are no good (and few FDA approved) drug therapies for treating Autism - definitely none that even pretend to work to this degree. This could be a huge boon to so many sufferers on the spectrum, enabling them to live more functional, fruitful, fulfilled and generally happy, normal lives. I would specifically like to see studies done on this before it's hastily banned when it has so much potential! Autism is huge nowadays!

As if the above alone wasn't enough to justify more research (and not banning) of kratom, it also treats both me and my daughter's frequent migraine headaches, and works better than Ibuprofin - which is continually being warned against due to side effects of heart attack and stroke - or any other pain reliever we've tried.

Kratom is the single thing that keeps myself and my daughter - among many others - employed, functional citizens, paying taxes and living fulfilling lives, instead of being societal burdens, stuck on disability, seeking help that doesn't exist in the pathetic state of our current mental health system.

If you go through with banning this natural remedy - which I'm opposed to in principle as well and support marijuana legalization also despite getting no useful effect from it myself - you'll be causing millions of people (look at the numbers involved in the outcry against banning) pain, suffering, and possible loss of livelihood and/or quality of life, vs this supposed "immanent threat" which includes what? A few hundred calls to poison centers (how many do they get for OTC medications), and a small handful of deaths that have all involved other drugs and can't be definitively linked to kratom (again, give us numbers relative to OTC or prescription drugs widely available also)? 

That hardly sounds like a reasonable tradeoff, even if the cited issues did exist - and there's a huge amount of contention on the cited data to begin with. Leave kratom alone or be prepared to deal with the massive backlash of millions of users losing the only thing that helps them and having to resort to far less desirable alternatives - if any are available at all. The extra burden on our healthcare system alone would be substantial!

documents.commentText:
As a natural products chemist and cell biologist specializing in plant medicines I would like to argue against the scheduling of kratom in the United States. Please review the unbiased, academic literature on this plant, as well as consider the lack of deaths and illness related to the use of kratom itself (not in combination with other pharmaceuticals, which may be contraindicated and warrants further study). This has proven to be an effective, non-opiate, therapy for opiate addiction and can be used in lieu of highly addictive opiates for pain management.
Please allow the science and facts to prevail when considering the legal status of kratom, as well as other whole, plant-based medicines. As a trained phytochemist I am well aware of the medicinal benefits of kratom and other botanicals and that they are safe for use by the general public. It would at least be a service to the healthcare community to keep kratom from being scheduled, as this would effectively prevent research from being undertaken to explore the benefits and risks from this plant, that, has thus far shown to be safe and effective in humans.

documents.commentText:
Two years and two months ago I had the first of my two hips replaced. I had the second one replaced 6 months later. I was born with a condition called acetabular protusio, which is the medical term for a malformation of the hip sockets. I was diagnosed in my 20s. I made it to 57 before I couldn't function without the surgery. Unfortunately, instead of improving my life, the surgeries fixed the original problem but left in its place many many more, and I am in pain every waking hour. I have travelled far and wide for a solution but no doctor has been able to help. My life has been all but destroyed as I can no longer do most of the things I loved to do--even walking around the house hurts. I hate taking drugs and avoid painkillers. I had to take opioids immediately post-surgery as almost everyone does, but after two weeks or so I switched to ibuprofen, which I have been taking a small dose of ever since. Needless to say, it doesn't do much for me. I recently heard about Kratom and have just this week taken some to ease my pain and help with the depression that comes with pain and immobility. I am thrilled to find something safe and readily available with very few side effects, which are manageable. This herb has given me hope that I will have some of my life back. I am too young to have the lifestyle of a 90 year old woman. Today I went for a long walk with my husband. I had some pain, but not nearly as much as I would have had without a low dose of Kratom. Thanks to the community, I have been able to study dosage and such carefully, and I have begun very cautiously, with good results. Please don't take away this first and only hope I have of a reasonably active life. In the summer my daughter got married and I was in severe pain all day long at her wedding, although I put a smile on my face as usual. If I had known about Kratom, I might have enjoyed the day more. It is my strong belief that for future family events, I will have Kratom to bring me relief so I can enjoy the grandchildren I hope for, and my son's wedding one day too. Please don't take it away.

Sincerely,

Elizabeth Hambrick

I am a 36-year-old chef. I was born with knees that didn't develop correctly. I used pain pills to cover up the pain so I could work a full-time job. When my mother died I began to abuse them. I lost my job, house and a lot of family. 

I got put on suboxone and was able to function enough to work and start fresh . But I noticed the longer I was on them I was always tired and losing weight. I'm 6'and only weighed 120 lbs. Got so weak I couldn't work more than 25 hours a week. It started to feel I would never be successful in life if I kept living like that. I decided to get off them and once the withdrawals hit I thought they would never end and were worse than any opiate withdrawal I've ever been through. After 2 weeks of the withdrawals not getting any better I found kratom. Within 24 hours, I felt normal again, had normal emotions that I hadn't had since before the opiate abuse. Smiling felt so amazing. I used the kratom for another 2 weeks until when I woke up in the morning and wasn't going through the sub withdrawal anymore. 

I discontinued the kratom because I didn't want to have to take something every morning to feel good. I was finally happy and gained 30 lbs over the next 2 months and have never felt happier or healthier. I am now working a full-time job and make more money than I have in my entire life. I only take the kratom when my knee is in severe pain. I finally feel in control of my life. Please don't get rid of this plant. I truly don't know where I would be without it.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name's Dylan Beresford and I am a daily kratom user. I would like to say that kratom has done for me what many pharmaceutical drugs could not for my clinically diagnosed chronic depression, acute anxiety, PTSD, and alcoholism. I have struggled with alcoholism for years. It negatively impacted many aspects of my life, I.e; job loss, relationships, financial insecurity, personal health, among many other things. I find that this is a virtually harmless way to treat my issues. There lies very few cons, and the pros outweigh them tremendously. It allowed me to put down the drinking. Cravings virtually are non existent. The diagnosis of anxiety and depression have diminshed to a point far superior than any antidepressants or mood stabilizers have done. I've been able to null the continuous dire health issues I was facing because of these issues. documents.commentText:
I would like to submit this comment against the DEA's proposed ban on kratom for the following reasons:
1) Banning kratom expands the unsuccessful, destructive "war on drugs," while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
2) If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
3) Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
4) Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
5) Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
6) Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

I am a devout Catholic (I attend Mass regularly), I am also a lawyer (University of Memphis, School of Law 2010), and I am an entrepreneur (I successfully run three small businesses). And I have no criminal history or record. 

With all that being said, I am also a Kratom user. I put the plant in a tea to successfully combat depression, insomnia, prior alcohol dependence, and chronic back pain. 

I have used the Kratom plant in tea for three - four years now and I know its effects well. It is extremely unlikely that this is a plant that can cause a fatal overdose. In the most severe cases, it can, however, cause nausea. The amount taken must be regulated; as taking large amounts can have similar effects to drinking too much alcohol. Similar to Alcohol, if an individual took an exceedingly large amount, it would be dangerous to get behind the wheel of an automobile. 

The main difference in Kratom and Alcohol is that Alcohol can be fatal in large amounts, and Kratom is very, very likely not fatal, even in rare instances when exceedingly large amounts are ingested. 

I believe that Kratom, as a plant, should be researched extensively for its benefits and possible dangers (if any) before it is taken away from the American people. I also believe that Kratom is not a problem, but an opportunity, for the DEA as a natural remedy and combatant to the current heroin epidemic that is destroying so many lives. And finally, I believe that the use of Kratom (a plant less dangerous than alcohol) is a civil liberty protected by the principles of the United States Constitution. 

Respectfully,

documents.commentText: The claim that kratom is an imminent public health hazard with no known medical use doesn't pass the straight face test so long as oxycodone remains in a different schedule and insofar as there is thousands of years of history confirming its beneficial uses. That no pharmaceutical company has been sufficiently motivated by profit to apply for FDA permission to sell this plant as a drug should not be the measure of whether this plant has any known beneficial uses. Thousands of years of its use informs any sentient human being - the DEA notwithstanding - to the contrary. Scientific studies show kratom to be safer and better treatment for symptoms of withdrawal from opiods than methadone. If you schedule this PLANT and send it to the underground, you will be placing lives at risk, much like you do with your entire prohibition regime. Its time for the DEA to enter the 21st Century. Imposing a ban on kratom based entirely on anecdotal evidence and without scientific study would be an abomination. Fifteen of the sixteen deaths attributed to kratom involved people with multidrug toxicity and it is irresponsible for you to attribute these deaths to kratom. As a plant in the coffee family, it is about as addictive as coffee which you choose not to regulate. Therefore, screaming "its addictive" is not a convincing argument that it needs to be scheduled. Most people reading this have been addicted to coffee for decades with no known adverse consequences. Anything is subject to abuse. Sugar poses a greater threat to the public health than kratom, yet I can buy four pound bags of it for $1.50 a few blocks from my home. High fructose corn syrup also poses a much greater and PRESENT threat to the public health than kratom. Moreover, kratom is not highly likely to be abused as people looking to "get high" have many more options that provide a more reliable and pleasant "high" than can be obtained from using kratom. Frankly, the scheduling of kratom appears to me to be nothing more than the protection of the big pharmaceutical companies that peddle methadone. Looking back on why Thailand originally outlawed kratom, recall it was because tax receipts on their government run opium monopoly were falling due to kratom use. Ask yourself: is it better that people be using kratom instead of opiods? There is only one answer to this question. Just look at the deaths in this country from opiod abuse.

documents.commentText:
I do not believe it is the country's responsibility to protect its citizens from themselves. That being said, to put kratom on the schedule 1 list shows ignorance to the substance and would be the biggest case of misjudgment since the scheduling of marijuana. The bill states: 

To find that placing a substance temporarily into schedule I of the CSA is necessary to avoid an imminent hazard to the public safety, the Administrator is required to consider three of the eight factors set forth in section 201(c) of the CSA, 21 U.S.C. 811(c): the substance's history and current pattern of abuse; the scope, duration and significance of abuse; and what, if any, risk there is to the public health. 21 U.S.C. 811(h)(3). Consideration of these factors includes actual abuse, diversion from legitimate channels, and clandestine importation, manufacture, or distribution. 21 U.S.C. 811(h)(3).

Judging something by its pattern of abuse is a nebulous and seemingly asinine way of determining if it should be restricted from the whole country's population. If the meaning of abuse is "to use badly" or "to use improperly", how can one objectively say a substance is being abused. Kratom is a less addicting, cheap, and less harmful alternative to prescription painkillers. It is used for just that reason, it helps people in pain. In addition, kratom has also been a godsend from people suffering from anxiety, depression, and sleep disorders, myself included. Where can the line be drawn between use and abuse? Can a substance only be abused when there are dangerous, life threatening side effects like those of alcohol, nicotine, and caffeine? If so, why aren't those banned?

Annual tobacco related deaths in America: 480,000[1]
Annual alcohol related deaths in America: 88,000[1]
Deaths from kratom worldwide between 2014-2016: 15[2]

Of the 15 reported deaths, it was found that other drugs were used in conjunction[2]. To say that kratom is more dangerous than already legal substances is a blatant lie and the American people should not stand for it. Banning kratom could make thousands of recovering opiate addicts resort back to prescription painkillers. To me, it is clear that the only motive for banning kratom is money related. Quickly putting a substance that has saved thousands of lives into a drug schedule that classifies it as having "no medicinal value" and "highly abusable" shows that the DEA does not even want to look into its potential benefits. At the time of writing this, over 142,000 people have signed the petition to stop the kratom banned[3]. The American people have spoken. We do not want kratom banned.

references:
1. http://www.drugwarfacts.org/cms/Causes_of_Death
2. https://www.statnews.com/2016/09/02/kratom-devotees-fight-for-supplement/
3. https://petitions.whitehouse.gov/petition/please-do-not-make-kratom-schedule-i-substance

documents.commentText:
I strongly oppose the DEA putting kratom on the list of schedule 1 substances.

Eight years ago, I was hit by a car while riding my bicycle, which severely mutilated my wrist and paralyzed my hand. Reconstructive surgery and years of therapy allowed me to use it again, but not without serious chronic pain, debilitating acute pain associated with moderate use of my hand, and insomnia caused by pain. 

I've tried just about every prescription or over-the-counter drug for pain relief, including opiates and medical marijuana, as well as dozens of dietary supplements. The best pain relief with no side effects I've had comes from kratom. Taking kratom as a regular dietary supplement has made life livable and allowed me to follow my desired career path.

I've taken kratom for three years now. Before my injury, I worked in remodeling houses (my family's business) for about a decade. My injury made such work impossible, but every other job I worked (in science research and writing) also caused acute pain from repetitive hand use. Since I began taking kratom regularly, I have regained work remodeling and can continue my writing work without frequent breaks. This kratom use also helps me to fall asleep and stay asleep instead of writhing awake from pain. Furthermore, my lifelong practice of piano became impossible after my injury but with kratom again enriches my life.

Kratom is extremely valuable to my well-being and has had essentially no negative impacts. If by accident (which is hardly possible) I take too much kratom, at worst, I feel nauseous and sleepy.

Kratom is not a drug and should not be regulated as such. It should be in the same category as coffee, wild lettuce, or kava. Kratom is about as addictive as coffee. Kratom is not possible to abuse since it is not a recreational drug and one cannot get "high" from it.

Kratom is a botanical dietary supplement indispensable for millions of Americans to reduce pain, sleep soundly, or to feel calm, concentrated, or uplifted in mood.

To schedule kratom would be absolutely devastating to my life and millions of others. That kratom has any of the characteristics meriting a schedule 1 substance has no basis in science or fact.

These recent articles are just a few of the many that show that kratom is safe to take, and poses no medical risk:
http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524
https://www.dropbox.com/s/bz83v89y59h5kky/112916%20AKA%20ER%20trauma%20med%20professionals%20survey%20news%20release.docx?dl=0

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am writing to request that Kratom not be placed on any DEA schedule.  My name is Kelly Meredith, I am 47 years old, married, and Ive worked in the technical department of an environmental company for over twenty-five years.  I was diagnosed several years ago with major depression and generalized anxiety disorder, and I currently take prescribed medication which keeps the worst of my symptoms under control.  I also run about twenty miles per week and do yoga at least once per week, and these both help as well.

I started drinking Kratom tea a little over two years ago. It was suggested to me by a friend of my husbands, and I noticed that it lessened some of my anxiety symptoms that arent controlled by other methods. The effect is subtle--the closest thing I can liken it to is coffee.  I feel uplifted, but unlike coffee, I dont get jittery.  Instead I feel both alert and calm at the same time. Occasionally I have some mild back pain from sitting at a desk all day, and Kratom seems to help with that as well.  Earlier this year I completed my Masters in Information and Library Science, and I feel that Kratom helped with test anxiety and the general anxiety of being in school.  My husband drinks Kratom tea often with me, and my 74 year old mother recently started drinking it to help with her anxiety and with some of her rheumatoid arthritis symptoms.  

Putting Kratom on a schedule will have a negative impact on me and my family.  It is now part of our lives in much the same way coffee or tea is, and I believe it to be just as benign-in no way do I agree that it is as dangerous as LSD or Heroin.  I think it should be regulated like other drinks such as coffee or tea, or as a supplement.  

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely, 

Kelly Meredith

documents.commentText:
I first learned about kratom after reading a news report that this new "drug" was going to be scheduled and banned by the DEA. It said that it was an opiate like drug that produced the same effects and danger as other opiates like heroin and prescription pain medication. Naturally I immediately ordered some. Having taken opiates in the past, the thought of a leagal (for now) drug that can be ordered over the Internet that produced the same effects as other opiates sounded too good to be true. Sure enough, it was too good to be true. It was not even the least bit opiate like in its effects, and there certainly was no "high" involved, no matter how much I took. At best it made me feel similar to drinking chamomile tea. But what it did do, which was a surprise to me, was aleveate my restless leg syndrome and the chronic cramp in my foot that RLS caused. 

I started researching kratom more and reading about the experiences of others who were regular kratom users and found their experiences to be similar to mine. It produces a mild analgesic effect, but nothing on par with regular opiates. I also found that the primary reason most people use it is to manage severe pain that previously had to be treated with dangerous and addictive prescription opiates. Some even use it to get and stay off heroin! 

It also turned out the dangers reported about kratom were either outright lies or gross exaggerations. More people die a year from drinking too much water than have ever died from taking kratom. Clearly the public health crisis and danger to society kratom has been made out to be is false. I won't go into the reasons for why I believe the DEA has chosen to mislead the public about kratom, but it definitely is not for the best interests of the general public. 

Kratom is a safe and helpful alternative to deadly and habit forming prescription drugs, and should NOT be scheduled by the DEA. The idea that the DEA can turn law abiding citizens into felons overnight by scheduling a natural and harmless plant is sickening and an abuse of the power they have been granted by congress. Though I do need to thank the DEA for making me aware of this life changing plant that I now rely on for a good night sleep and a pain free work day, and I sincerely hope you thoughtfully consider this and the many other accounts from kratom users when you make your final decision on kratom scheduling.

12 medications later, I was fraught with the developing side-effects. 
I have a BA in Equine Science and have some graduate work in Counselor Education. As a previous counselor and coordinator of programming in the field of Chemical Dependency, I quickly realized that the medications and the dependency on them were going to shorten my life and so started working diligently on healing using alternative and natural means by which to do so.
 Also, as an Equine massage and physiotherapist who has researched and incorporated Integrative Medicine and Holistic Health Care into my life and my work for the past 26 years I have a fairly extensive knowledge of how this healing process works naturally!
I was introduced to Kratom in April of this year (2016) after being told by my doctor that due to new CDC regulatory guidelines there would be a decrease in pain medication.
So I began research to figure out what else I could do to help myself with the continued process of healing since I would no longer be permitted to manage it with the medicines.
After doing fairly extensive research on the safety and efficacy of this plant I figured it couldnt hurt to try it. Much to my surprise and relief, the addition of this herbal tea helped immensely. I have been able to consume the tea and get relief from the physical pain of the ankle. I have also found support from this amazing plant in that I am finding relief from the anxiety and the depression from the PTSD that I have refused to take prescription medications for over the last several years. 
As a result, I feel as though I have a new life. I have been able to work more regularly, take on new clientele, and have been able to spend more time with my family&my grand-kids&something that I have struggled with for so long. I actually HAVE a life now. I do NOT get high from this plant (and do NOT use marijuana for that very reason) and have experienced ZERO side effects. 
I have noticed that this proposed ban comes on the heels of the new CDC regulatory guidelines. These guidelines and the resulting panic with the medical doctors in their actions to decrease or stop the pain management programming have created havoc and in my opinion have increased the numbers in the opiate epidemic.  So many people are being discharged from their pain-management programs that despite the side-effects, were giving most people at least some semblance of quality of life (especially the veterans!) Many of these people have discovered Kratom and have improved their lives beyond what the medical profession was giving them
 I have also noticed that there is a huge (and genuine) concern for the opiate epidemic and this decrease in pain-management in the medical field has not helped. Now there is an herbal supplement that can essentially be a huge part in healing this epidemic and help people to get their lives back and the DEA wants to take it away?  Now I am very concerned about how this decision would affect the opiate epidemic! If hundreds of thousands of people are using this herb responsibly for various reasons instead of opiates (including heroin), how do you think this is going to affect the epidemic? 
Another thing that stuck out to me was the economic impact that this would have. I have read several articles and surveys on the economic impact that this ban would create. 
https://www.facebook.com/l.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.botanical-education.org%2Feconomic-impact-kratom%2F&h=uAQGZSqla&s=1 
With all of these implications, this proposed ban is the most ridiculous and deplorable thing I think I have ever heard of! Personally, I would agree with some responsible and appropriate regulation in order to keep this whole natural plant unadulterated and possibly an age limitation but since the unadulterated whole plant is clearly safe and beneficial, I would appreciate able to continue to make my own choice about consuming it!
CLEARLY keeping this plant legal and available would be in the very BEST interest of ALL! 
Sincerely,
Marcilyn Brient

documents.commentText:
I am writing today to urge you to oppose legislation banning kratom and rendering it a Schedule 1 illicit substance. This ban is not only unnecessary, but it's potentially perilous to chronic pain sufferers and recovering addicts. 

A good friend of mine suffers from chronic pain due to an injury she experienced in her work place. For years, she struggled to get doctors to take her pain seriously, as medical professional after medical professional failed to find a diagnosis. After following the advice of the doctors she visited, she was flagged as a "drug seeker" and essentially blacklisted from receiving treatment. Her debilitating pain prevents her from working, and even everyday tasks like going to the grocery store can be thwarted by bouts of pain that compel her back into her house for hours or even days at a time. She exhausted avenues such as chiropractic treatment and homeopathy. A couple of years ago, in her efforts to take ownership of her health in the face of a system that would no longer help her, she discovered kratom. This has been the cornerstone of a series of lifestyle changes that have permitted her to go back on the job market, resume directing a choir in conjunction with her church, and look ahead toward a happy marriage with her fianc. 

The DEA proposes listing kratom as a Schedule 1 drug citing imminent danger to the public from its continued use, a claim that is not borne out in the numbers. Kratom, by itself, has been linked to no fatalities (it's only in connection with other drug use that kratom has been tagged as a dangerous substance), nor does it cause a high that endangers the user nor those around them. Meanwhile, it is effective in alleviating chronic pain and an affordable, homeopathic means for heroin addicts to detox and break their cycles of addiction. 

In a healthcare system where, despite efforts at reform, too many patients still slip through the cracks and we rely too heavily on pharmaceuticals whose costs continue to skyrocket, solutions such as kratom need to be available without government intervention. Moreover, in a political climate where increasing attention is being paid by both political parties to the crisis of heroin addiction across the United States, it would be nothing short of disingenuous to ban the use of a plant demonstrated to help addicts quit on their own.

documents.commentText:
I am a 40 year old woman working in the software industry as a project manager, my company works closely with Fortune 100 companies providing their infrastructure. I have am an accredited PM and have a Bachelors degrees in Psychology. I also have chronic pain due to a riding injury which shattered my hip when I was 18, a shattered coccyx and symptomatic degenerated discs in my lower back. I cannot stand for more than about 15 minutes without pain, which becomes intense to the point of being unable to move after about 45 minutes. I also have clinical depression, anxiety and C-PTSD. I have years lost to impaired function due to either the pharmaceuticals needed to combat the worst of my symptoms, or the mental exhaustion in managing these health issues without prescription medication as my job requires me to be focused and sharp, which takes a great deal of mental fortitude, often lost when I'm on medication. Additionally I am unfortunate enough to suffer from most of the side effects of medication, so careful choices must be made as sometimes they can be worse than actually gritting my teeth and suffering. 

That was until I found out about Kratom earlier this year. On the first day I started a small 1 teaspoon dose, I was astounded at the effect. Not only am I now almost pain free, but I have my emotional stability and clarity back as well. My husband was moved to tears on the first day only an hour after I took my first dose, he said he felt like the woman he had fallen in love with had come back home. I have been more impact-full and focused at my job, I am able to do simple things most people take for granted like clean my home or go for a walk without being crippled in pain for days afterwards. The only side effects I have are a little dry mouth and extremely mild nausea within a half hour of first taking a dose. After several months I'm not taking a higher dose that I originally started with (the 1 teaspoon) nor do I feel any need to take more. I have been able to come of all prescribed medication for both my chronic pain and my mental health with the approval of my doctors... I've even lost weight because I'm now able to be so mobile! 

I almost feel like a teenager again. I cannot imagine life without this simple herbal remedy, and it's not just the impact it's had on my own health, but the impact on my husband, family and friends who have also had a huge weight lifted from them even though their not taking it. No longer does my husband have to be my care giver and be wary of my mental health at detriment to his own needs, no one needs to be mindful of how they speak to me, we can all actually go out together as a group instead of my anxiety keeping me at home alone or only able to be out for a short time. 

I've studied this herbal supplement in depth, and while I understand the concern to keep harmful items out of the public's general access, this is not something to restrict. Rather it's something that should be allowed to be available, and with raising awareness, safe use becomes the burden of the user. I understand the DEA has had concerns over 12 deaths thus far linked to Kratom, but in every single case Kratom was just one substance in a cocktail taken by the person who died. Kratom is no more the cause of the death in those cases than alcohol is the cause of the death of someone who mixes too many pills with their drinking. Raising awareness of safe use is the only thing that needs to happen, as the unsafe use cannot happen with Kratom alone. Therefore the responsibility should be on the user who chooses to use unsafely, just as the drinker is held responsible for drinking while taking pills, not the alcohol. 

Please do not punish the many tens of hundreds, if not hundreds of thousands of people who are using this beneficial herbal supplement to manage pain & mental health safely and without any more addiction than Coffee (which I'm sure many in your offices would say they're addicted to!). There always will be the reckless and unsafe few who will take the greatest risks in chasing a high. And Kratom is NOT a high in any sense of the word, if anything it's a stabilizer, a normalizer - I know from my experience that it is pretty amazing to not feel caged by my anxiety or crippled by my pain, and one could liken that amazing normalcy as a "high" if to you it feels like a miracle just to not be in pain physically and emotionally, but it cannot be compared to any other  mind altering drug like heroin or even marijuana. It sharpens and clarifies, not dulls and disassociates. 

Thank you for this opportunity, I look forward to you making the rational and compassionate decision, and leaving Kratom as a dietary supplement to allow awareness to grow that it is NOT a "high" to chase, and for its safe use to be widely understood.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:
My name is Aidan Lawrence. I'm 24 years old, and currently a student in the final semester of my senior year at Williams College in Williamstown, Massachusetts. I use Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) daily for pain -- because of a spinal fracture (L4 Transverse Process) incurred while playing rugby for my college, and also for depression and anxiety -- because said spinal fracture was misdiagnosed as a bone bruise, and left untreated for three years. Every doctor I went to assumed I was looking for painkillers, because this country is in the throes of one of the worst opiate epidemics in history. I didn't want drugs, I just wanted to know why I woke up every day in pain, miserable to be alive -- I wanted help. I wanted to know why sleeping for twenty hours a day was preferable to leaving my bed and doing anything with my life -- I got nothing but judgment and echoed sentiments of "We can't help you, try another doctor". I couldn't even get a doctor to touch my back to feel the knots that kept me from sleeping. For three years, that was how I lived. I literally did not leave my bed. I was constantly in pain. The first thing I did every morning when I woke up was cry -- every single morning, I wished that I had just died in my sleep so I wouldn't have to deal with yet another day of excruciating agony, of hating myself and my life, of lashing out at my friends and family. I didn't have any hope left, I had completely given up. 
Then, my friend introduced me to Kratom . It gave me my life back. Within moments of trying it, my back didn't hurt. I cried again that day, but not because of pain or depression. I cried because I could finally do what I wanted with my time and with my life. I could get out of bed and do the dishes. I could take my dogs for walks again. I could be nice to people again without concentrating only on pain and anger. Because of this plant, and the support and love of my friends and family, I'm going to finish college in two weeks. It's taken me seven years, but I'm finally going to graduate -- and I owe that to the pain relief and quality of life that Kratom has given me. Kratom has helped so many people get their lives back -- from pain, from anxiety, from opiate addiction, and from depression, among numerous other things. Kratom has let the veterans that fought for this country's continued freedom live their lives without being in a haze of prescription opiates all day. The people that use kratom aren't junkies looking to get high -- they're human beings who simply want to live their lives free of pain and depression. 
Please do not schedule Kratom -- it will do so much more harm than good. Kratom is non-lethal, non-toxic, and not at all a threat to anyone's health or wellbeing. Banning it will do nothing but drive more people back to street heroin or illegal prescription pills. Banning Kratom will ruin the lives of hundreds of thousands of people that don't want to be dependent on drugs that take away the essence of who they are as people -- they want to work and be part of society, to be themselves, and Kratom lets them do that. Kratom has given hope to so many people who thought they would never escape the cycles of pain, depression, and addiction, and done so in a way that poses the absolute minimum of risk. Please don't take that away from us.
Thank you so much for taking the time to read this comment, and I truly hope you will make the right decision -- to keep this wonderful herb available, in its natural form, to the millions of citizens whom it helps on a daily basis.

documents.commentText:
Nov 8, 2016

Thank you for providing this opportunity to express my views on this issue.

I am a 64 year old male and have been drinking kratom as a tea for about one year. I purchase it from a local kratom/kava bar in Gulfport, Florida. I consume it 1-3 times per week with no more than 12 oz during a 24-hour period.

Kratom helps me in the following ways:

1. It relieves severe headache/sinus pain to a remarkable degree. My pain is caused by recurring and sometimes severe sinus infections. 

2. It is a mild mood enhancer.

3. It reduces general anxiety, which I experience at various intervals.

I've never experienced an undesirable side effect from kratom. There was never a loss of equilibrium. My only caveat is that drinking it on an empty stomach may cause some mild nausea, although vomiting never occurred.

When kratom became unavailable to me due to the temporary ban, I did not experience withdrawal, either physically or psychologically. I did miss it, however, because I was at times experiencing the sinus/head pain as well as anxiety. But I never felt an overwhelming desire for kratom.

Of course, various medications are available for alleviating pain and anxiety. But I would much rather use a natural herb for relief as opposed to potentially harmful or toxic medications created by the pharmaceutical companies.

I fully support the legalization of kratom, except the minimum age for its use should be 18.  

Finally, I applaud the DEA for reversing its decision to ban kratom at this time, and sincerely hope that the lifting of the ban becomes permanent.

Best regards,
David Yelenchic

documents.commentText:
I am a 42-year-old female who is a disabled SAHM. My highest education is a bachelor's degree in science (biology) from Rutgers University. I suffer from major depression, panic disorder, anxiety disorder, and agoraphobia. I've been taking Kratom for a few years, and it to say it has saved my quality of life is an understatement. I'm currently on four prescription medications. However, they fail me in so many ways. For instance, I am on Xanax for the anxiety and panic attacks. While the Xanax works to subdue a panic attack, it also knocks me out and I must sleep. This is not a practical solution when trying to live a functional normal life. I deal with panic and depression on a daily basis. How can I live a normal life asleep? Or even so tired I cannot concentrate? I can't. I cannot raise my child, pay the bills, do the shopping, care for all my animals (I rescue them and also have a service dog), etc. because my medication has sedated me. It's just not practical. If I take a lower dose, then it doesn't help with the panic. This is just ONE problem with ONE of my prescribed medications. 
I was not functioning AT ALL and was bedridden for 18 months. I finally somehow managed to peel myself from my bed and get to my computer. I cannot describe to you the mental anguish I was experiencing. I was completely grief-stricken for one thing. I had lost my dad in a tragic motorcycle accident and was suffering from PTSD on top of my already existing emotional and mental illnesses. As stated above, I rescue animals and had suffered the loss of FOUR dogs within a year and a half. These were my children. I had a hyper toddler at the time, and there was no time or space to grieve the way I needed to. I would stay cocooned in the bed, enwrapped in my blanket with only one arm out to play with my child. I could not cook her dinner. I could not go outside to play with her. I suffered a nervous breakdown when my home was headed to foreclosure. I lost a lot of weight and was down from 135 to 113 lb and looked sickly. So I somehow by the grace of God made my way to my computer. I had given up on my meds. I Googled "herbal remedies for anxiety and depression" and discovered Kratom. I was willing to try anything and this was so simple, a plant relative to the coffee plant but with people claiming it was relieving their pain, physical or mental. So I wanted to try it. 
 I placed an order and received my capsules within a few days. I took them with some iced tea and quickly ran back to my bed, my sanctuary, my best friend. And I waited. About a half hour later I noticed my racing heart was calming down, the panic dissipating. My mood was lifted. I didn't feel so gloomy. The feeling of doom went away. I could feel love again, something I had lost, and could show my child how much I loved her. I did have feelings inside but they were dormant and protected by the panic. It's the only way I can describe myself at the time; I was numb. I was in such pain that it's all I could feel...pain or complete numbness. Empathy, passion, love, and any other positive feeling like that eluded me. The grief, the breakdown, the fear of losing my home...it all overwhelmed me to such an extent that I couldn't feel at all and I certainly could not function like a normal human being. Now suddenly everything shifted. I could feel again but in a positive way. I showered, I took my child outside to play at the park. Yes! I left the house!  With taking Kratom in the morning, I was able to care for everyone again, including myself! I started cooking again for my family. I could function! 
I do not know where I'd be right now if it wasn't for this wonderful plant God has provided to us. As a biologist, I c\an tell you that every organism on this planet serves a purpose. Hell, there's even little fish to clean sharks' teeth. This plant has not only saved my life but also my quality of life. I do not know what would have become of me by now, but I fear I may not be sitting here telling you my story. And now there's threat of my MIRACLE being banned? A plant that is helping so many people? It's not only unfair but it's absurd. Please do not let this happen! I'm still to this day taking my prescription meds, but as you read above, they were not working to get me to a functional level. I see a therapist now and a psychiatrist who prescribes the meds. I was able to get out of the house and see my family doctor thanks to Kratom, and he prescribed me Abilify, another miracle. BUT, I still struggle with panic and only like to take the Xanax at night before bed. It's just not practical to use during the day when I have a life to be live. I know my family is grateful to Kratom because they got back their wife, mother, daughter, and sister. My animals would have a story to share also I'm sure. Please, leave this plant alone. I cannot survive without it, and if I do, it will be awful. I will be back in my bed once again, locked away both inside my body and inside my home.

documents.commentText:
I would like to make my comment about this amazing all-natural plant which is closely related to the coffee plant.

I am female, in my early 40's, single and live in California. I have been diagnosed with Fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue, depression, chronic migraine. I have struggled with these conditions most of my life and have been seen by numerous doctors and specialists through the years including my own father, who is a physician (internal medicine). I have been on too many medications to count, with little or minimal benefit and most often unbearable side effects which made it impossible to continue treatment. One unfortunate symptom of fibromyalgia is being overly sensitive to medications whether RX or natural so my options through the years has been limited. Enduring horrible side-effects and withdrawal symptoms from prescription medicines has just added to the struggle and frustration to try to live a somewhat normal life. 

After many years of seeking help from physicians and trying medication after medication at great expense both physically and monetarily I found that I was still living in constant pain, exhaustion and depressed. I decided a few years ago to try a more natural approach. I did research, sought advice and was also seen by naturopaths and slowly started adding natural supplements and foods to my daily routine. I also slowly, and with the help of my physicians weaned off of the prescription medications that were not helping me. I can't say that it was easy to do, and it took a long time and a lot of trial and error, but I found that I slowly started to feel better! 

One of the main components in my natural regimen is kratom. I initially heard of kratom through a fibromyalgia support group. I researched the vast information available on kratom; including published medical trials (and subsequent patents of the active compounds found in kratom) and after I became very interested in trying it. I also had my father who is a MD read the published medical literature on kratom and he decided it would be safe to me to try. I slowly added kratom to my daily regimen and started to see improvements in my overall pain levels and fatigue. My father was also impressed with the results and lack of side effects. I would liken kratom's effects to it's plant relative, coffee, with the added benefit of pain relief. I have used kratom daily for over 2 years now and have found that it has been a life changing natural medicine for my symptoms. Kratom also had little to no side effects for me, which is quite rare given my high sensitivity to most prescriptions. The more information and studies that I have read have also posted very similar success stories with almost zero side effects. There is also a large online support community including the American Kratom Association and Botanical Education Alliance that have amazing information and resources on kratom. 

Considering where I was just a few years ago I cannot imagine living without kratom or being forced to go back on medications that did more harm than good. For kratom to be banned and placed in the same schedule as heroin and other illegal drugs is unimaginable and there is substantial documented research to support this. There are kratom studies that prove it is superior in the treatment of pain versus high strength RX opiate medications without #1 being an opiate #2 having the same harmful addictive properties and  #3 it does not affect the central nervous system or slow breathing which is one of the main reasons people can die from overdosing on prescription opiates. Far too many people die every single day from prescription drug overdoses and I fear banning kratom will only increase that number. The number of deaths from legal medications far outweighs those of natural remedies including kratom. The overdoses where kratom was involved always included another prescription or illegal substance. There have been zero overdoses from kratom alone and the number of calls to poison centers/ER visits from kratom is less than those for children accidentally consuming laundry detergent packs. The reasons behind the proposed ban are not in line with the truth and published research. 

Kratom has become part of my daily routine (just like coffee for a majority of the population) and it helps me to live and function without the pain, exhaustion and horrible side effects that traditional prescription medications had provided. I would be bedridden and unable to work or provide for myself without kratom and cannot imagine that this could be taken away within weeks by having it placed on the same schedule as heroin and drugs that have zero benefit and kill thousands of people every year. 

I along with my father are strongly opposing the proposed scheduling of kratom . We both are making our comments here along with writing to and calling our state/federal representatives. Thank you.

Kratom gives people are natural alternative to help with  anxiety, depression, PTSD, sleep disorders,chronic pain and helps people get off of opiates.  We should be able to choose what we use to help with such conditions. It is not dangerous and any deaths that have been connected to kratom have been shown to have other dangerous drugs in the systems of these people but none have been proven to be from Kratom itself.  It is only as addictive as coffee because it's a cousin to the coffee plant. 

Personally, it has helped me with anxiety, depression and fibromyalgia pain.  It never gave me negative side effects.  My state banned it earlier this year and as a result,  I am suffering needlessly as many others where I live and in the other states where it's been banned. Those who used it to escape addiction from narcotics are turning back to these known dangerous drugs or even to other illegal drugs like heroine to help with their pain because of these bans in these states!

Please don't ban kratom nationwide and make some many people suffer, make so many become desperate that they turn to truly dangerous drugs and deny people are safer alternative to many issues that they face. Please also help kratom become legal again in states it's banned already.
