documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am a US Citizen living in Michigan becoming a Pharmacist. I am writing this to make it clear that I oppose the scheduling of Mitragyna Speciosa. As someone who helps many patients with dispensing their pain, anxiety, and ADHD medication, I cannot tell you how many HATE the medicine and wish so badly for an alternative. They tell me of all of the horrible side effects. I cannot and do not say anything to them about this wonderful alternative plant that has helped so many people, but it is clear that this is something that needs to stay around.

I started using Kratom 3 years ago because I was in a near-fatal car accident which left me with many, many issues including severe pain and anxiety from PTSD. I could not handle the amount of side effects and "hooked" feeling from the Percocet they gave to me. I decided to look for alternatives and found Kratom. I realized it is not a "drug" and is not "addictive" like the painkillers they were giving me were. I had to wean off of the Percocet and even still had lasting issues from it. I started using Kratom while weaning off and it helped so tremendously. It was night and day. The pain disappeared, the withdrawal symptoms from the Percocet were reduced drastically, and I was able to continue to use it to stay pain free. Here is a link to a government done study that concludes that kratom is a wonderful plant for cessation of opioids such as Oxycodone:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3670991/
Some key quotes from the article:

"One striking finding of this report is the extent to which kratom attenuates potentially severe opioid withdrawal, yet cessation of kratom administration itself appears to be associated with modest abstinence symptoms."

"Although mitragynines agonize mu-opioid receptors, respiratory depression, coma, pulmonary edema and death have not, to our knowledge, been associated with human kratom ingestion."

Once I healed and did physical therapy, I no longer needed the kratom for pain, had used it daily, and had no withdrawal issues whatsoever from stopping cold turkey. I had therapy and found out my increasing anxiety was due to PTSD from the accident, I decided to try Kratom again as I read it was good for anxiety as well. It is unbelievable how much it helped. It has completely and utterly cured it. All this from a PLANT, not a drug isolated from the well-known addictive plant Poppy Somniferum, which I know is imported in MASSIVE quantities for pharmaceutical companies to keep making these horrible addictive drugs. 

To conclude, it just seems so clear to me that this alternative should be available for US Citizens. We are in the "Land of The Free" and a PLANT which helps so many people and has been found to have so many medicinal properties is going to be banned? It may be anecdotal, but I have never had a single issue or side effect from this plant and yet it has helped more than any pharmaceutical even could come close to with virtually no side effects. I genuinely hope you will not ban this plant that could and does help so many people and that you can see how wrong it would be to do so.

documents.commentText:
To place the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxmitragynine, (hereby referred to as "kratom"), into schedule I classification would be a significant miscalculation on behalf of the Federal government. 
Individuals in the United States have been consuming kratom without harm for decades, and people throughout the world have consumed the dietary supplement for much longer. Despite the reports of some shock media, Kratom is not a "new exotic drug."

Kratom is a natural botanical that has quietly been part of the American economy for at least 2 decades. Hundreds of thousands of mature adults suffering from chronic pain have used Kratom for years, as well as individuals trying to abstain from hard drugs like opiates, or alcohol, which is obviously legal, yet much more dangerous.

Commercial Kratom has been on shelves for years but never caught on as a 'legal high' because it's recreational potential is limited. If Kratom was anything like heroin, it would have seen instant popularity and gotten national attention and prohibition a decade ago.

Kratom can produce a 'sense of well-being' but falls far short of the 'euphoria' category because it largely doesn't interact with the Mu-Opiate receptor which produces euphoria, major pain relief and dependency. That is why you almost always see mature adults in support videos/media and not teenagers looking to get high.

The opium epidemic kills 78 people in America a day. This is an epidemic that was ignored by the federal government for way too long, until it grew out of control. Kratom has the potential to help opiate addicts recover and become functional members of society, much more painlessly than methadone or suboxone. 

Denying people this opportunity to get back on track can be a literal death sentence for many. To be able to wean off deadly, addictive opiates simply by drinking kratom tea is a miracle and would save numerous lives. The Federal government would be heroes by facilitating this treatment, especially since kratom has very limited recreational potential. 

Additionally, placing kratom into schedule I will not permit important research to be performed without mountains of red tape that will discourage most researchers from performing these necessary studies into the beneficial aspects of kratom.  

The war on drugs is an utter failure, and it is now time to start offering solutions rather than blind imprisonment and prohibition.

documents.commentText:
Please, please, please keep kratom available as a natural choice for my (and many others) health and well-being, please!

I will keep this a brief as possible. I was addicted to pain killers from 2007-2014. For a long time I thought it would take me dying or going into the hospital to get me to stop taking them.  In 2009 I went into the hospital for pneumonia, they put me in a coma for 13 days.  When I woke up, i had pain killers brought to me every 2 hours. It took me a month to get released from the hospital, they sent me home with 120 pk and a prescription for 2 more refills, those were gone in less than a week (all 360 pk, not just the 120).  Fast forward 2 and a half years later to late 2011.  I had eaten so many pills that I had a hole in my large intestines. I had hours to live before they opened me up, cut out the piece of my intestines that had a hole in it, and sewed the two ends together.  When I woke up this time I couldn't eat anything but guess what, I could put Dilaudid in my I.V.  Three weeks later I was released from the hospital, again with 120 pk and 2 more refills.

So lets review, I was in a coma for almost 2 weeks, I have a 10 inch scar on my stomach, I'm missing 8 inches of my large intestines, in the past 2 and a half years I've spent almost 2 months in 2 different hospitals, and I'm still addicted to pain killers.

The moment I discovered Kratom, the grasp pain killers had on me was released, my life improved in ways that I can't put into words.  I suddenly could think clear, I didn't crave pain killers, I had money again, and most of all I had hope. Hope that I was going to win.  All the things that happened to me while I has on pk's was not enough to wake me up, kratom did wake me up. 

I know for a fact that I'm not the only person with a story like this. You want to solve the pain killer/ heroin problem in the United States, you already have the answer, KRATOM!  Don't let this important plant go to waste. I'm living proof that it really does work. 

Feel free to look into my medical records if need be, to see I'm not making this story up.

documents.commentText: I have been using Kratom for about 2 months now for discomfort from having a fistula and a peri-rectal abscess. I have only been taking 1 to 2 teaspoons of it, sometimes everynight; but I started taking it only every other 2-3 nights. To me his herb is like other supplements only that it allows me to slow down and & it helps me to relax when I'm in discomfort. I don't feel any toxic affects from it. Toxicity is usually one of the main indicators of whether anything is addictive. I don't feel it makes me high. I just feel it helps me be more inside of my body and it assists with allowing my body to balance out stress & pain, making me feel comfortable. I am a care giver & for the last 9 months I've been working everyday for my client. I am clearly burnt out from not having any days off in such a long time, not to mention not having a vacation or much time for recreation. Kratom has helped me to bottom out this stress that this situation is causing me. The main thing that impresses me about taking Kratom is that it does this without causing any side effects. I feel more alert when I'm taking it, & this wouldn't be the case with prescription drugs that are given for pain or anti-depression drugs. Again I reiterate that there doesn't seem to be any toxic effects from using it, even on a daily basis. Prescription drugs, such as the opiods, that are addictive are very toxic; especially if taken over a long period of time. I work at least 40 hours a week for my client. She is an elderly woman who is 82 years old. She has limited mobility, and she has diabetes. She is mainly bed ridden, and can't get up on her own out of bed. She is type I bi-polar and has arthritis, and most of the time she is in extreme pain. I have been giving her Kratom in capsules for a little over a month now. She would usually have somewhat violent outbursts & hysterical behavior when the pain got too extreme for her, and she felt overwhelmed with anxiety. None of the many psychiatric drugs she is taking, such as depakot, klonopin, or buspiron, exhibit the same results of taking the edge off her pain & depression and give her a better quality of sleep than the Kratom does. When a person such as my client, who arguably has a short time to live in this life, is given a better quality of life by using this one herb it is pretty miraculous, and it just may give her a longer life by helping her to sustain her strength & keep a more positive mental outlook in dealing with the effects of neurological pain, the depression surrounding diabetes, and the type of mental illness she has. I have seen a handful of videos on YouTube from Kratom users who have told their stories about what they've been dealing with and how the Kratom has given them a higher quality of life than was possible with the opiod drugs. One video particularly caught my attention that told the story of a mother whose son had been addicted to opiods, and she didn't find this acceptable at all, so she had him try the Kratom. He proclaimed that he had profound results, because not only was he able to let go of his addiction to the opiod prescription drugs, but it released him from depression from the pain his body was in and allowed him to have a much more positive frame of mind in dealing with his mental & physical problems. After having taken the Kratom myself I see how this could be. I was initially given the information about Kratom from a close friend who I have known about seven years. She has Lyme Disease. She said that she had been taking Kratom for 3 years. She told her story of how it has helped her to deal with the effects of the Lyme Disease, and how the Lyme disease has wore down her immune system, & the immense level of pain she has had to endure. She said that using the Kratom all during this time has enabled her to get rid of taking many drugs that had toxic side effects, which caused discomfort and pain; and how it has been the main thing that has allowed her to have a more normal life by being able to get out of bed and take care of her children and be there for her husband. I can't imagine Kratom causing anyone to die. Indeed all of the deaths that have been linked to Kratom were when the user took Kratom with hard drugs. Is it a good idea to mix drugs? I can't see how it is, because so many of the deaths of famous people have been caused this way. I am very confident that Kratom won't risk the health of users. I would classify it as an herbal supplement. I feel that caffeine is so much stronger than Kratom. Giving up long term caffeine use has caused me bad headaches. I can't imagine how Kratom would do this. I am of the opinion that you would be causing so much more harm by banning it and denying people a way to deal with long term pain than saving anyone from harmful effects. I don't feel that it has any. Thank You.

documents.commentText: My name is Daniel Coleman.  I am 27 years old, I live in Los Angeles and I work as a lead engineer on mobile application development for a major corporation, where I have worked for the last five years.  I discovered kratom when I was reading about the public health crisis of opiate addiction and overdose (I personally know two people in my age group who are dead from heroin overdoses).  I heard people discussing kratom as something people can use to wean themselves off of opiates and handle the otherwise very painful withdrawal.  At the time I myself was dealing with a decade-long addiction to marijuana that I had been trying for the last year, unsuccessfully, to overcome, and figured it may be possible that kratom could help with that too.  At first the fact that kratom is an opioid scared me away from it.  It was a full year after I first heard of it that I decided since I felt nearly hopeless about overcoming my own addiction, I might as well give it a try.  Two months after I began using kratom I completely stopped using marijuana and it has now been six months since I have touched any form of it, the longest I have gone since I was 15 without smoking marijuana.  My life has massively improved from beating my addiction and I cannot imagine beating it without kratom.  Additionally, I have always suffered from mild depression and anxiety and I have found kratom to be a very effective treatment, after trying pharmaceutical antidepressants and not liking them.  I know from experience that kratom is more like coffee than a psychoactive drug.  It may cause slight changes in mood but you cannot get "high" off of kratom, like you can off of marijuana or other drugs.  Taking more does not intensify the effects, it just leads to nausea.  It is also completely safe.  It is not possible to overdose and face a life-threatening situation with kratom.  I have taken too much and just got sick for 30-4 minutes.  I urge you to consider the actual repercussions of criminalizing kratom.  Since so many people use it to get off of dangerous psychoactive drugs, they may end up relapsing.  Kratom awareness may be key to ending the crisis of opiate addiction, which will only get worse if kratom is banned.  I understand and sympathize with the desire to keep dangerous drugs off the streets.  But kratom is not one of them.  Kratom is not, and has never been, a "legal high", even if dishonest scammers try to sell it as one.  Thank you for giving me a chance to voice my concern and I hope you take the testimonies you receive on behalf of kratom to heart.

documents.commentText: I've served six years in the military and with two tours to Afghanistan, both of which followed with the struggle of minor PTSD, the contrast of the two post returning home are vastly different in managing and defeating my PTSD. The first tour I did as many did and was embarrassed and ashamed or too proud and stubborn to admit having PTSD. Seven months after being back... I was separated and eventually divorced. I suffered from severe anxiety, insomnia as well as the other physical complications that come along with it. I saw a therapist and took advantage of all of the yellow ribbon tools available from my unit. It took about two years to fully recover, just in time for my second tour. After returning home from my second tour I was determined not to repeat the process of struggling with PTSD. My second tour was far more intense and twice as long, 6 months the first tour being 60 days. Desperate for a legal and natural solution I began to research. Eventually I came across an article on Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine. Unknowing of what Kratom was or that there was any controversy over the herb I decided it sounded like a potential supplement. I managed my anxiety and insomnia with a warm cup of Kratom tea, 3mg of powder mixed with lemon and honey did the trick and the mild effects lasted for hours. There were no negative side effects that I could tell from this dosage and one cup usually did the trick. In fact the only effects that I can say it had was it made me feel happy, in a good mood and have positive attitude. I dosed as needed and felt no desire or need to have it every day. Within 90 days of starting the tea I had had no panic or anxiety attacks, or avoided them if I felt one coming on with a glass of tea. The same for insomnia. I kept a 25mg bag of the powder in the cabinet for about 6-8 months and eventually only used it for insomnia which I have always wrestled with prior military. To this day this it is the only treatment that I've needed to overcome my PTSD and I've been home for 16 months. For me personally I did not find Kratom to be addictive at all. I haven't purchased or thought about Kratom for months until tonight (insomnia) and remembered how well it worked. I had no idea that there was a pending ban and was surprised to find out about it tonight when I decided to place an order. In my opinion Kratom should be treated like other coffee or tea products. I have no problem with anything I ingest into my body being FDA approved, however I don't have to go to my doctor for a prescription when I want caffeine. Nor do I think I should for this product. I do think there should be studies to ensure there are no long term negative side effects or risk of overdose. Just recently I read a news article about teens doing the "caffeine challenge" and dying from caffeine overdose. I didn't hear about any caffeine ban, because that would be ridiculous. If anything this should be treated as a supplement with a notice that it has not been approved by the FDA or a warning that you would see on a product with caffeine, although the effects are mild in comparison and vastly differ from caffeine. If this ban was enacted and had I not come across the information, my military career could have been jeopardized if it were on the banned substance list and I were popped with a random urinalyses, that I am not okay with. I haven't seen it on the military's list so far but I will definitely be watching for it. I ask that the plan to ban be revoked and ask vendors to place a warning or notice of the effects on the packaging.

documents.commentText:
First and foremost, I would like to offer a gesture of appreciation and to sincerely commend such consideration of constitutional right and civil liberty from Drug Enforcement Administration officials.. THANK YOU FOR SERVING OUR COUNTRY!!! Secondly, to give thanks to whomever has the opportunity to read and include this comment in our debate.  

In regards to subjecting Mitragyna speciosa and/or some of its chemical properties to the Controlled Substances Act:

We the People have the responsibility to question EVERY aspect of law passed and/or enforced and are obligated to be mindful of ALL regulatory proposals pertaining to action - whether it be based on prior extension of an amendment - or legislature;  likewise, whether it be deemed appropriate upon the commonality of suspicion. 

These suggestions of prohibition should include EVERYONE'S opinion, discussion, and choice to abstain. Furthermore, in an undoubted respect, we are to expect responsible and concise conduct by those elected and/or assigned in our justice and intelligence agencies, as well as to critique the rationality and motive of lawmakers in our states and federal government.  

With that being evident..

We all have our beliefs of how things are the way they are. Religiously. Spiritually. Philosophically. Though, we all can agree on the simple, deductive reasoning, that our species has lived and thrived by nourishment of plants. Some may suggest the significance of adapting to agriculture as detrimental for the very origin of settlement.

As a matter of fact, mankind has used plants for medicinal and "recreational" purposes for longer than history itself can account. And, in some contrast, the vast of religions suppose there is indeed purpose for their presence.  
  
No matter where someone may be in our country or on our planet, something as natural as a plant should never be subject to restriction.. prohibition.. propaganda. It simply contradicts its place on earth, and is, perhaps, even dangerous to its existence. One may as well place it on an endangered species list.

As a citizen of the United States, I oppose any such action to make credible, the assumption in illegality of something natural. It's our individual, earth-born right to behave in any manner regarding NATURAL substances. Needlessness to say, if one would like to eat a poisonous mushroom - it's their NATURAL RIGHT! We can only education, pity and mourn those who are unable to distinguish nectar from poison. Likewise, Some system of government can't simply demand chili peppers be illegal -- because they burn our mouths. That includes ALL AGRICULTURE (e.g., the legalization of marijuana is inevitable).  

In conclusion, please review current practices and anticipate the inevitable changes in our society. Inorganic/Synthetic drugs are what truly plague our youth and principles. Natural "solutions" could become quite the answer to the problems of drugs such as methamphtamines, LCD, etc.  

Note: It would be more beneficial to the Drug Enforcement Agency to focus more on the pharmaceutical industry. It is being overlooked.

documents.commentText:
Hello -

I am 59 years old, and have been employed as an Information Technologist at the local university for 18+ years.  

I am writing in support of keeping Kratom, in it's natural form, as an unregulated herbal remedy.  I am a recovering alchoholic (20 years sober) with mild depression.  I have found that Kratom, in conjunction with my normal 10 mg / daily prescribed anti-depressant (Celexa aka Citalopram), to be helpful for my mood, I take 10 grams of the organic powder on a weekly basis in a chocolate milkshake, prior to ingestion I drink some quinine water to potentiate the effect, and also take an antiemetic (Dramamine aka Dimenhydrinate) to reduce the nausea caused by Kratom ingestion.

I have found Kratom to be mildly addictive, but nothing that is causing me to increase my dosage, the above is working for me.  I will say that the "enhanced" products being sold (where the active component of Kratom is extracted and concentrated on the leaf product) I think could be an issue.  Not for me, I would not buy it, but maybe for kids that get a hold of it.  My suggestion would be to not restrict the organic, un-enhanced product, and enforce an over 18 requirement, like for tobacco.  I would support restriction the enhanced product.

Anecdotally, because of the reasonably low concentration of Mitragynine and the related active components in the organic leaf, it is difficult to imagine ingesting enough to cause anyone serious harm.  I know there are exceptions to everything, but ingesting, lets say 100 grams of the stuff would not be worth the effect in my opinion (!).

One other important note I think:  Since Kratom as a plant (I believe it is a tree) is difficult to grow, particularly in the North American continent, I think the supply is limited pretty much to what is imported, at least currently.  Also, being a 'perennial' tree vs. an 'annual' (e.g. Marijuana) limits the degree to which folks would be able to increase the Mitragynine content via plant breeding or chemical methods (e.g. application of Colchicine to Marijuana to induce polyploidy).

Thank you for your attention

:-)

documents.commentText:
I am a woman; daughter, sister,mother, grandmother and friend with a loving family and support system. I work at a Medical Examiners Office as a Forensic Pathology Technician. It is a job that makes many people say, "Eeeeww!" but I see and learn something new every day. I find this to be very rewarding and I love my job. I am proud to be an employed and productive member of my community, and I have Kratom to thank for helping me maintain the stamina required of me daily. I can't imagine having to change the kind of work I do because of the physical, emotional and mental distractions that  chronic pain brings.
I have suffered from chronic pain (failed neck surgery, DDD and nerve damage) for 15 years. In the last 5, as I have come closer to 60 years of age, I have gradually been able to do less and enjoy less and have become a really unhappy person because of pain. I also wondered how in the world I would be able to continue to work until retirement age... sometimes when adding all this together I couldn't help but wonder, "what's the use?".
I have made many lifestyle changes in an effort to bring back some of the old me. Lost some weight, added some herbal supplements, and learned about kratom. What I learned in my research is that it deserves the opportunity that I have been affording my other supplements. And so, I added kratom to my daily supplements! It has had such a positive impact on my life, my pain levels and my overall sense of well-being.
I can't say that I don't ever have pain anymore, but what I can say, is that things are not as dark as they once were. I am more hopeful. I am more well balanced. I am not as focused on my pain. I am able to do more than just sit with my grand children; I am now a fun grandmother! I can finally work in my garden again. I get to experience the joy that has been missing for far too long! My quality of life has improved and I am happy and thankful!
So I have to ask...why would you want to take that from anyone?
Amy Hendricks

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern:
I take 1/2 tsp to 1 tsp of powdered kratom in a tea as needed for severe, episodic fatigue. This fatigue I experience is debilitating, and does not respond to caffeine. Although I have taken legally prescribed amphetamine for this, the amphetamine has unpleasant side effects such as heart palpitations and anxiety which are extremely unpleasant. As such, restrictive scheduling of kratom will significantly decrease my quality of life. 

I understand the DEA's concern over kratom because, like other psychoactive substances (e.g. caffeine, alcohol), it does have the potential for abuse. One way to address this would be to require sellers to include safety information about kratom with all purchases, as is required for alcohol and tobacco products. 

Requiring sellers to provide certifications of purity is another good step toward improving safety of supplements in general, including kratom. This would've prevent that one death related to tramadol-laced kratom.

Another option may be to limit the more potent kratom extracts that are available for purchase, or limit the amount that can be sold to one individual over a period of time. However, if caffeine (which is also toxic at high concentrations) can be sold without a prescription in tablet form, I don't see the necessity for this measure since such high amounts of kratom would be needed to induce toxicity. 

Personally, I think a good compromise would be to assign kratom to schedule IV, but only AFTER the active compounds are available with a prescription. 

I challenge the DEA to be both scientific in their approach to scheduling, and considerate as to whether any scheduling of kratom might harm more citizens than it helps. 

Sincerely,
A fifth year immunology PhD student and mother of one

documents.commentText:
I am a 64-year-old, retired, mental health professional with rheumatoid arthritis and fibromyalgia. These conditions are treated by physicians and I am, otherwise, healthy. I've raised children and grandchildren while being actively involved in their lives. I was an athlete and a jazz dancer until my late forties. In the past ten years, my normal activity level and ability to remain physically involved with friends and family has been curtailed by pain associated with my medical conditions. In spite of following all suggestions and treatment plans provided by medical professionals, the pain associated with these conditions has continued to impact my life in negative ways. The discovery of Kratom, as an herbal nutritional supplement, has changed my life with its softening of my pain and capability of return to a functioning life.  

    I've always believed that I had a high tolerance to pain and have only received prescription pain meds for tooth pain and post surgical procedures. Over the years, I occasionally took muscle relaxers when I suffered a sports injury that didn't resolve after a few days. I've always sought alternate ways of dealing with pain aside from pills. The relentless, chronic pain associated with my current health has come as a shock...especially since the severity of it varies, over time, and it is unpredictable in occurrence and capability of responding to my efforts to manage it and not have it take me down.

    Taking me down, in pain, means that I was never sure if plans I made could be followed, if I would be able to spend time with my family on a holiday, able to get to medical appointments, take a shower, shop for groceries, clean cat litter box, pick up mail, etc. Sometimes I dreaded not knowing what the next day would  bring: a better day than the current day or back to worse pain than I was relatively free of on that day. Going to bed was a curse. Waking up could be a curse. Sleep wasn't  a guaranteed escape because pain could prevent sleep....or wake me during the night, unable to return to sleep. Sometimes I felt overcome to the point of sobbing from pain and frustration. My mental health has suffered. I'd become an isolated, cranky, person...shoving everyone in my life away with my anger...something that snuck up on me as I've struggled in getting on top of what had turned out to be a situation that was not going away. At times, relentless episodes of pain have taken me down the path of depression to contemplation of suicide. 

    There exists a catch-22 in dealing with chronic pain: the exercises and activity level which is supposed to help, in providing degrees of relief, are often not possible because of pain which limits capability to engage in activity without pain.

    In my personal path of researching methods of dealing with pain outside of medical care, I learned to use a specific type of pillow to support my head, benefit of OTC products, and came across the mention of Kratom. I spent dozens of hours researching this herbal plant. I read three books, numerous articles, and followed blogs. I determined that an occasional reference to it as a recreational substance seemed to have sprung from its rumored application to pain issues. There will always be a small percentage of the population who seek something from which to get "high"; they hear "pain" treatment and they think euphoric opioid effects. 

My personal preference has been to avoid the use of pharmaceutical opioids as long as possible. I am aware of the pitfalls of potential addiction. My experience with them...post surgery and teeth extraction...has been unpleasant. They leave me lethargic, fuzzy-headed, and with a sense of depression. I can't imagine that a dependency on them would make my life a whole lot better than one of living with chronic pain. 

When researching vendors of Kratom, I found that it was fairly easy to identify legitimate suppliers who were helpful, informational, and did not offer medical advice or claims that their product treated specific conditions or disease. In addition to my background in psychology, I have medical experience and have studied chemistry. I understand what is known about how Kratom works and I've been excited to see what will unfold, in knowledge, from current scientific research on this plant.

I was shocked, recently, to learn about the ban on this herb and the halt of research outside of pharmaceutical companies seeking patents for synthetics. I've also come to learn about the application of Kratom in the area of opiate and opioid addiction. It is not a replacement for these substances and it does not provide recreational value.

I do not understand why agencies of our government seek to create a potential drug epidemic by leaving a chunk of the population without legal  access to this plant, nor how a claim of managing an opioid drug epidemic can be made. It's that simple.

documents.commentText:
Dear Drug Enforcement Administration,

My name is Lauren and I am a manager at a store that sells kratom. I have been doing this for over four years now. As such, I am very familiar with kratom, the people who use it, and the reasons as to why they use it. I am writing this because I am in a more unique position than most individuals when it comes to seeing what the day to day use of kratom looks like due to the fact that I interact with a large number of kratom users on a daily basis. Although I work in a retail environment I graduated college with a degree in Psychology. A significant amount of my education centered around addiction, treatment, and the numerous issues surrounding substance use and abuse. I am not claiming to be an expert, but I was well educated in this subject from a university known for their Psychology program.

When I first began working in my current field I had never heard of kratom. But I quickly realized that it was a popular item. So i decided to research it. Eventually I decided to try it myself since it seemed to pose minimal (if any) risk and had the potential to be beneficial. I was surprised by the fact that it did indeed help with physical pain that I had been experiencing. I was also surprised by the fact that something this effective was completely natural and did not get me high. Like many Americans I have been prescribed narcotic pain medications before. Fortunately for me however, I never became addicted to them. Though I can understand why others do.

I legally sell kratom every day that I go to work. And I sell it to a wide array of people. Moms, dads, grandparents, military veterans, firefighters, police officers, doctors, and more. These people use kratom for a variety of reasons. These reasons include pain management, PTSD, anxiety, depression, and withdrawal from prescription pain medication. Interestingly enough, some people are using kratom in order to get off of things like Suboxone and Methadone. I find it ironic that these medications designed to get addicts off of opiates seem to be addictive to some users. Regardless, kratom has definitely helped many of the ones that I have dealt with at work.

Over the years I have quite literally seen people turn their lives around. I have gotten to watch and listen to people who have effectively and safely used kratom to help get themselves sober. Many of these people are not your cliche drug users that you imagine when you think of addicts. I have been shocked to see how many "normal" people - who I never would have imagined to be opiate addicts - come through our door. Most of these people are working professionals who are educated and have families. I find many of these people to be really great human beings. And over the years I have become very sympathetic to the situation that they are in. Like Bethany, the wife and mother of two children who works for the United Way and sings in her church's choir. She developed an addiction to pain pills after they were prescribed by her doctor. I was shocked to learn that she had been an addict. And I am happy to see her living a normal, happy, and healthy life. She is a great friend, and she does a lot of good for the world.

But as I stated earlier, I sell to many other demographics than just addicts. Word has gotten around in the veteran and military community that kratom has the ability to help with PTSD. And in many cases with the chronic pain they are dealing with because of what they have done for their country on our behalf. I come from a military family and grew up as an "Army brat" to a father who is a high ranking medical professional. I have a big heart and the deepest respect for those who have served our nation. And I feel privileged to be able to in some way help them in return. Much like I have seen addicts turn their lives around, I have seen countless warriors get their lives back. People who could barely leave their house who have now reintegrated to civilian life. People with missing limbs who can now go about their life with less pain without being loaded full of narcotics. Kratom has obviously helped them regain some semblance and normalcy in their lives. I think that taking kratom away from these people would be incredibly cruel and detrimental to many of them and their families. Please, do not do this to these people. They, and their families, have given and suffered so much. And now you are thinking about making a plant - that does not get you high - a scheduled substance. In my humble opinion, this is going to be a serious blow to these Americans who are already suffering enough and have an astonishingly high rate of suicide. You may not care about drug addicts or feel sympathetic towards them. But surely you care about the people who we send into the deepest recesses of hell so that we may enjoy our safety, liberty, and current standard of living.

So think hard about what you are about to do. And ask yourself: Is this really a good idea?

documents.commentText:
I am a 28 year old man with a promising background. I went to a reputable liberal arts university and was at the top of my class, but by the time I graduated I had very severe anxiety. 

I was caught in a bad cycle after graduating from university. I was only working low-level jobs, because my anxiety made it difficult (nearly impossible, even) to pursue something more challenging even though I knew I was otherwise capable of doing far more. Because these jobs didn't offer insurance and I didn't have enough money to pay for it myself, I was stuck without a viable solution.

I sometimes turned to alcohol, though the effects the day after always negated any positive anxiety reduction and loss of inhibitions.

A friend recommended kratom, but when I looked into it I was initially skeptical. I was reluctant to try anything that was associated with opiates, as I knew how destructive that class of drugs tends to be. 

Eventually I decided to give it a shot because the anxiety was so persistent and I wanted anything that might alleviate it. I was surprised not to full a 'buzz' or anything of the sort when I first gave it a try.

What I noticed instead was that it helped me to not fall into my anxious thought cycles. I felt healthy and motivated, able to socialize and accomplish tasks and work toward being my best self.

I now take kratom 3-4 days per week, and it still helps me immensely. I run my own very profitable blog and also do freelance writing and business consulting on the side. This is a huge change from where I was even a few years ago, and I can attribute much of my success to kratom helping me overcome mental hurdles.

It is not by any means an intoxicating drug. It has helped me to focus, contribute to society, cultivate better friendships and romantic relationships, and be my best self. I genuinely fear what might happen if I no longer have access to this plant. Please consider the very real consequences this would have on people like me before you take the plant away. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Greetings,

I write now to express my sincere opposition to kratom being categorized as a Schedule 1 drug.

As an emergency and primary care physician, I am in a position to have carefully weighed the pros and cons of this very important and potentially dvery harmful decision.

Kratom has been used for centuries as a practical and safe way to improve function in those who suffer from chronic debilitating pain. Many patients are also discovering the value of kratom in decreasing or eliminating their dependence on prescription pain medications.

The pharmaceutical industry has a vested interest in debunking methods of pain management which do not further its own agenda. I certainly hope the influence of corporate pharmaceutical lobbyists is not a factor in the DEA's decision making process. No doubt big pharma is chomping at the bit to make kratom "their own", furthering their already astronomical profits, at the expense of the health and wellbeing of the American people.                                                   

The fact that the number of poison center calls regarding kratom has rapidly increased in no way translates to a need to schedule this plant. It merely suggests more people are discovering it's value and wishing to gain further information. 

The DEA loses credibility when it fails to responsibly assess it's decisions in a manner consistent with good science. Evidence of harm from this plant is so vastly outweighed by innumerable reports of its efficacy. If for no other reason than reducing prescription drug abuse, the DEA might please consider leaving well enough alone! The use of plants to improve the human condition began thousands of years ago, and will continue. 

Has the DEA still not acknowledged the failure of the "War on Drugs"? Kratom has not demonstrated sufficient harm in a significant number of people to warrant efforts to eradicate it's use. These efforts will result only in harm by denying legal access to many thousands of legitimate safe, responsible users who deserve the freedom to choose. 

Are there no potential risks to kratom remaining available without criminalization? Of course not!  But until the unlikely day that it's use is shown to harm more people than it helps, it is unjustified and irresponsible to make it a controlled substance in an era when there are so many bigger fish to fry.

As a physician, a patient, and an American, I implore the DEA to more carefully evaluate the evidence (or lack thereof) and allow kratom to be used without criminalization.

I sincerely appreciate the DEA's recent decision to allow discussion of this matter. 

With Thanks and Respect,

Ely Zaslow MD

documents.commentText:
Dear Regulators:

I am writing to you today about an organic herb that is the ground leaf of a tree in the same family as coffee. The media has recently begun portraying this safe herbal tea as some kind of "new" heroin or cocaine, or even a hallucinogen, which couldn't be further from the truth. And we all know about the 'hasty' ban that was narrowly avoided. Kratom should be viewed as an important tool in the solution to the opiate/opioid epidemic, not just another green plant for government agencies to vilify for profit.  Kratom has a 2000-year history of safe, responsible use as a detox from opium and alternative to dangerous drugs such as opium and heroin which is easily verified. The Botanical Education Alliance website (botanical-education.org) and Transnational Institute (TNI.org) have extensive medical and scientific papers available showing both its efficacy and almost foolproof safety profile.  Ithas greatly enhanced the chances of opiate addicts to achieve permanent recovery for the same period of time, inexpensively and unofficially. During the last 15 years it has become a staple of many successful Narcotics Anonymous participants, boosting long term sobriety rates by preventing PAWS relapses.

There is no respiratory depression associated with Kratom, an established scientific fact, making it impossible to overdose, since one simply upchucks a larger than necessary amount. There hasneverbeen a death associated with use of Kratom leaf alone --compare that with any prescription opiate/opioid, much less street drugs.

I worked for a time as a legislative aid, so I understand that lawmakers and regulators have many demands on their time and sometimes only have time to scan the lobbyist statements before voting on some issues.Don't let that be the case with Kratom.

You wanted a silver bullet for the opiate crisis? --here it is use it!

Many thousands, or more, mature American citizens have found kratom to be a safer alternative to opioids or western medicines' "solutions" and an entirely new lease on life without any of the harms or side effects associated with either street drugs or the tightrope of prescription substitutes.

The only connection that Kratom (mitragyna speciosa) has with opiates is its ability to safely block withdrawal symptoms of street drugs like heroin or dangerous Rx opiates/opioids and provide a safe alternative for pain management and/or mood support. It does not produce a "high" that users will chase, and is ineffective as a a recreational drug. It is actually quite subtle. Other than an absence of pain, no one would notice its effects any more than an espresso coffee. The rest is media hype and misinformation by mislead anti-drug groups and pharmaceutical companies who have noticed a drop in their revenues from the highly-addictive opiate/opioid Rx medications that are wreaking havoc on our society.

Thousands of older adults have been spared the horrid effects of prescription drug abuse by using this relatively harmless dietary supplement as a simple tea. If a ban on Kratom becomes law, responsible adult Americans will no longer be free to avoid the snare of chronic opiate dependence.Leave Americans a choice, don't become the drug pushers!

Allow the many adult, responsible users of this herbal tea to educate you, and you will likely come to the same conclusion as the legislators in most States, that an age restriction of 18+ or 21+ is more than enough "protection" for consumers of this rather harmless herbal tea.

Thank you for allowing common sense to rule this issue rather than media hysteria and misinformation. I realize the war on drugs is always a high political priority, but don't shoot yourselves in the foot. Americans will benefit from your good sense. Good health to you.

John Hilger
Penacook, NH 03303
highwaterz2@gmail.com

documents.commentText:
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: Thank you for reading my comments. I'm an active, athletic wellness professional who's used kratom consistently for 3 years. Now 40 years old, I live with arthritis from two spine surgeries from competitive athletic injuries sustained before the age of 20. I take a heaping teaspoon of kratom in the evenings before doing yoga/meditation and have found it more effective than anything else for pain relief as well as mental clarity and overall feelings of ease and wellbeing. Although never really a "problem", I've also noticed since taking kratom that I've lost interest in alcohol and don't experience food cravings. I had experienced difficulties sleeping in the past and now sleep much better when taking kratom. I've never wanted more than the dose I started with as I've found that more is not better when it comes to this substance. It's truly amazing how effective and beneficial this plant has been in my life and I request the right to continue using this as a responsible adult.

documents.commentText: Please allow us to keep kratom on the market..  I am in recovery from heroin for over 2 nd a half years..in February I was t-boned by a 20 year old kid and ended up having my car totalled nd I got hurt..I went to the doctors where they tried to prescribe me Percocet and Vicodin at the same time..I told them immediately I am in recovery nd I can't take those nd I would like a non narcotic..they proceeded to prescribe me tramadol..which gave me the impression it was a non narcotic..little did I know it was moved from a non narcotic to a narcotic nd I wasn't informed by that.  I ended up having a seizure from the tramadol nd landed in the hospital for a few days and tested positive for PCP..I was mortified nd immensely confused because I hadn't touched a drink or a drug in almost 2 years at that point..after doing research the doctors confirmed that I had a false positive from the tramadol nd I had to stop the drug immediately ..but by this time I was addicted..I didn't know what to do nd I was horrified I had to go through this all over again ..finally a friend recommended kratom..I decided to try it nd it helped me get off the tramadol with ease nd with no side effects..it even helped me get off of all psych meds nd prescriptions I was on nd I haven't put a pill in my body for months now..kratom has helped me more than the doctors ever had since my accident ..please do not take this off the market for it can be detrimental to people like me after all the good it has done..I hope my story can reach at least one person because I have gone through alot nd disclosed my addiction but it fell upon deaf ears..please help stop the drug pushing nd not the herb that has helped so many like me.

documents.commentText:
My partner has been using Kratom several times a week for pain caused by 3 separate automobile accidents. In all 3 cases, she was riding in the back seat of the car, and suffered multiple injuries that have been compounded by scoliosis.

For years, here only option for pain management was the use of pharmaceuticals, OTC and prescribed, that caused uncomfortable and dangerous side-affects. A couple of years ago, she discovered Kratom, and found that is significantly reduced her pain, and without side effects. Since then, she has been using small doses of Kratom instead with great success. In fact, over the last year, she has been reducing her Kratom dosing as she continues physical therapy and other treatments to heal her body.

The DEA claims that Kratom is an "imminent hazard to the public safety." This is hyperbole, pure and simple. As this Newsweek article points out, single use laundry pods are vastly more dangerous to public safety than Kratom: http://www.newsweek.com/dea-list-kratom-schedule-i-effectively-outlawing-herbal-supplement-495144

Neither my partner nor I are recreational drug users. My partner uses Kratom only in small doses- primarily because she doesn't want to build up a resistance to it's effects, and secondarily because larger doses give her an upset stomach.... yes, that's right, Kratom has its own mechanism to deal with over use.

I am contacting you as a concerned citizen, because I have seen the major benefits in quality of life that my partner credits directly to Kratom. She is distraught that she may not be able to obtain Kratom in the future, and if she can, she is worried that since it will be illegal, she will have major concerns about quality and purity. Making Kratom illegal will have the unintended side effect of actually making it dangerous. Please do not disenfranchise the thousands of people that use Kratom for pain relief.

documents.commentText:
Respectful greetings, my name is Matthew Wood. I am 36 years old and have been employed as a Trust Settlement Officer Assistant for the past 4 years. I am writing this, to humbly opose the Dea's intent to include Mitragynine and 7- hydroxymitragynine on the schedule 1 controlled substances list.

I started using Kratom about 2 and half years ago. I discovered and decided to sample Kratom after searching on the internet for legal stimulants similar to caffeine. I was looking for an additional plant stimulant that I could use to provide an energy boost that I desperately needed. This is because I have to battle treatment resistant Bipolar 2 Disorder and chronic fatigue disorder on a daily basis. These illness have robbed me of my, physical energy, desire, motivation, and ability to enjoy my life. 

In my experience, moderate use of Kratom and Caffeine have been the  safest, healthiest, and most effective ways to manage my illness, because they temporary restore my energy,  motivation, desire, and ability to enjoy living life. I do not like to use either every day because I like to keep a low tolerance and maintain their effectiveness. I do this by using them each for 2 days a week, but on different days from each other. They both help me live a more normal active life for at least 4 out the 7 weekdays.

I've been on several antidepressants and mood stabilizers. None of them were effective enough, and some of them even wrecked havoc on periods of my life. Kratom is a has been a godsend for me, and my life wouldn't be as beneficial without it. If Kratom is scheduled and no longer legal, I would lose a very powerful tool that I stratigicaly use to help me live a normal life 2 days each week

Before closing, I wanted to address your potentional concern about Kratom addiction and apply it to my own life. I have developed a physical dependency to kratom in the past. I also have developed a physical dependence to caffeine just like milions of Americans,  but It took a much longer time for Kratom tolerance and dependency to build. When I wanted to quit Kratom I was able to avoid withdrawal symptoms by doing a simple taper. I now chose to avoid dependency all together by using Kratom as  recommended, which is every 3 days. 

In closing, I humbly ask that the DEA please keep this plant which I greatly respect, legally available to myself and many other Americans who responsibly use it to manage their illness and chronic physical pain.  I lost my wonderdful cousin Nicholas Gangemi when he was 35, to prescription pain killer abuse, a few years before I discovered Kratom. I wonder to this day if he still might be alive had I discovered it sooner. Please consider reviewing this article emphasising the need and importance of Kratom for pain killer use and research.

https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/kratom-drug-ban-may-cripple-promising-painkiller-research/


I genuinely thank You for taking the time read and consider my personal testimony on Kratom.

Scincerely, 

Matthew Wood

I can function with full cognitive capabilities, and there is no affect on coordination or nervous system impairment.  I have spoken with dozens of people who use it for withdraw from prescription pain medications successfully.  This is incredible and so much better than having to go through expensive rehab programs or having to take prescription drugs to avoid withdraw symptoms.  Kratom does not cause any health problems or negative side affects.  Further, keep in mind that in those cases where some individuals have called for medical help, after ingesting krater, that you are not taking into account how many of those individuals were taking other drugs at the same time as taking Kratom, so you are confounding your assumptions on what Kratom does or does not do.  Let's face it, a person can overdose on caffeine and have a bad outcome.  Even too much vitamin C can cause negative symptoms.  At the end of the day, there is NO reason Kratom should be outlawed or restricted.  Thank you!

documents.commentText:
Hello,
Thank you for taking the time to read my comment. I am respectfully requesting that these natural substances remain legal. My background: In July, 2005 I was sitting at a stop light waiting for the traffic light to turn green. A man in a Ford F-350 slammed into the back of my 2000 Toyota Camry. This totaled my car. After I was released from Littleton Hospial in Colorado, I met with my doctor. My doctor assessed me, and prescribed medicine to help my body heal. Over time, my body ached very badly. I did not get better. I didn't understand why. I was an Army Reserve Soldier in excellent shape. My name came down on orders to be deployed to a unit that needed a nurse. I knew my job, had learned it well. I was not allowed to be deployed due to my neck, back, body hurting constantly. I was a fast tracker in the Army Reserves. I earned the rank of E6 (Staff Sergeant) within four years. I had to go to a doctor to be assessed. Long story short, I was given 2 (2's) in my PUHLES Scoring. This killed my career, and left the Army in April 2006. Now it is November 2017. I was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia, Degenerative disc disease, and there are problems with my spine. I have met with various medical doctors, 1 Orthopaedist, Acupuncture from the traditional School of Chinese Medicine, Psyologist for decompression therapy. and now the VA Clinic. My doctor said there are no other medicines to try. I used to take oxycodone/Apap 5/325-very low dosage for pain. The CDC has made it to where doctors don't prescribe pain meds like they used to. So now, I only have these natural substances to take-this works to allow the pain level to decrease so that I may go to work and be productive. I have worked 25 long years for the government, I am trying to make it 5 more years to lock into retirement. I have to work to pay my monthly bills. Please, allow these natural substances to remain legal. This is all I have for pain that works. Thank you for your time. 
Respectfully, 
Jacqueline Anderson

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: Kratom has saved me from A life of horror. I was prescribed Pain Medication for an injury that lead to pain management. I soon realized I was addicted to this medication and was in big trouble. I tried to taper off a few times but being the sole provider working two jobs to support a family of five prevented me from ever having the time to get clean. I stayed in this struggle for three years then decided to try the maintenance drug Suboxone which is a horrible drug. I lost nearly 50 lbs became very depressed, lost & easily aggravated I hated myself. I nearly lost everything while under my doctors "care". My doctor said I needed to be on Suboxone for the rest of my life to prevent relapse but if i wanted to stop taking it the withdrawal was nothing compared to opiate withdrawal. I was on this horrible drug for five years and experienced many bad side effects including depression, anxiety, Low Testosterone, and major muscle loss. On April 1st, 2016, I looked at my self in the mirror and decided I was not ever going to take this medicine again. The withdrawal from Suboxone is brutal i made it 35 days on my own then ended up in the urgent care about to give up still feeling awful. I was in horrible shape, near death, a shadow of the person i desperately wanted to be. I was in terrible pain, near suicidal from the withdrawal depression, unable to work, eat, sleep, lay down, stand up or sit still and with no end to the suffering in sight. Instead of giving up I went on the internet and the Kratom community reached out and gave me a gameplan. So I went and bought a some to give it a try before i gave up and went back to Suboxone. I was very skeptical and the taste was awful but 20 minutes later I started to feel OK, by the 30 minutes mark Ifelt like a million bucks. The pain was gone as was the depression, anxiety which was replaced with hopefulnessand joy for the first time in years. The icky withdrawal feeling was totally gone!  Kratom saved my life and saved my family. I have been off Suboxone, all opiates as well as all the other nasty chemicals my doctor prescribed for me to help with the side effects. It has been 244 days and I feel great, it is great to be off those damaging drugs. All the side effects have disappeared, my life is better then I ever thought it could be and in large part its due to Kratom and the Kratom community. Please do not turn you back on the Doctor made addicts that are victims in the Opiate crisis. Unfortunately i have many friends and family members who did not get the last chance I did.

Hello, My name is Todd. 

I am a 34 year old Order Picker/Loader at a Kroger distribution center in
Ohio. I first stumbled upon Kratom a little over a year ago. while trying to find a way of coping
with chronic pain (Caused by Fibromyalgia).

Over the counter medications wont even begin to touch the pain that I experience on a daily
basis, and can damage my organs. 
Pretty much any prescription medication that l have ever tried..has either had little or no effect contained animal products (which I dont eat), or had side effects, that out weigied the benefits.

The only medications that Have ever given me any relief, were either muscle relaxers (that incapacitated me), or opioid type medications (that come with some serious risks).

While trying to avoid going down the road of becoming heavily dependant on medications, or unconscious in bed for days at a time. I stumbled upon Kratom, and it has helped me immensely.

It takes my pain away. and leaves me feeling awake and aware, when I need to be. It provides me
with long lasting pain relief, and even helps me with anxiety..l believe. Which as a result, helps me
to sleep better at night and function more productively during the day.

Based on how much Kratom has helped me to live a more productive life, (It's also helped me to
maintain my 2.1/2 yr sobriety from alcohol, I do believe) and how mild its effects are, in
comparison to many other substances that I have encountered (many of which obtained legally with no prescription, such as Alcohol).

I Do Not believe that Kratom belongs in a class of 'Drugs' that has no accepted medical use'.

If anything it is quite the opposite. Kratom is a Plant. that has helped a lot of people. It needs to
be researched. and needs to remain available to the people of this nation.

I Do believe, that this plant -if available to the public (at a low cost, as it is now), has great potential to steer a lot of Very Lost people, back into the rigrt direction. 

Away from highly addictive drugs (and alcohol), and back into a life of normality.

If it were categorized as a schedule one drug. it would just create problems for a lot of hard working individuals, and people who are trying to turn their lives around. 

It would limit the amount of research that could be done, on this wonderful plant (that is a related to the coffee plant), and that would definitely not be in the best interest of the American people..if ya ask me. 

Thank you for the comment period. and for taking my comment me consideration.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:  I am a married 56 y/o former real estate agent, with severe chronic cervical spondylosis (aka cervical arthritis/degenerative disc disease).  Last year, I had to retire from my profession due to issues with chronic pain which cannot be treated with surgery.

I learned about kratom from a family member who also has arthritis, and researched it before trying it.   I then bought some myself and tried it.  I found it worked well to minimize my pain, and worked better than some of the prescriptions medications such as Tramadol and Hydrocodone, without the negative side effects.   It also gave me more energy, on par with coffee or vitamin B-12, and improved my mood.   

I take it orally, in capsule form, intermittently, usually two or three 100 mg capsules (200-300 mg).    I found that when taking this herbal product in small quantities, I am able to better tolerate my pain and have a much better quality of life, and reduce the other opiate based medications such as Tramadol and Hydrocodone.  Also, the other medications I have been taking to treat my pain have caused problems with tinnitus that has worsened over time, but I do not have any issues with tinnitus if I use kratom instead.

I have not found this plant to be habit forming in any way, but take it only as needed, and have started and stopped it several times without any issues.  I am pleased to find a natural product that does not have the habit forming aspects of hydrocodone or oxycodone, which I have been prescribed in the past.   

I understand some people use this herbal product to reduce their intake of other opiate-based drugs, which I think is a great benefit to our society, as I have read a lot about the issues in some areas with opiate dependency, and how this has ruined many people's lives.  

In contrast, I see no such risk with kratom. Therefore, I hope that those who oversee this will consider a special status for this plant, or implement a moratorium on the proposed ban, so that chronic pain sufferers like myself are able to reduce their use of opiate-based medication by using this mild herbal product instead.  It has certainly worked well for me, and I have taken it now for a five or six months.   

I see this product falling under the category of dietary supplement, and it could easily be regulated by existing laws under DSHEA. 

Finally, it would be a lose-lose scenario to ban and outlaw kratom, as it would have a negative impact on those who suffer from chronic pain (and have few options already), those who have opiate drug dependency and need an alternative, and would create a new class of outlaws in our society of those who have used this product and find it to a very effective herbal alternative.  

I regret that I must provide my testimony anonymously, but feel this is necessary to protect my own privacy, yet I felt this issue was important enough that I wanted to provide my testimony, and I hope it will be well received even if anonymously given.

documents.title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-24659

documents.commentText:
Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa), is a plant from Southeast Asia related to the coffee plant. It is a popular and widely used herbal supplement. People have used it for thousands (if not tens of thousands) of years for physical pain, fever reduction, diarrhea, coughs, hypertension, anxiety, depression, insomnia, and fatigue among other things. Many veterans use kratom to help with PTSD. Countless people have used it to help break their alcohol or opiate addiction. Kratom has saved many lives in this way.
In lower doses it's stimulating like caffeine and in higher doses it's sedating. Most people take it in their morning tea. Though some take it in capsule form because it is so bitter. You do not become inebriated from kratom and it is not an opiate. It does not cause significant or any respiratory depression. It is about as habit forming as coffee. The primary alkaloid in kratom, mitragynine, is also present in the coffee plant. Kratom's effects are mild at most. Millions of Americans (estimated 3-5 million by the AKA) are using kratom today and have been for decades. There are thousands of (possibly more than 10,000 estimated by the BEA) American kratom small businesses.
You tried to emergency schedule (ban) kratom in September. You cited as their reason 15 deaths over a two year timespan. You later admitted that those deaths involved other substances, which were undoubtedly the cause. Compare this to the literal millions of poisonings and deaths caused by things like prescription drugs, alcohol, tobacco, Tylenol, Aspirin, caffeine, laundry detergent pods, etc. every year. This is actually a record of amazing safety not danger. If kratom was actually dangerous as the DEA is currently portraying then there would be millions of dead people. You were actually going to put kratom into Schedule I with heroin and meth which is beyond absurd and frankly insane.
As an example of how kratom is treated in other places, in Canada, kratom is completely legal and classified as a NHP or Natural Health Product under Schedule 1 item 1 (plant or plant material) of the NHP Regulations. In 2015 the Florida Department of Law Enforcement studied kratom and determined that "Kratom does not constitute a significant risk to the safety and welfare of Florida residents." The Florida Department of Health added that, "there are no pervasive health issues that can be attributed to the ingestion of kratom products in Florida."

I have Ehlers Danlos hyper mobility and have had 4 back surgeries now, arthritis removed from left shoulder joint due to hyper mobility and now have to have it removed from my right shoulder, again due to my extreme range of motion.

I also now suffer from chronic pain due to all the back surgeries and also because my L1, my last mobile disk is also now breaking down. I am currently fused from L2 to S1 and both SI joints.

While I am able to receive some opioids to deal with my chronic pain, due to the current opioid hysteria and the CDC guidelines, I am not able to actually receive enough to allow me to live an active lifestyle or work full time. I tend to run out of my prescribed opioids 3 to 4 days early every month and I rely on Kratom to prevent any withdrawal symptoms and to give me pain relief. I am 60 years old and not taking these medications to get "high" but so that I may have some quality of life. I live alone and have animals I have to take care of. I have been trying to get a small cottage business going making organic soaps and lotions to sell at Farmer's Market and on-line to make some funds. I need to have work that allows me to work around my physical disabilities and need to be able to lay down periodically during the day to give my spine a break.

I went over 6 months with no relief and all I had was kratom, which gave me enough relief that I had some quality of life. 

Kratom has been used safely in Asia for millennium and should remain accessible to those who need it. I can attest that when I use Kratom I do get mild pain relief but more importantly it keeps me from suffering from withdrawal symptoms when I run out of my opioids every month due to not receiving an adequate amount.

Please rethink this!

documents.commentText:
Hello!

I am a responsible Kratom supporter and consumer who has been taking Kratom in raw, powdered leaf form for 2 years. Initially, I had heard of Kratom as the legal "high" it has been mistakenly marketed as, and I was severely disappointed. I noticed that my pain was reduced, my mood improved, and I had a little more energy, but there was no euphoria.

I say this because I am one of the Americans that fell into the deep hole of opiate dependence and addiction. In 2002 I rolled a car, blowing out discs in my neck. In 2006 a chiropractor tore a disc again, rendering me in excruciating pain and limited the use of my left arm to 80%. At 26 years old and a father of 3, I looked to doctors for help. I was prescribed opiate medication, muscle relaxers and xanax, THE LETHAL COMBINATION KILLING ANERICANS. I gained significance tolerance to opiates, to the point where I could take 10 times my daily allowance at one time and feel no effects. So, I, like many Americans, turned to illicit drugs and abused my prescriptions. I lost the wife, kids, jobs, house, cars, dignity and self respect. In 2011 I enter rehab. After 4 years of sobriety, I had re injured my back and was faced with the decision to either go back on the opiates that destroyed my life, or live in excruciating pain. I went back on opiates, both prescription and illicit, and my life started to fall apart again. That's when I started looking into alternatives. I found Kratom as an alternitave, and I was told about its "intoxicating" effects, supposedly similar to the opiates I loved. 

I was severely disappointed. There was no high. I felt the effects as discribed before, so I thought more would work better like my pills and dope. I was, again, severely disappointed. I became a little nauseous and vomited up the "extra". I couldn't take enough to get "high", but I found relief from my pain, my depression, and I had some energy that I was lacking. It may have been a side effect of feeling less pain. The pain was not gone, which is good because I know I can't over do things and hurt myself. I know my limits because I can feel without dibilitating pain. 

I have not taken an opiate, muscle relaxer or anti-anxiety medication since finding Kratom. I no longer chase "highs", because I like who I am and like how I feel without being dependent on opiates. My life has improved since I have started taking Kratom as a supplement. My fianc has also found relief from debilitating back pain from degenerative discs and has improved mood offsetting her clinical depression. My neighbor with Chrones disease has found relief from her pain from Kratom. 

I would like to see Kratom regulated like alcohol, tobacco and supplements like Kava and St. John's Wart. It makes sense to have age restrictions and quality control measures to prevent adulteration and keep "head shop" garbage off of the streets. Just like "vaporizers" for nicotine, there are ways to make the market safer for consumers without destroying the quality of life of millions of parents, grandparents, and veterans with PTSD. I believe that the government is designed to represent the will of the people, and the people wish to hold the right to take natural supplements. 

In summary, after seeing my life, my fianc, my neighbors lives all improved by taking a natural organic supplement, I STRONGLY believe that taking Kratom completely off the market will be a significant risk to the opiate epidemic and the veteran suicide epidemic. The risks have been outlined with factual research, showing that Kratom is safer than aspirin, and harms significantly less people, per capita, than doctor prescribed opiate pain killers. It has more benefits by far than alcohol or tobacco, with significantly less harmful effects. All of these claims will be backed up by the research that will be provided by scientists and researchers. I trust the DEA and FDA will make the right choice and base its decision on what the people want. It's our bodies, it's our government. Please do the right thing.

In 2011, I was diagnosed with Rheumatoid Arthritis and prior to that diagnosis, I had been struggling with Chronic Tension Headaches as well as anxiety. My "Medical Professional" had me taking anxiety medication 2x a day as well as sleeping pills at night to help me deal with the symptoms of my anxiety and I have NEVER been through a worse time in my life. The medications caused massive memory loss and unpredictable/dangerous behavior. After a medication-related car accident (the 5th within a 1 year period after YEARS of no driving incidents), a friend recommended that I try kratom. This herb has made a HUGE difference in my life. I'm probably ALIVE today and able to raise my daughters because of it.

For ten years I have been a daily consumer of a 5 MG opiate to control the pain from my very distorted spine.  With all the reports of opiate overdose and death, I have feared that opiates would become illegal and/or unavailable.  Thus, I was quite interested back in September to hear on NPR a discussion about kratom and the Fed's consideration to place these leaves in the same classification as heroin.  Never having heard of kratom, I researched it extensively, reading a multitude of testimonials claiming the pain reducing properties of the leaves for a large variety of painful conditions.

I ordered a bottle of capsules and received a bottle labeled "Vietnam".  I took two or three caps a day in lieu of the opiate and found it to be effective.   When it was nearly gone I placed another order and received a bottle of "Maeng Da"..  Two days after starting to take it, my "stomach of steel" began to hurt with increasing severity over the next several days.  With my gut in an uproar, I wondered if it was connected to the kratom.  My further research revealed that there is such a thing as "kratom stomach flu".  Although I took it for only two or three days, the debilitating "flu" symptoms have persisted for over a week, much to my dismay and disappointment.   I suspect that some strains are kinder to the gut than others, but I have a reluctance to risk further trials.

In addition to its pain reducing properties, kratom is reportedly useful in drug addiction recovery.  For that reason alone, it should remain legal.

This place will not allow me to sign my name.   Sincerely, Eleanor Boyce
