documents.commentText:
I had a much longer letter written out. It went into detail on why I appreciate the opportunity and freedom to comment, and that I would appreciate the preservation of my freedom to consume this particular plant. It discussed why I believe this potential ban is a serious mistake, about the harm it would do to individuals and families, including mine that have regained a chance at life again. It even cited the published research discussing why I believe what I do: that kratom is bereft of respiratory depression, its withdrawals are akin to Restless Leg Syndrome and similar to coffee without the headaches, and that no one has ever died from kratom use alone. I even surmised on what entities are spearheading the ban, and why.

I decided against it. Partly because it was too longwinded, but mostly because I realized that would be a bit demeaning to my readers. I mean, I cant imagine this wouldnt be common knowledge to any government agency that is trying to take this tea from its citizens. I mean, the research is there, albeit limited. And thats another reason the ban would be a mistake. A plant with numerous potential medicinal values being placed in schedule 1 temporarily would extremely restrict its research, including current research at universities across America, if not outright cease research altogether. 

So, instead I will tell my story, for whats it is worth; the concise version. 
I had open heart surgery when I was 3. My son had the same surgery at 20 months old. Over the course of my childhood I had various tests, procedures and more surgeries. I had to have a pacemaker implanted at age 29. In grad school I was eventually diagnosed with cardiac neurosis, a condition where one perseverates and worries about cardiac related fears, including death. Indeed I feared that I was going to suddenly die, every day. I was prescribed SSRIs, benzodiazepines, and various other drugs. Each had their own side effects, but unfortunately most of them did not adequately address my issue, and if it did, the side effects were crippling (brain zaps, inability to focus, lethargy etc). Both my condition and the various side effects of the prescribed medications almost ended my collegiate career and even my marriage. I had a newborn son and simply refused to let it all fall apart. 

I researched online and found a plant named kratom. I researched its alleged safety and efficacy. I decided the potential risks were minimal (vomiting) and the rewards may actually be worth it. 

That was one of the best and most important decisions of my life. After adding a mug of kratom tea to my daily regimen, I was able to focus on finishing graduate school. I got married, had my son Andrew (whos open heart surgery went perfectly at 20 months old) and grew my family with an amazing daughter named Olivia. I moved to Brevard County Florida, began working in our regional medical center as a Registered Dietitian/Nutritionist, 5 years later became a professor at Keiser University all while telling others how kratom had turned my life around. 

My primary care physician supports my choice to consume kratom tea. She is glad that I do not require harder addictive substances such as benzodiazepines. I have even decided to attach my most recent labs for further scrutiny. This is after 10 years of almost daily ingestion.

If kratom is taken from me, I am terrified I will begin to experience full-fledged cardiac neurosis. I am very uncomfortable even entertaining what that will mean to my family, friends, and career. And more than anything, I can only hope that my son will not be stricken with cardiac neurosis, but if he does, I pray that the blessing of a plant named kratom will be there to support him in life, as it was for his father. 

Respectfully yours,

Greg Cannon MS, RD, LD/N

documents.commentText:
Kratom is a plant, in the same family as coffee, and it is known for its mood enhancement, stimulant properties and anxiety relief.


Kratom is safe when used properly. When kratom is taken by itself (without mixing it with other drugs), the greatest risk is falling asleep. 
Withdrawal has been compared to caffeine and is usually mild. Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.


One of the uses of kratom is as a treatment opiate addiction. 
Opiate addiction is a widespread problem. Not just for people who use opiate drugs illegally, but also for people who are prescribed opiate pain medications. 
Unfortunately, people who use opiate drugs daily often become addicted. Understandably, many people do not like being addicted to these drugs and are looking for ways to overcome their addiction. 
Many people report that kratom is effective for this purpose. In fact, Kratom has been used to successfully wean many addicts off their addiction. Once clean, most simply stop using kratom.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Please do not ban kratom. I agree with the Drug Policy Alliance on the following points:

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

     Daily in my work, I see the ravaging effects of alcohol, tobacco, and opioids on population health.  Never have I seen a problem due to kratom. documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
 kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v


There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
In light of the response from qualified and knowledgeable persons, perhaps it would be best to defer to congress. If this plant is really as dangerous as some @ the DEA would like us to believe, then surely they would have no trouble explaining that in a transparent legislative session. 

The intention of emergency scheduling is not to suddenly criminalize a plant thousands of years after people began using it. The purpose of emergency scheduling is to get drugs like bath salts off the streets, and they are completely synthetic. Come to think of it, the only reason people were buying bath salts is because they could not legally purchase or use their drugs of choice (likely MDMA, amphetamine, or cocaine) -- all of which are safer and better studied than their subsequent "bath salt" analogues.

The only thing scheduling kratom will accomplish is that these gas stations and smoke shops will begin selling new, unscheduled, completely synthetic, untested analogs of mitragynine. It will be a bath salt situation, but this time with ultra-potent mu-opioid agonists. It seems to me that people are currently filling a hole inside of them with sand. Why force them to switch to dynamite?

My honest advice to the DEA as a friend is to do yourself a favor and quit while you are ahead. The alternative, as with all prohibition efforts before, is the continued accumulation of blood on the hands of those responsible for these policies.

My name is Paul Kendrick, I am 20 years old, and I have been a part-time, feeder dispatch supervisor, for United Parcel Service.

I am fully against the proposal by the DEA to place Kratom on the list of Schedule I controlled substances. 

I have been a "Kratom" user for 2 years now. 

I began using Kratom in October, of 2014, after researching it and confirming that putting it in my body would NOT be of harm. I've never been a user of any recreational drugs, even to this day, as Kratom (Mitragyna Speciosa) is Not a drug. It is a pure, all natural, regulated dietary ingredient.

Kratom was a way for me to overcome a low point in my life. I didn't have a lot of motivation, and I felt like it was something that I could use to give me the edge that I needed to pull myself out of a depression and take charge in my own life. 

That's exactly what I did. 

I learned how to use it responsibly, before ever even consuming it. I have logged almost every time that I have taken any, and I always rotate strains, to prevent any probability of gaining a tolerance. I personally have absolutely no addiction to Kratom. I have proven this time and time again. Kratom IS NOT Addictive. 

There are almost No negative effects of kratom, unless you combine kratom with DRUGS, that are proven to be harmful, or use it irresponsibly. 

Contrary to misinformed, popular belief, Kratom isn't intended for the use to get "high;" Kratom is used to enhance and sharpen one's mind, as well as increase the user's productivity and mood in a very subtle way. 

I'm asking the DEA to not ban kratom Or Any of it's naturally occurring alkaloids, mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine. Doing this would be a horrible decision and would affect many citizens And war veterans (or others suffering with PTSD), who truly need it to live and get by, in a very negative way. 

Thank you for allowing us to publicly comment, and thank you, Congress, for helpings us to have this proposed ban of a very safe, natural, and life changing plant, delayed. 

Please completely withdraw this ban and restriction, especially as a Schedule I controlled substance, which it is Absolutely not. 

If age consent is a concern, then we understand restricting it from those, who are under the age of 18, likewise to tobacco; but kratom is harmless, in many forms aside from extract, and does not need to be placed under ultimate restriction and/or as a Schedule I controlled substance. 

Thank you for listening to the people.

Second attempt to submit due to my error, please accept. Comment on FR Doc #2016-24659. I am sixty-six years old and a retired teacher. At forty-six, I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia and prescribed Prozac, Hydrocodone, Xanax and Ambien.  My treatment plan progressed and Lyrica, Ultram, Tramadol, anti-inflammatories, steroids, hypnotherapy, massage, acupuncture, chiropractic treatment and laser therapy added and inter-changed. Through the years, my profile expanded and my life diminished by inclusion of degenerative arthritis, spinal stenosis, cancer, knee replacement, disc repair, laminectomy and carpal tunnel. Twenty years post diagnosis, I filed for early retirement.  Few knew my "secret" as disclosure was often received with misunderstanding and misadvice. I made my way, took my drugs, kept my secret and readied myself for the monster that reduced and erased my hope. I have served as a Girl Scout leader,  been nominated "Teacher of the Year", volunteered at the local zoo, worked with wildlife rescue, served as Elder in my church, directed Vacation Bible School, taught Sunday School, directed and written school musicals, volunteered with local theatre and committed myself to living with a condition that reduced me through chronic pain and fatigue. 

In 2014 I weaned myself from the opioids and pharmaceuticals; I decided to try the natural plant, Kratom, the flu-like malaise, pain and chronic fatigue were eased.  Why does the DEA and FDA advocate criminalization of a plant that is helping me? I am harming no one and living without the side effects of pharmaceuticals should be my choice. It is a gross disservice to thousands of responsible adults to dismiss our testimonials of recovery and pain reduction with Kratom.  President Obama has expressed his desire to win the war on drugs. Why was our presence ignored on Pennsylvania Avenue?  I feel victimized by the big business of pharmaceutical addiction. Allow me my choice to choose Kratom. The plant has not been responsible for a single death. Alcohol is legal and lethal as it destroys the American family.  Kratom is my best choice into the day which is a journey in determination. I am one voice among thousands advocating that Kratom need not be scheduled. 

We face daily obstacles which require presentation of the best we can give. It is my nature to do my best with my gifts. There will be a day when each of us must deal with acceptance of limited mobility, cognitive difficulties and life threatening challenges. I am standing at the threshold of my greatest challenge; a family member has been diagnosed with frontal lobe dementia. It is my nature to help navigate the heartbreak that my daughter experiences as caregiver and primary breadwinner for her young family. I might as well be dead if I am unable to help her emotionally and physically. The natural leaf Kratom has helped me and will support me in this unexpected and demanding role. Why place me in the position where I am unable to help my child? I know from supplementing with Kratom that I can be present for her. My diagnosis is not life threatening but it is life challenging. 

What can I do to gain understanding that my condition is helped with Kratom? You are invited to follow me throughout my days in order to ease your concerns about Kratom being addictive or a threat to society. This natural alternative to pharmaceuticals will support me and thousands who want nothing more than living productively with conditions characterized by pain and fatigue. How does the FDA reach the conclusion it is in my best interest to take from me and thousands that may help support mental, physical and emotional well being.  It is the nature of a healthy mind and spirit to choose a productive lifestyle. With my time on earth, I aspire to be my best self; not just for myself but the family and friends I cherish. I am Kratom.

Mary W Jones

documents.commentText:
I would like to make comments on your proposed measure to ban Kratom and tell you how it has helped my husband and I. Our lives would be quite different without it.

7 years ago I had to retire early and go on disability for migraines. I was 59 years old and am now 64. I had a very long and successful career as an art director for magazines. I have an MFA in Design and have won many design awards. I was also at the top of my career. I was diagnosed with daily migraine. The headaches were continuous and I was put on daily opiates for pain40 mugs daily and given Xanax for anxiety. We lived in Virginia at that time and have since moved to Houston, TX. While I gained a new team of great doctors for my condition in Houston, they wanted me off opiates (turns out the opiates were making the migraines worse) and Xanax. I was offered nothing but Aleve for pain.

In desperation I searched for some herb that would help with the constant pain and found Kratom. I can't express fully how it improved my life. I also suffer from depression and anxiety. Kratom helps all three problems. 

Kratom works well to ease the pain in my head. It is also a mood elevator and reduces anxiety. My husband has serious back problems. Serious enough that it requires him to to require daily medication and spinal shots. Even though he has opiates, he prefers to take Kratom as there are no side effects. He has told me he would not be able to continue working without it. (my husband is 63).

There is nothing in this herb that causes hallucinations or a "high" like opiates. There is no way to overdose on this herb. I have tried large doses and it does not seem to do anything more than what a regular dose does. It seems like your body absorbs only so much of what is the active ingredient.

I am stunned to hear people make remarks about this herb being dangerous. I don't think they are getting different Kratom than I am. It's just ground up leaves. Why are you listening to these hysterics who know nothing about this "drug". 

I don't want to believe this, but it makes the DEA sound like it is league with the pharma companies who want to synthesize the active ingredients and make it into pill form so they can sell it as a controlled drug. This thought sickens me. 

Please feel free to contact me if I can be of assistance in any way to stop this ridiculous and hurtful ban.

Jan Hilton
Houston, TX

documents.commentText: My name is James Barnes, and I recently changed jobs and I work at A ProLogistix Warehouse. I work 10 hour shifts, and I work 50 hours A week. I use organic Kratom from A reputable online vendor to keep me  focused when I work long hours. I have been diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, anxiety, and depression. Kratom helps me live A more functional and fulfilling life by helping me manage my attention deficit disorder,  anxiety, and depression. I have been prescribed drugs such as adderall and Ritalin for my attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, Xanax for my anxiety, and Prozac for my Depression. In my experience the drugs I have been prescribed have been much more dangerous with much higher addiction potential then Kratom. Adderall is A combination brand drug made from dextroamphetamine and amphetamine. It has A high addiction potential and can be lethal. Even if you don't take too much adderall and overdose it can be dangerous because of it's cardiac effects. Xanax is also very addictive and can kill you. Even if Xanax doesn't kill you it can still cause memory problems, drowsiness, coordination problems, dependency, and even addiction. I am currently off medication. I presently just use kratom, and I feel so much healthier. I've been around the block and I know what's dangerous and what isn't. Prescription amphetamines like adderall, and benzodiazepines like xanax are drugs with high addiction potential that can kill. Kratom is an organic herb that grows on A tree. Kratom has about the same addiction potential as coffee and you can't overdose on it. Kratom has been A miracle medicine for me. I'm A goal oriented person, and Kratom helps me stay motivated in my career. Kratom also helps me work out harder in the gym and recover faster from my workouts. Kratom helps me in my relationships with people by reducing my anxiety. Kratom helps me fall asleep faster, and sleep longer. I eat A clean diet, run marathons, and work overtime at my job. I can credit Kratom for helping me achieve many goals in my career and in the gym. In our American society where tobacco and alcohol are legal we shouldn't make Kratom illegal. My reasoning is that it is estimated that about 450000 to 500000 Americans die from tobacco related diseases such as lung cancer, esophageal cancer, bladder cancer, or heart disease every year. It is estimated that 75000 to 88000 deaths can be traced back to alcohol use. Alcoholic liver disease, fetal alcohol syndrome, alcohol poisoning, and drunk driving deaths can be 100% attributed to alcohol abuse, and liver cancer, hypertension, and stroke deaths can be partially linked to alcohol abuse. In our society tobacco is available in stores to anyone of age and is clearly poison. I would know I quit smoking A couple of years ago. Alcohol is also available in stores to anyone 21 years old and is toxic when misused. If our society accepts tobacco and alcohol it is my opinion that it is obvious that Kratom deserves to be respected as an herbal supplement and remain legal and available. Kratom is an herb not A drug, and it has low addiction potential. You also can't overdose on Kratom. That is something you can't say about the very popular drug caffeine. Kratom has been available in the United States for mere decades, but Kratom is an ancient herb that has been used for millennia. I encourage you to research the entire history of Kratom, not just the small window of it's use in America. Kratom is native to southeast Asia and is related to coffee. Kratom benefits me more then the harder prescription drugs I used to use with less side effects, addiction potential, and dangers. If Kratom wasn't available to me anymore it would become really challenging for me to manage my attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, anxiety, depression, and to keep working 50 hours A week. My work is demanding and I have to lift things that weigh over 80 pounds over and over for ten hours straight, and If I couldn't use Kratom my work would be A lot difficult for me. I would be negatively impacted if I no longer had access to the herb Kratom. I'm not A doctor and nothing in this comment should be perceived as medical claims. Kratom should stay legal and available because we are in the middle of an opiate epidemic in America and Kratom helps opiate addicts quit pain medication and heroin. It also helps people with real pain management issues, and people that work demanding hours at work like me. I really believe kratom saves lives and making it unavailable to the general public would have A negative impact on American society. Just look at States that have laws that prohibit Kratom use. They have higher opiate and opiate related deaths. I don't believe that making herbs in their natural form unavailable to the general public is the way that adults that work full time, pay their taxes and vote should be treated by their government. Thank you if you read this whole comment.

documents.commentText:
To Those Whom It May Concern:

While the need for regulation on the types of drugs that actually pose a public threat is true, there becomes a line that must be drawn for kratom. While a majority of the bad wrap that kratom receives is from being sold in Mylar plastic bags and jars at gas stations and head shops, a lot of good does come from this product. Yes it certainly should be taken off the shelves so people are not inclined to buy it in a common atmosphere to when you are buying soda and snacks or tobacco (head shop, gas station, smoke shops, etc) and it most definitly should be regulated at 18 years only online to buy.

But from everyone I know that uses kratom I would say 9 out of 10 individuals use it for a chronic illness that they can not get relief without a pharmaceutical painkiller which has undesired, deadly side effects like withdrawal and dependency. Very rarely do you come across someone that is able to "get high" or use it for recreational purposes. Sure, as with any LEGAL pharmeceutical, the initial doses might offer an effect that one might find euphoric or enjoyable, but as with any RX (prozac, citalopram, oxycodone, vicodin, trazodone) they do the same, and once it works into your system you no longer get it.

Kratom has a very low addiction potential, and the withdrawal from those of the heaviest users that choose to stop can only be described as A VERY SLIGHT form of withdrawal in regard to physical symptoms, compared to popular pharmaceutical withdrawals.

Do not ban kratom or you will be screwing up a lot of peoples lives, and not just a group of drug addicts that you seem to think encompasses the kratom user base.

CHEERS

documents.commentText:
Hello, 

I very strongly believe that Kratom should be kept legal. 

I am a veteran, a former US army officer and I have served a deployment in the middle east in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom.

I use Kratom to ameliorate the symptoms of Restless Leg Syndrome. Without it my quality of sleep is terrible - I get sick more often, I am achy and sore, groggy, etc. Until I discovered Kratom my sleep was so fitful that it was affecting my girlfriend's sleep as well. 

Kratom completely eliminates the symptoms with no side effects. I do not want to have to take expensive, powerful prescription medications with appalling side effects that don't really work, when a simple, natural plant fixes the issue completely. 

If Kratom is made illegal, I will stop using it. I'm not going to end up in jail. But what has been accomplished? Who has been helped?  I will go back to sleeping terribly, and it will affect my quality of life. 

Nobody who uses Kratom 'recreationally"  will keep using it. The only people who will keep using it if it is made illegal are the ones for whom it helps so much that they have to risk jail. People with chronic pain, or opiate addictions, and other serious disorders. 

Kratom is not dangerous, and It is impossible to overdose on Kratom. Any of the deaths that have been fraudulently and irresponsibly attributed to Kratom  (and there aren't even that many) are the result of other drugs that were consumed simultaneously. It is extremely limited in any kind of recreational use (coffee and red bull are much more of a noticeable stimulant). 

I have risked my life in service to this country, and in the quest to keep us free. Please don't reward that by hastily REMOVING my freedom to own a harmless natural plant that improves my quality of life.


KEEP KRATOM LEGAL!!

documents.commentText:
I am very concerned about the plan to potential schedule Kratom as a schedule 1 substance and I fully oppose it. 

My brother was addicted to heroin for years. He stole many of my favorite electronics when I was a child. My brother is a good person, opiates turned him into something else. He tried several times to get clean but it only ever lasted a few weeks. Eventually he used Kratom as an aid to help with withdrawal, and after two months of finally being heroin free, he was able to quite taking Kratom. He has lived clean ever since. I believe Kratom aided him in a journey that brought his life back. He had no withdrawals getting off Kratom as he did with other substances he would try to take to aid during former withdrawals.

I also begun taking Kratom at a time when I dropped out of school and lost motivation after being diagnosed with a rare neurological disorder that causes chronic depersonalization and derealization and horrible headaches. Kratom helped me gain back motivation. I also started exercising and eating better. I was able to quit taking clonazapam. The withdrawals were tough and long but I made it through with Kratom being one of the things that helped me. I went back to school and am currently still attending the University of Utah. I have maintained a 4.0 despite the brain fog from my disorder. I feel hope again for the future. I have stopped taking Kratom since the potential ban has been in place. I have reduced my Kratom usage from daily to weekly. I experienced nothing besides a runny nose with the reduction. It felt about equivalent to taking a break from coffee. I have had a harder time keeping up on my studies due to renewed headachs that Kratom was helping with.

I am also very concerned about the reasoning behind this ban. The number of calls to poison control being 660 over five years is not alarming to me. poison control centers received 6,843 reports of young children ingesting single-load laundry pods in just the first seven months of 2016. I'm sure you have already heard that the deaths linked to Kratom almost all involved other substances mixed with the Kratom making a direct cause of death being Kratom hard to conclude. I understand that The World Health Organization estimates that 4.6 million people die each year from causes directly attributable to air pollution. Opiods killed more than 28,000 people in 2014. I feel there are much bigger things to worry about and spend tax dollars on. Locking up people for Kratom, in my view, will not reduce as much harm as it will cause to people such as my brother and I. I would like to see the DEA focus more on reducing that very real Opiod death toll.  

It short, Kratom has helped both my brother and I in different ways and has brought no negative consequences with it. It feels very benign to both take and quit taking. It certainly does not feel intoxicating. I am strongly opposed to the ban on Kratom and hope you will find it in your heart to let people who are benefiting from Kratom remain doing so. 

Sincerely, 

Chase Stephens

documents.commentText:
I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEA's Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. This would put kratom, a plant helping millions of people suffering chronic and acute mental and physical conditions that is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem naturally, on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. It would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown kratom to be an effective painkiller that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose. 

I have been dealing with depression and anxiety for years now. Three years ago, things became a lot worse after I lost my grandmother. I had a lot of guilt inside me after she past. I would go days being in the worst mood for no particular reason. My anxiety would get so bad that I could not willingly be around anyone. I would not talk to any of my friends or family. I would avoid the people in my every day life day in and day out. I had no will to live. There are many personal issues that lead to this I believe, but I never addressed it. I always put it off to the side and convinced myself that I did not have problems going on in my head. It was no way to live. When you have anxiety and depression, your way of life seems unbearable. I began to abuse prescription pain killers to deal with my issues but after months and months of living through hell dealing with my new addiction. 

I began to do my own research on natural substances that will have the same medicinal properties. I even tried to speak to close family members or friends about how I was feeling and nothing worked. I learned that just letting things out and having therapy sessions did not fix anything. So I knew I had something more serious then I thought. 

I then came to Kratom and tried it for the first time and it was everything I needed. I now live happily every day. My days are not grueling and unbearable anymore. I am able to spend time with family and friends. Kratom has changed my life completely. I have more clean energy to my days. I have spent over 4 years dealing with my depression and anxiety. I now have a will to live every day to the fullest. Best of all, I am completely off prescription medications and have no need or urge to take any more. Kratom and it's many beneficial properties has gotten my life back together and prevented me from going down many wrong paths in life. I now have been using Kratom daily for 9 months and it has been one of the best years I have had in a very long time! 

Kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important medicinal uses and has changed my life. I fear this action will only lead to more tragic deaths of victims of the opiate epidemic, maybe even my own. I know that my own quality of life as a productive member of society will not be the same without Kratom.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
When I was in high school, my selfless, hard-working mother fell down the stairs, injuring her neck and back. Her condition deteriorated over the years, and she has been in relentless, chronic, excruciating pain for years. Can the government representatives who determine her future know what it's like to be in relentless, chronic, excruciating pain that no prescription painkiller can help for very long, that no surgery can heal completely or even help without incredible risk, including making it worse? The only thing that provides her relief is kratom. And kratom doesn't just help - it eliminates the pain! Kratom enables her to function - drive, work, attend her youngest daughter's chorus concerts, visit friends and actually enjoy their company instead of masking pain, take care of the vast array of family members she loves and who depend on her. When she first told me they were planning to take this away from her, I froze in horror at the thought of what this would do to her life. My mother has suffered so much throughout her life, but she had found this ONE way to effectively fight her pain and allow her to live. And it was going to be stolen from her, why? For what purpose?! Because some people insisted it was dangerous and that an overdose could kill you? Hmmm...

Water - safe in many quantities, even necessary, but too much of it, and you die (it's called drowning).
Tylenol - perfectly legal, useful substance sold over the counter with no restrictions, but too much of it? Not good.
Bleach - perfectly legal, useful product sold everywhere with no restrictions, but drink it, and you die.
Cigarettes - perfectly legal, popular product for everyone in the U.S. over 18 years of age with the potential to slowly kill you from various forms of cancer.
Alcohol - perfectly legal, popular product for everyone in the U.S. over 21 years of age with the potential to kill you and even cause you to harm others.
Sex - dangerous activity responsible for spreading horrible diseases to millions of people every year. There has been no proposal to restrict people's freedom to have anytime, anywhere, with whomever they want under any circumstances.

Kratom - an herb that for many people is the only thing standing between them and excruciating, constant, incurable, untreatable pain.

You ban one potentially dangerous substance or activity, if your motive is truly the safety of people, you have to ban ALL potentially dangerous substances and activities.

Citizens of the United States are not serfs or subjects of the government which has the right to control every single, solitary detail of their lives in exchange for taking care of all their needs. People who are citizens, not subjects, have a personal responsibility to take care of themselves and make their own decisions. People should have the right to weight the benefits of using kratom against the risks and decide for themselves if it's worth the risk; the government should not have the right to make this decision for them.

Especially important: there is no need for the government to protect people from any overwhelming danger from kratom! There has been no epidemic of people overdosing and dying from this herb. It does not make one high. It does not impair judgment. It does not affect one's mental state at all and has no debilitating physical side effects. It's a cost-free pain reliever. Potentially dangerous in too high quantities? See above list - the existence of a small risk of addiction or danger from too much is obviously not the standard used to ban a substance or activity. A bigger priority would be outlawing sex outside of approved, government-run institutions where applicants are screened for STDs and interviewed for competency prior to being permitted to do the deed. Think of the unfortunate consequences people would be relieved from under such measures! Why has no one proposed such a measure to protect people from bad decision-making?

The proposal to ban kratom came from people who don't use the herb, have no need to use the herb, and don't know anyone who use the herb. Anyone who supports such a bill should first spend significant time with chronic pain sufferers who rely on this herb's effects so they know what lives they'll be ruining. And for what gain? Banning kratom would gain nothing. It would cause no benefits to society at all because you're banning a substance that hasn't caused society to suffer! Chronic pain sufferers who found relief will be forced to lose that relief, and nobody will gain anything in return.

For the sake of my mother and all innocent, chronic pain sufferers in the United States, I strongly urge you to leave them free to find relief from kratom.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,
I am here to comment on the DEA's intent to make Kratom a Schedule I drug.  I am a 46 year old male, registered professional geologist, environmental department manager and safety director at an engineering firm, and husband and father.  I have dealt with chronic pain, depression and anxiety throughout my entire life.  I have been to many doctors and placed on many different pain meds, anti-inflammatories, anti-depressants and anti-anxiety medications over the years.  All of the medications I have been prescribed had side effects which left me either feeling sick, lethargic, spaced-out and/or addicted.  I was constantly searching for new medications that could adequately and safely take care of my issues and deliberately ignored natural remedies thinking they could never work better than a laboratory-made pharmaceutical.  However, earlier this year I reached my tipping point and after reading many testimonials from numerous people online, I decided to try Kratom.  After all, desperate times call for desperate measures.  I am so glad that I did.  Kratom has completely given me my life back! Who would ever have thought that one plant could relieve conditions that multiple pharmaceuticals collectively could not...and with no side effects!!!  The best part is that there is no "high" feeling and I feel "normal" again.  Please don't believe the negative hype that is perpetuated by people who know very little about the plant and likely have never tried it.  It would be a grave mistake for the DEA to make Kratom a Schedule I.  This plant must be studied so that its full potential can be realized.  Ultimately, why would you ban a plant that has shown the potential to treat a number of mental and physical illnesses naturally with little to no side effects?  You would be doing this country and the millions that suffer from chronic pain, depression and anxiety (to name a few) a great disservice by not studying the medicinal qualities of this wonderful plant.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am a employed, responsible, 47 year old man with chronic back and shoulder pain. I also suffer from GI issues and abdominal pain from multiple hernias and an inoperable hiatal hernia. And I have been taking the herbal supplement known as Kratom for over nine years to help me manage the pain, depression and anxiety that come from having to deal with these issues on a daily basis. 

To be clear, I have tried many doctors. I have undergone painful surgery, and have been prescribed powerful opiate pain killers like Vicodin, hydrocodone, and oxycodone to help me manage my pain. My medicine chest is overflowing with muscle relaxants, and prescription strength naproxyn, diclofenac and other NSAID pain killers. 

As you are most likely aware, all of these drugs come with an assortment of side effects that are well documented by the medical community. The byproduct of all these medications, make it difficult for me to be an effective provider for my family when I am taking them. The prescription strength nsaids have left me with GI issues that must be treated with PPI drugs like omeprazole (prilosec), and ranitidine on a daily basis. Furthermore, the omeprazole (prilosec) causes me to have chest pain and tachicardia as another side effect. And my cardiologist recommended this year that I discontinue usage of all PPIs in this class. 

This leaves me with very few viable options to treat my pain.  I can take the narcotics and suffer the slow, "muddy" thought processes, addiction, constipation, and difficulty breathing that they bring. Or I can take the nsaids and PPIs and suffer through the chest pain, tachycardia, ulcers, gastric reflux and irritation to my hiatal hernia.

OR, I can take an all natural, and SAFE herbal supplement like Kratom that comes with NONE of these symptoms. I can choose to take low doses of this herbal supplement that has been used to treat pain for thousands of years and that has been proven to be safe and effective by the community of people who have used it as part of their traditional medicine.

I have lived in NC all my working, adult life. And I have worked for the same company here in NC for over thirteen years. I am well respected by my customers, colleagues and my management in this company. And I have been responsibly using Kratom for almost nine of those years now - WITHOUT any of the complications or issues with addiction that have been reported in the news recently. Certainly nothing like the horror stories and narrative currently being pushed on the public by the DEA and FDA.

Kratom is a plant that comes from the same family as the coffee plant and is no more addictive than your morning cup of coffee. But the DEA and FDA almost decided, without any community discussion, to arbitrarily schedule this useful herbal supplement as a schedule I drug. Due to public backlash, the scheduling of this herb was delayed to allow for a period of public commentary. But if this ban is ratified on December 1st, kratom will be placed in the same class as HEROIN. At that point, the DEA and law enforcement agencies of the US will view me no differently then a Heroin-using street junky.

I have been legally taking this amazing herbal supplement for almost a decade, and I do not drink alcohol, or smoke, or use illegal drugs. I do not even like to take prescription painkillers. Every morning, I get up, pain or no pain, and I go to work to provide for my three little girls. Because that is what a good Father - NOT a Junky - does for his family. And now the US government is going to classify me in the same category as a Heroin addict? That is ludicrous!

What is needed at this time is an EXTENDED period of responsible discussion with the medical community to properly address the debatable claims of negative side effects and rumors of danger to the public. The medical and scientific community need to be given time (and the funding) to properly research this amazing herbal supplement. What we do NOT need is a knee-jerk reaction to ban this herb due to the few unsubstantiated claims of death and addiction that have been associated to it.

IF, it is determined that some form of regulation is required during this period of discussion and research, then let's please work together to find something less draconian then requiring a prescription or outright banning.  For example, we could simply restrict the sale of the herb to minors - much the same as we do for OTC medicines, tobacco and alcohol. 

Please keep the sale of this herbal supplement legal to adults and responsible individuals such as myself who depend on it for their daily activities.

Thank you for your time in this matter. It is a topic of great concern to me, and I look forward to hearing back from you!

documents.commentText:
Kratom is a vital botanical supplement that works wonders for arthritis and pain management, and is non-abusable because any overuse causes extremely nauseous reactions. This notice of intent to schedule the "drug" (which are actually just chemical constituents of nature's botanical, not some dangerous "drug") is entirely immature and unfounded. The fact that this alleged "ban" comes along at the same time that Big Pharma is patenting synthetic chemicals that resemble these active constituents, in order to treat pain and anxiety and depression just blatantly shows how the DEA is lobbying for Big Pharma's control over the Kratom industry.

As I'm sure you know by now, the Botanical Education Alliance and American Kratom Association are pulling for stricter indications and stronger focus on purity/safety. However, while this is nice and reassuring, people who take Kratom know what amount works for them, and the only ER visits have been from polydrug use, not "Kratom intoxication" - the latter would make one vomit the Kratom and render it rather useless, floating in the toilet. But it won't land you in the emergency room. There has been a humongous outpouring of caffeine related ER visits compared to anything regarding Kratom; not to mention, Kratom is no more habituating than coffee and shares it's extremely minor day-after tired feeling. This makes sense, and it tells us that, while Kratom is a member of the coffee family (fact check me), Kratom is probably safer than coffee. At least, if you're using substance-related ER visits as your measuring factor of harm.

The community behind this plant is not seeking recreation; they are trying to live functional lives in the face of pain, fighting through it in a docile manner (especially compared to these ridiculously, incomparably addictive opioids and opiates prescribed by Big Pharma.

Of Kratom is put on schedule I and people lose access to it, you will proceed to see the worst opioid epidemic this country has ever seen. I've already read plenty of stories of people turning back into the zombified versions of theirselves on western medicine pain management therapy, and it has already ruined enough lives to take things this far. Let Kratom be, and trust that the Botanical Education Alliance will protect the Kratom using community from any hazardous sources/vendors of the powdered herb.


By the way, there are bigger flies to kill. Ever heard of fentanyl analogues, or U-47700? They are readily available and pure on black markets. I don't want to see people turning to dangerous opioid drugs or things like "Lean/Sizzurp" in place of something that was previously helping facilitate existence, rather than letting it wear away in front of you. We're already in the middle of a heroin epidemic. It will increase so rapidly after the potential scheduling of Kratom that it will be like a zombie apocalypse.

Kratom is a WELLNESS SUPPLEMENT that attenuates opioid withdrawal (without carrying the dangerous constipatory or respiratory depression side effects), eases depression for people who have no luck with western medicine, and obliterates unfounded anxiety from anxiety disorders. It is non-addictive (at least not more than coffee; Google "Kratom and Forbes" for a well-written subjective account of a writer trying to convey how docile Kratom actually is and respectively how demonized it is by this country and the DEA in particular.

Save Kratom. Save the people.

documents.commentText:
My name is Tina Saylor and I am 58 yrs old. I was dx with Reflex sympathetic dystrophy in 1984 and was placed on a variety of medications, including up to 8 Vicodin a day. In June of 2000 I was also dx with Fibromyalgia. At that time the doctor's put me on oxycontine (120 Mg's a day) . I have been given fentanyl patches, morphine, methadone and oxycontine over the last 14 yrs and by accident I discovered alternative medicine. While in the hospital for a Fibromyalgia related issue the nurse suggested magnesium and potassium for my restless leg syndrome, it worked! I then started researching other natural vitamins and minerals that could help with my pain.in December of 2013 I began reading about Kratom and after much research began taking Kratom along with the other vitamins, minerals and natural supplements I'd discovered.. My last pain pill was taken on Jan 19th 2014. After 30 years I was totally opiate free! 
During the above mentioned time, I had not been able to work except here and there... Would end up having to quit because my employer would get tired of me missing time due to a "Fibro flare". I have been working full-time since Jan 2014 & have only missed a few days. Kratom does not completely take care of all my pain and suffering, but along with the other all-natural supplements that I take, I have my life back. I became, at the age of 56, a productive member of society!

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA;
RE: KRATOM
Thank you for allowing this public comment period.  As has become clear in recent weeks, there exists among the general public and within the scientific research community a keen interest in kratom and its active ingredients.  Also clear is that your original proclamation of an imminent hazard to public health was premature.  You did the right thing by withdrawing that original notice of intent.

Presently, then, the proper course of action involves two steps.  First is for DEA to take no action with regard to scheduling kratom.  Second, your agency should advise FDA that its review of the extant scientific research is no longer directly tied to any pending action by DEA.

By withdrawing the involvement of your agency in this matter, you will have avoided doing actual harm to both the public and the scientific community.  You will also have avoided the appearance of specific impropriety; namely, that DEA was controlling who in the scientific community would be permitted to conduct research.

documents.commentText:
My name is John.  I am 34 and work as a handyman, mechanic, and farm hand. I oppose the DEA putting kratom on the list of Schedule I controlled substances.  I feel the ban is unwarranted because Schedule I drugs like heroin, and cocaine are narcotics with serious side effects while kratom has a very mild effect and no negative effects that I have found in three years of taking it.

My experience pre-kratom: 

I suffered severe chronic pain due to muscle injuries that wouldn't heal, as well as back and head injuries due to a couple of serious vehicle accidents.  My doctor said I also had advanced arthritis and that my joints looked like those of a 70-year-old man.  I had been dealing with these problems since I was 18.  I went to many doctors and spent tens of thousands of dollars but they could not figure out what was wrong.  I was recently diagnosed with Hashimoto's, an autoimmune disorder, as the cause of the healing problems.  But now these problems are so bad they cannot be fixed.

Over this thirteen year period, doctors prescribed these drugs for me:

For pain: Opiates (Oxycodone, Methadone, Morphine).  These drugs took away my energy and made me sleepy, worthless, and lethargic.  I was too impaired to drive or work. I had to keep increasing the dose to get relief from the pain.  They were extremely addictive.  Detoxing off them was horrible.

For depression: I tried three or four common anti-depressants.  I felt like I had no emotions.  I was numb, had no energy, and felt dead inside.

For anxiety: (Diazepam and others).  They worked, but I always had an impaired feeling.  I couldn't function.

For insomnia: (Trazedone, Seraquil, Ambien). I woke up feeling horrible, angry, tense, worked up.

For side effects: I took a variety of medications to combat the side effects of the other drugs I was taking.

Transitioning from medications to kratom: 

Three years ago I detoxed off oxycodone. It took two weeks of heavy-duty detoxing.  I had to get off all pain meds to decrease my tolerance for opiates so that kratom would work.  Please note that kratom is not an opiate but it affects the same opiod receptors in the brain that they do.  Coffee and chocolate also affect these receptors and obviously are not opiates.

The kratom I take: 

I take straight kratom - the pure, dried, powdered leaf of the kratom tree, not mixed with any other substance, always the same type of leaf and always from a reputable supplier.  I take the minimum I need to based on the amount of pain I have that day. 

My experience with kratom and that of relatives and friends:

I do not experience euphoria or any negative side effects.  Kratom does not take away the pain completely, but enough that I can function.  It also provides relief from anxiety, depression, low energy, and insomnia.  Mentally it changes me back to a pre-illness state.  I no longer need to take any prescription medications.

Each individual may have a different experience - especially depending on what type of leaf they consume.  Some people say it doesn't do anything.

The following list of kratom's effects is from DEA's "Drugs of Abuse" (page 84).

I have not experienced these symptoms:
Itching, constipation, increased urination, anorexia.

I have not experienced these symptoms or heard of anyone else experiencing them:
Psychotic symptoms, including hallucinations, delusion, and confusion.

I have not experienced these symptoms, but I might if the kratom was too potent or I took too much:
Nausea and sweating.

I have experienced the opposite of these symptoms:
Loss of appetite.  Weight loss.  Insomnia. 

I have experienced these symptoms or a variation of them:
Dry mouth - Yes.
Improved physical energy - Yes, definitely.
Stimulant effects and increased alertness - Improves my mood rather than being a stimulant.
Increased talkativeness - Maybe a little, due to better mood.
Sedative effects - It is calming and reduces anxiety.
Psychological addiction - No worse than coffee.

In conclusion, kratom gave me my life back after eight years of taking prescription pain killers.  I had lost everything - my family, my house, and all my possessions.  My cousin suggested getting off prescription medications and trying kratom.  Three years later I am a new father who is able to help support his family.  I am in the process of rebuilding my life.  I do not want to go back to my old life.  That is what will happen if this ban goes into effect.

For more information please refer to the American Kratom Association website which contains links to the latest scientific studies on kratom - www.AmericanKratom.org/science.

documents.commentText:
Dear government officials.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs

The public overwhelmingly supports ending it. 

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

 
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

 
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. 
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. 

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose. 

THE WAR ON DRUGS MUST END.  MEDICAL COMPASSION MUST BEGIN.

documents.commentText:
Hello I am in my 30's and a father of two. I work in sales and am great at what I do and am very much a family man.

7.5 yrs ago I cleaned up from a devastating oxy contin addiction, I couldn't hold a job nor could I be available or present with my family. I came very close to overdose a few times and hit rock bottom. I entered into my 3rd treatment facility and actually worked a program of recovery that time around which allowed me to achieve true and lasting sobriety. Fast forward 4 years and I was diagnosed with a chronic condition that would've required me to go back to prescription pain killers. I told the doc no way I'm going back, I am terrified of the effect the prescription pain killers would have on my life now. I did a great deal of research and found kratom. I believe Kratom quite literally saved my life because I know going back to the prescription pain pills is a death sentence. I have been taking kratom for 3.5 years and the effects are a mild mood lift a little less than a 5 hour energy and it has some pain killing aspects. Kratom replaced my morning star bucks. I don't believe kratom is even close to schedule 1 worthy because in my experience there have been no side effects and it has helped me not hurt me. Schedule 1 would also stop or make any future research very difficult. I believe it should be regulated like any other herbal supplement or food item (like chamomile, lavender, Kava, green tea ect) to make sure it is not adulterated however in 3 and 1/2 years I've never come across anything but fresh natural crushed leaf kratom from dozens of suppliers, which just goes to show the free market and internet reviews at work. 

When I was using prescription pain killers I used to fall into a deep sleep everywhere and I was always worried about not waking up. I used to steal and do things I'm ashamed of to get my oxy but I've never even thought about that with kratom nor had any side effects like that from kratom. Kratom is not any more addictive than caffeine in my experience. 

To compare kratom with heroin is like comparing green tea to crack cocaine. I realize for the USA this is a brand new herb and government entities don't know much about it but in other countries in the world they have used kratom for hundreds of years with no serious side effects. That can't be ignored. Please do thorough research. I'm a little concerned the FDA is going to slap research together real quick due to the short time frame they have and it won't be as good as thorough un-biased research.

Please don't ban kratom, it has given me my life back from a condition that would've ruined my life. I'm able to do things and live my life to it's fullest by being a present dad, go mountain biking, hiking, make a very good living and participate in charity work.

I am a 54 year old Female that has been diagnosed with Fibromyalgia, bulging disks in my lower back and neck.  I have a knee replacement in my left knee and arthritis in my right and my hips.  I have also been diagnosed with nerve damage in my legs. I am also the mother of a 14 year old Son that is deaf, Autistic, and Epileptic due to him contracting Bacterial Spinal Meningitis at 7 months old.  He also has an aggression problem, they believe it was brought on by puberty.
 I have been the route of pain clinics with Opiates, and Morphine for over 2 years.  I found myself addicted to them and not functioning on a normal level.  I stopped that treatment so I could have a clear head and take care of my son.
I chose to find Holistic and Supplemental treatments that would address my pain levels so I could control my Son and make a living.
In my investigation for alternatives I came across the ancient treatment of Kratom.  I tried it, and it worked.  My mind was clear, and the it took the edge of my pain when it was bad.
Please do not make this a class 1.  We have to have some alternative to pain that is safe.  Kratom has been used for over 2,000 years.  There is not a documented death due to taking just Kratom.  All other deaths involved other drugs mixed in.  There are people that need Kratom as a mode of relieving pain without being hooked on Opiates.  You have to leave some avenue for us.

documents.commentText:
My name is Jeremy Haley and I am the owner/operator of Rocky Mountain Kratom based out of Denver,  Colorado.  We were featured in the LA Times, NPR, and the front cover photo of USA Today and a number of publications after the Denver Environmental Health Division had closed down our shop strictly because of the DEA announcement a week prior that the DEA had announced kratom as an imminent threat to public health with no more information provided.  We were still shut down with no valid explanation given other than that and it was on 9/6 when the original proposed DEA ban was slated for 9/30.  

Afterwards, I received so many heartbreaking e-mails from people whom were suffering immensely as they had been using kratom as a mild coffee like substitute to keep them from doing more harmful drugs such as heroin, oxycontin, xanax, cocaine and alcohol (although we followed all of the the FDA and regulatory guidelines that were required of us and never promoted it for such use).  

These people had lost the desire to use those other substances until kratom was taken away from them when kratom hasn't been found to have officially caused any severe health crisis that has been specified, has any substantial statistics comparable to the dangers presented by even some of the most benign seeming household foods and products and kratom has been used for thousands of years without a history of health concerns being reported as opposed to the positive information that was volunteered to us despite our FDA required "Not for Human Consumption" policy.  

We even had customers messaging us whom had just discovered kratom after attempting to kick opiate drugs and alleviate withdrawal and had their supply cut off halfway through the withdrawal process.  A couple had messaged us with thoughts of suicide after discovering the relief kratom has been reported to provide as an opioid withdrawal suppressor (once again we never promoted any of this as it had not been FDA approved or evaluated) only to run out and be faced with a week or 2 of hell trying to function in their lives while enduring the living hell that is opiate withdrawal without a buffer to make it tolerable.

We still avoid making any medical claims as a result of respecting the rules imposed by the FDA, DEA and US customs about making any claims that had not been approved by the FDA but ended up getting the DEH ruling overturned.  I've just seen kratom lead to so many drastic positive changes in others and myself with very little downside that is no worse than coffee which is unregulated.

I personally am in favor of kratom regulation and support a set of standards that kratom vendors (including us should adopt) such as the ones we have already put into place such as using a cGMP rated manufacturing facility with FDA grade storage containers and adopting the lab testing and making the results available public for each batch in our shop and new website to come.  

As for my own experience, I have given up alcohol almost completely with the occasional beer at dinner maybe once every 3 months if that.  It has properties as a dietary ingredient that could provide relief to so many people whom are suffering horribly or slaves to pharmaceuticals as they reach the point after taking these dangerous legal drugs with way higher reported death totals that aren't even in the ballpark of the legal FDA approved alternatives even with a couple of 0's added in at the end.  Point being, kratom has changed my life, got me clean from all other substances that are considered drugs (including alcohol outside of that rare single drink).  

I just don't understand what imminent danger that kratom poses that would call for an emergency ban and why it has been impossible to get a decent and sensible answer from any government agency as to why kratom is being singled out like this based seemingly on irresponsible reporting from local news agencies whom have referred to kratom as an "opioid" and "designer drug" when neither description could be further from the truth along with the tone of each of the news agencies (cbs for example) whom have seemingly made up their mind.

I was following the test trials by the Florida Law enforcement division whom were studying kratom earlier this year in order to discover proof that would allow the lawmakers to ban it statewide but the results ended up refuting the very claims that the kratom opposition in Florida had made against the botanical and had hoped to find in these studies only to be humbled by science and quickly have that story kept low key and swept under the rug.  Then as research comes out showing favorable reports that refute the reported dangers behind the botanical it is then a few months later attempted to be made Schedule I along with heroin and therefore halting the ability to do future research on the botanical.  Sounds sketch to me but what do I know after having been unjustifiably judged by the FDA, banks, cc agencies and landlords.

documents.commentText:
Sir

Kratom now offers the potential of helping people that suffer from chronic pain using a natural produce that will not only help deal people with their pain but also lessen their dependence on perscription opioids.  All the millions of people that have documented chronic pain deserve all the relief they can get, especially if they are having trouble dealing with opioids like Norco.

The effectiveness of Kratom deserves to be explored carefully BEFORE the DEA makes its use illegal.

While the DEA may want to limit kratom's recreational use, they should not prevent its use by those that are living with documented chronic pain every day of their lives!  It is not right for the DEA to turn a blind eye to all those millions of people that suffer chronic pain, especially before any research has been done by independent researchers that are not connected to Big Pharma. That want to limit any competition to their own medications.

Also some additional info from the web:

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

The side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose problems.

The War on Drugs has had a catastrophic impact on the trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. We need to restore that trust, and allowing for research and regulation of drugs like kratom will be a significant step.

documents.commentText:
My name is Jason Brown, I am a professional photographer and laborer, and I have been an advocate and user of Kratom for roughly 10 years. I first came across Kratom speaking with a friend who suffers from chronic pain and has adverse effects to prescribed medication. Having suffered myself from chronic back problems (spending years getting treatment through a chiropractor), he told me how he took a trip to Indonesia and found Kratom, and how it helped in a way that nothing previously had. Upon my first encounter with this wonderful and safe plant, my life changed dramatically. 

I had spent a number of years coping with some person problems--some related to work, some not--by drinking alcohol. I drank regularly, probably 5 or 6 times a week for about 5 straight years, and it was profoundly affecting my daily life at home and at work. I felt my life was spiraling out of control, but didn't know how to quit. I felt trapped, alone, and powerless to stop. That it, until I discovered this leafy plant that had been safely in use for thousands of years. It was a miracle. It does no impare my function and allows me to thrive as a person!

Quite simply: Kratom changed and ultimately, I believe, save my livelihood and possibly my life. It turned things around for me in a way I can't fully express. I don't know what I will do without it. the burden of this precarious situation is already too much to bare. For this reason, and for the many hundreds of thousands of Kratom users, it must remain legal--especially during our dangerous opiate crises. 

Here are some helpful resources on the science of Kratom. 

www.americankratom.org/science

I get really sick and tired of these public outcries over something people just don't understand; and when that happens the government jumps on the bandwagon and throws down their wrath to get it abolished!  Kratom is a plant!  Just like marijuana, it is something that is naturally grown on our planet and has amazing medical uses.  The fact that these are being made illegal is beyond ludicrous; they are plants!

I was diagnosed with some minor depression and anxiety problems in the past and was prescribed something similar to Zoloft.  Being on Zoloft was absolutely horrible!  It made you feel uneasy and sick.  You could say it almost made you feel "zombie-like".  That is when I found out about Kratom from online stories about it and video testimonials.  The community behind it was very descriptive of its effects and dosage.  The common misconception with it too is that it is addictive...that is not the case!  Whoever says this is clearly abusing it and doesn't understand it's usage.  With anything in life, it takes moderation to fully accept something.  When it comes to Kratom, that is no different!  Any of these stories that are being garnished by the media about people overdosing on Kratom getting hurt in some way by Kratom, are honestly being over dramatized! If anything, these people were most likely abusing it or they were on other medication when it occurred.  Not once have I EVER experienced these type of occurrences when taking Kratom!

With me, Kratom is not a daily activity.  In fact, Kratom can become highly tolerant if taken too often, which I believe is it's only downside, but also it's upside.  I find taking Kratom best when I get any sort of fits of anxiety, especially when it comes to social anxiety of some kind.  A relatively small dose of Kratom can give you that uplifting experience you wouldn't get from other anti-depressants that are cooked up in a lab.  This makes it great to always have on hand, because banning it would only make up for more problems from the public.  In my personal experience, the only problem I've EVER had with Kratom is possibly an upset stomach and this was only because I was a beginner and trying to figure out my proper dosage.  Like I said, everything must be taken responsibly and in moderation!

documents.commentText:
Although the DEA claims there have been numerous deaths associated with kratom, it does not cite any deaths where kratom was the only factor. The agency cites 14 deaths reported in the scientific literature, plus 16 others that have been confirmed by autopsy/medical examiner reports, meaning that mitragynine and/or 7-hydroxymitragynine were identified in biological samples. It is not safe to assume, as the DEA does, that every person who ever died after consuming kratom died because he consumed kratom. But even if you overlook that logical fallacy, a grand total of 30 deaths associated with kratom in the whole world over the course of centuries is hardly numerous, and it pales beside the number of deaths associated with myriad legal drugs. Alcohol, for instance, is implicated in about 88,000 deaths a year in the U.S. alone, while 28,000 deaths were attributed to heroin and opioid painkillers in 2014.

Mitragynine and its constituent compounds pose no threat in comparison to many over-the-counter medications - let alone warrant a schedule 1 classification. The herb and its compounds have been implicated in stopping withdrawal symptoms in various classes of depressants allowing the user to wean off safely.[1] Kratom is a safe alternative for pain, and even in a recreational setting, given the much lower potential for abuse and devastating addiction. With only a few hundred incidents of medical attention in all 50 states in 5 years (most benign and non-life threatening, and one single death in combination with other drugs)[2], the bias towards this plant or its being touted as "deadly" is increasingly more clear.

[1] https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3670991/   
[2] www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6529a4.htm

documents.commentText:
Kratom

I am not a user of Kratom, and honestly had never even heard for the supplement prior to the knowledge that the DEA was going to designate it a schedule-1 substance. After reading some journal articles about the supplement and its pharmacologic effects, I believe it would be a mistake to make Kratom a schedule-1 substance for the following reasons.

1. According the article entitled "Pharmacology of Kratom: An Emerging Botanical Agent With Stimulant, Analgesic and Opioid-Like Effects", in The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association, December 2012, Vol. 112, 792-799, Kratom stimulates both mu and delta opioid receptors (a mechanism similar to our narcotic pain medicines like Oxycodone), exhibits an anti-inflammatory effect similar to NSAIDS like Celebrex, and also stimulates alpha-2 receptors (Clonidine and Precedex are medications with this mechanism of action used for pain management). Another, source suggested that it may be an NMDA antagonist as well, which would be useful in pain management, and may explain is stimulant effects.

2. The people I have spoken to that utilize this substance are not people who abuse it for recreational use. These are people who have chronic pain issues, and are taking the substance to improve their quality of life. They lead fully functional daily lives, and to my knowledge, pose no threat to society due to the utilization of this supplement. 

3. My area of expertise is anesthesia. Some pharmacological agents have what is called a synergistic effect, meaning that the utilization of drugs that hit different receptors has a higher efficacy than just taking a higher dose of one single substance. NSAIDS (Cox 1&2 inhibitors), alpha-2 agonists, NMDA receptor antagonists, and opioid-receptor agonists are all utilized for pain management. The combination of these effects, and the resultant synergism may explain why people can take just a small dose of this supplement and receive the pain relief that they could not formerly achieve when taking one or two of the medications in these drug classes, while experiencing minimal side effects. Removing the option to take Kratom from these people will unnecessarily impact their quality of life, and possibly their ability to provide for their families. 

4. From what I know, this country is currently experiencing an epidemic in opioid addiction due to the over-prescription of Oxycodone and other opiates for pain management, which leads to dependence. I have read many news stories in the past couple years about people overdosing on fentanyl-laced heroin. So many stories in fact, that Narcan pens have recently become more available to the general public and first responders (unlike the Epi pen, which is a travesty in its own right). These heroin addicts are often born from opioid addicts that formerly obtained opiate pain medications for legitimate medical issues from legitimate medical sources. Removing Kratom as a safer, more effective option for pain management could possibly turn some of these functioning, productive members of society back to opioids for their pain control needs, adding to the rampant opioid epidemic that is already plaguing the country. 

I contend that removing Kratom without just cause would infringe on the civil liberties of many Americans by severely impacting quality of life, and possibly exacerbate the opioid epidemic. If the DEA has adequate investigative research that proves Kratom is wreaking havoc on our society in a manner that outweighs the benefits, I would be glad to receive that information and take it into consideration. Considering that Kratom is not a widely known substance, public education could go a long way in reducing some of the negative outcomes that occur from abuse of the drug. However, in light of all the aforementioned points, I recommend that the move to designate Kratom as a schedule-1 substance be halted, or at least postponed until adequate data exists, proving that this supplement is a detriment to our society deserving of such a designation.
