documents.commentText:
Hello.

I am writing to you regarding the potential ban on kratom.  I want to tell you about my experience with this herb.  Kratom has been an invaluable tool on my journey of recovery from opiate addiction.  All of my previous attempts to quit opiates (as well as Suboxone) had failed because I wasn't able to make it through the extreme withdrawal and the anxiety was overbearing.  That's when I found kratom.  When I quit taking the opiates, kratom alleviated many of the withdrawal symptoms, while not altering my state of mind.  This allowed me to set up a plan for my recovery and put that plan into action.  I was able to stop taking the kratom not long after.  Thanks to kratom, a great support system, and becoming involved in recovery programs, I can be a contributing member of society.  Kratom is not a cure-all for addiction, but it allowed me to get my life in order and focus on my recovery.  I don't believe I would have been able to make it to this point without the help of kratom.  I now use kratom occasionally (along with counseling) to combat my anxiety.  I don't want to use benzodiazepines for my anxiety, due to their long list of potential side effects and potential for dependence.

Not only has kratom greatly improved my quality of life, I know many others who have benefited from kratom as well.  I have witnessed firsthand how much it helps those battling depression, addiction, anxiety, chronic pain, and other ailments.  Banning kratom will have a negative impact on our lives.  My heart breaks thinking of the impact this ban would have. 

I would also like to add that any deaths where the individual had kratom in their system, the person also had dangerous substances in their system (such as Heroin). There have been no reported deaths that can be directly linked to kratom.  This is huge, when you look at the number of deaths caused from legal substances such as alcohol or cigarettes.  Kratom is natural and originates from the same family of plants as coffee.  

I ask that you please consider the repercussions this ban would have.  I predict that we will see an increase in drug addiction and drug overdoses if kratom is banned.  I know how devastating and hopeless life can seem for those battling depression, addiction, and chronic pain.  Kratom gives these individuals hope. Taking away hope is a very dangerous thing. 

Thank you for taking the time to read and consider my message.  It is greatly appreciated. 

Sincerely, 

Kelsey

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
I'm writing to express my deep, impassioned disapproval of the plan to turn kratom into a schedule I substance, thereby criminalizing its use and making it unavailable to the thousands who rely upon it daily for chronic pain management. This is a dangerous abuse of power--for a multitude of reasons--and should be terminated immediately.

The assertions that this thousands of years old natural plant remedy is an "imminent public safety hazard" that has "no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse" are erroneous on every level. First of all, there is absolutely no scientific evidence to suggest that kratom--which has been used medicinally all over the world for generations-- is dangerous. The DEA has cited reports of 15 total deaths linked to--though not necessarily attributable to--kratom in the last two years (2014-2016)-- and in all of those cases, there were other drugs and/or alcohol involved (all of which routinely cause thousands of deaths annually, and are far more likely to have been the cause of death). Fifteen deaths in two years is an astonishingly small number, considering the number of deaths from opiate drugs was over 47,000 in 2014 alone, according to the American Society of Addiction Medicine, and has been steadily increasing every single year. Thus, kratom can't reasonably be classified as a public safety hazard. Secondly, the assertion that it has no medical use is just as foolish, given that thousands in the U.S. alone have either ended their addictions to narcotics and alcohol or safely and effectively treated their chronic pain--often when narcotics failed them, caused an adverse reaction, or were not made available. Finally, the assertion that kratom has a high potential for abuse has been proven both scientifically and anecdotally inaccurate, and is far safer than the addictive prescription drugs prescribed to people every day for pain, substance abuse, and the multitude of other conditions that kratom helps to treat (not to mention its safety record when compared to the obvious dangers of the millions of illegal drugs in use for pain or addiction). Please see this research in the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (just one example of the multitude of research that proves kratom's safety, efficacy, and lack of addictive potential in the brain's reward centers): pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jmedchem.6b00748?source=cen

For those in chronic pain or battling addiction, kratom provides safe, effective, and affordable relief, and has been used safely around the world for thousands of years. For purposes of clarification and perspective, I'd like to share with you that I am a 35 year old Harvard graduate with a successful career and family life, and no history of substance abuse or criminal activity. However, I nearly lost everything after a devastating illness that left me with chronic, severe pain, and on over ten medications-- all of which came with their own dangers and side effects, and weren't terribly effective to begin with. It wasn't until I discovered kratom (approximately two years ago through friends also suffering from chronic pain) that I was able to start enjoying a reasonably good quality of life again, safely, and without dangerous side effects of medications. As a result of using kratom, I have been able to get off of all but two of my medications naturally, have been able to resume a normal social life, become productive again, and have even become healthy enough to have another child, which was previously considered impossible and dangerous because of my condition (my second son was born safely and perfectly five weeks ago). Kratom quite literally saved me--and as a result, my family-- and the idea that our government would criminalize my right--and our collective right as a free people--to a decent quality of life is unthinkable and unforgivable. If kratom becomes a Schedule I substance, my use of kratom as an herbal supplement will have the same legal and criminal consequences as if I was using heroin or cocaine! By supporting this ban, you condemn the millions who use kratom to safely ease their suffering to, at minimum, a life of unnecessary pain and suffering, and at worst, that painful life spent behind bars. 

At the very least, kratom should be fully and properly researched before ANY decision about its standing is made. Ultimately, if the government wants to regulate it reasonably (for example, limiting its purchase/use to those over 18 years of age, or setting minimum standards of quality and purity), fine; I don't believe any reasonable person would have a problem with that. But please, don't force millions of good, law-abiding citizens back into chronic pain and/or medication and drug dependency under the guise of public service. 

Thank you for you time and consideration. 

With appreciation for all you do,
Brianna Ladapo

documents.commentText: I am diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia; schizoid, depressive and narcissistic personality disorder and I can tell you that Kratom helped me through all this in a way that the meds could not. I only used de-stemmed leaves as a tea twice a day but I had to give it up because I could not afford it on my monthly disability. This plant is one of the best things I've run into, it helped me not just with depression but also anxiety, as well as my harsh insomnia, which are two of my biggest problems.At this point I can only go to sleep when I want using three different pharmaceuticals. I have no problem with a ban on the extracts as they are often hard to gauge, I've overdosed on extract but all that happened was that I basically sat in a chair, puked a few times, and I didn't want to talk to anyone as though I was in a trance. Nothing at all like the deadly effects of opioids. The natural leaf I would take everyday and probably throw out most of my pharmaceuticals in the process. I stay on pharms because my insurance pays for them, I simply cannot pay $200 a month out of pocket when my disability only gives me $500. You guys need to understand that big pharma is not interested in our best interests, while a plant that helps more is demonized. If I have one dream it's that the DEA or the Gov in general takes no interests in simple plants that can help people in need. All my votes will be for candidates that are not interested in prohibition. The original drug they had me on, Abilify, made me gain 50 pounds in less than 5 months, rendered me totally emotionally numb and unable to be creative. Creativity is the most important thing to me as I went to school just to learn how to write creative fiction better. I do not experience the weight gain and loss of creativity when I use herbal alternatives. I am begging you, stop this nonsensical approach to things. I do think you have a bias, that you are often unscientific or willfully discourage scientific research into naturally occurring compounds that can be of immense benefit without turning the Pharma industry a profit. How long I live most likely depends on your decision to either back away from these natural plants or to arbitrarily consider all of us criminals. I am not afraid to die if I am forced to live in a society that gives no fucks about how natural substances can help me, yet insists on prescribing me artificial chemicals that are guaranteed to shorten my lifespan and make what life I have completely unproductive. I hope someone who actually cares reads this. There must be a shift in policy, for I am hardly the only one who feels this way about the situation. Thank you for reading and for your time, may I and others like me have our voices be heard. End the nonsense. You will have far more respect from society at large if you just back off, as telling a sick person that something that makes them better also makes them a criminal. This is psychopathy. These herbs are not for everyone, nor should you assume that they are, but for some they are not just life-saving but quality-of-life saving. Do I want to live as an angry depressed lunatic, or do I want to live as someone who can actually function at least to a limited degree. Lives are at stake. Please take my statement seriously.

documents.commentText:
Regarding Docket No.  DEA-442W

Kratom has been a godsend for me and people close to me. Two people I know used it to kick a multi year opiate addiction, by using it as a supplement to relieve withdrawal symptoms. They are now functioning members of society with jobs. Another person close to me used it as a caffeine substitute and relieve pain from a knee injury instead of relying on dangerous pain medications. 

Personally, I have used kratom to relieve symptoms for some of my ailments. It has helped my insomnia and I'm able to rest and be more productive at work. It helps alleviate what would otherwise be crippling anxiety to a point where I can use techniques like PMR to relax myself. 
My only complaint is that the effects are pretty mild. But the overall changes are significant enough to have a positive impact on my life. 

As a citizen of this country, and a student of science; I urge you to not schedule this plant. It has done nothing but improve and save lives. The two former opiate addicts fear a fatal relapse if restrictions on access occur, as they use kratom to stave off cravings. 

Kratom has been used for centuries and has been sold as a supplement in the United States before 1996. I believe we should research this plant as much as possible and thus we should retain it's ease of access as it stands.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA, as a concerned citizen, I do not sponsor the proposed ban on Kratom, or listing it as a Schedule 1 drug. Here is why: 
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: I am writing on behalf of my beloved daughter-in-law, who, after many years of using conventional therapies and prescribed drugs to treat her anxiety, depression, and medically diagnosed PTSD, carefully researched and began to use Kratom to alleviate her symptoms. She uses a powder that she mixes into a yogurt smoothie. Admittedly, I have no personal experience with the plant, but, at her urging, I have read a wide source of documents and articles to educate myself. I am aware of the benefits of Kratom for persons who suffer from PTSD, including scores of veterans, and its potential for helping opioid addicts, avoid the deadly consequences of their addictions and recover. If the DEA proceeds with putting Kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances, without allowing for much-needed research into its benefits (and risks), it may have tragic consequences for people, such as my daughter-in-law, whose quality of life I have watched dramatically improve since she began using the supplement. I would like to add my voice to the many who wish to see much more consideration of the potential healing properties of this natural plant that has been in use throughout the world for thousands of years, before summarily making it illegal without allowing for much-needed research and investigation. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524

Keywords: DEA, kratom, opioid, pain management, withdrawal

In December 2012, I was the lead author of a review published in The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association that focused on an emerging botanical agent called kratom.1 The species, Mitragyna speciosa, is a tree indigenous to Thailand and other areas of Southeast Asia.2 When ingested or consumed in the form of teas, kratom leaves produce complex dose-dependent stimulant and analgesic effects.1 In Southeast Asia, kratom has been used to stave off fatigue and to manage pain, diarrhea, cough, and opioid withdrawal.2-6 Our analyses of the medical literature and websites in 2012 revealed that kratom had been increasingly used for the self-management of opioid withdrawal and pain in the United States. We also reported on the pharmacologically active constituents of kratom, most notably mitragynine, 7-hydroxymitragynine, paynantheine, and speciogynine, along with more than 20 other substances.1,3 These compounds have complex and potentially useful pharmacologic activities. In addition, we found many anecdotal reports and testimonials posted online suggesting that kratom may have beneficial effects, particularly in the management of both opioid withdrawal and pain.1 
At the time our review was published, kratom was not banned by the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), although it was on their Drugs and Chemicals of Concern watch list.1,7 We summarized the potential therapeutic benefits of kratom, but we also emphasized that no well-controlled scientific studies on the safety and efficacy of kratom had been published.1 We noted an increase in the number of reported adverse effects attributed to kratom and highlighted the lack of regulation and quality-control measures in the production and sale of kratom products. Our conclusions from these analyses were that even though kratom or its active constituents could have potential for development as therapeutic agents, it would not be appropriate for physicians to recommend kratom for their patients. 
In the 4 years since the review1 was published, several major developments have been made regarding the pharmacology and legal status of kratom.8 Given the widespread use of kratom and the extensive media attention it is receiving,8-11 it is important for physicians and other health care professionals to be knowledgeable about the subject. The purpose of this review is to update readers about key developments in this rapidly evolving area.

documents.commentText: Addiction. It's a word that has been affecting America for quite some time but in the last decade it has become one of the leading causes of death other than cancer. Cancer and addiction however do have their similarities. Both addiction and cancer are diseases and someone who suffers from either one of these killer's have to fight for their life every single day. I myself suffer from addiction. My great grandfather died of alcoholism along with my grandfather as well. This gene was passed to my father which in turn was unfortunately passed down to me as well. Though I don't drink alcohol, over time I have come to the realization that my addiction to pain medicine will forever be a constant struggle in my everyday life. My addiction all started when I broke my hand in a high school soccer game. I was prescribed Vicodin for the pain following the surgery to repair the broken bones in my hand. I was immediately hooked. I didn't stand a chance. I was 17 years old. When I had surpassed my number of refills to my prescription I couldn't figure out why I was so sick for a few consecutive days. Now I know they were something called withdrawals. As I continued to grow through my younger years I was living my life with a masked addiction that I had no idea about. Everything was fine until one day... I was at a high school party drinking alcohol to fit in like everyone else at the party when an accident occurred. I fell off of a balcony 3 floors high and landed on my back. I landed on the windshield of a car and broke my back. It required surgery and metal bars in my back to replace half of my spine. I was prescribed high levels of Vicodin for the pain. I was on this prescription for 3 whole years. When I decided to quit the Vicodin it was because I became depressed. I was able to make it through the miserable withdrawal symptoms but as I lived without my pain medicine I was in so much pain that I couldn't do simple tasks like stand stationary for more than an hour without my back throbbing in pain. I got back on the pain medicine prescription. Another year went by when I knew I just wasn't myself anymore. I didn't know what to do. I didn't want to be on Vicodin because I just became depressed but I didn't want to be off of it because I couldn't handle the pain. Finally I decided to do some research and I found out about KRATOM. I ordered some. Thank God for Kratom because I can take it everyday without being in pain but more importantly because I can be myself on it without slipping into depression. It also masked the withdrawals of the Vicodin when I decided to quit it and switch to Kratom. Kratom has saved my life. This is the only thing on the market that works to get rid of my pain without going through the constant prescription refills I was with Vicodin. I know I am not alone. Please. Don't take away Kratom. It should not be banned it should be the new alternative to prescription medicine. I tell people about Kratom all the time. I have a friend that I recommended to try Kratom for his Heroin addiction. He took it for the Withdrawals and he told me it literally saved his life to help him get through the painstaking and miserable withdrawals of heroin. Please. I am begging you to really listen and let everyone's testimonials about how Kratom has helped them and let it resonate with you. I know this is new but we as a country need new. It's how we evolve as a species. Thank you for listening. I trust you will make the right call.

documents.commentText: I'm a successful attorney and devout Christian in my 30's. I've been using kratom off and on for the last five years. I started using it as a relaxation aid, but found that it also helped me to quit drinking and reduce my ADHD medication use. I usually use a teaspoon (about 2.5-3 grams) of crushed powder, which hasn't changed in the time I've been using it. I might use it a couple times a week, at most. Depending on the strain, it either gives me mild pain relieving (Bali) or mild stimulant (Thai) effects. It is far, far safer than alcohol or methylphenidate, both of which I used legally. The most negative effect I've had is dry mouth and slight nausea, and that was with a significantly higher dose than I usually use. It's simply a mild herb that excels at easing cravings, rather than giving you a high (I've never felt anything resembling a "high" feeling). While my life will move on without issue if it's banned, I fear for the people who use it to ween themselves off opiates. The DEA will be effectively murdering them.

documents.commentText:
I am a professional in my late-twenties with a mentally-demanding job.  I have also been diagnosed with ADHD, chronic fatigue, chronic pain, on and off depression, anxiety, and finally with fibromyalgia (leading me to believe that all of my conditions may be symptoms of fibromyalgia). My doctors' solution (in addition to recommending a healthy lifestyle, which I try to do) has always been to prescribe medication.  

I've tried several prescription anti-depressants, which made me feel like a zombie or as if I was watching someone else live my life.  I've been prescribed fast-acting anxiety medication, which weren't very helpful as I couldn't be proactive in avoiding panic attacks, but could only be reactive once I felt one coming on.  I've been prescribed daily ADHD medication, which heightened my anxiety, caused me to lose my appetite and my ability to get a good night's sleep, and elevated my heart rate (which scared me, as they can cause potentially life-threatening cardiac issues).  

My doctors have tried to prescribe me strong, opioid pain medications, but I did not want to take them as I know that I need a fully-functioning and fast-acting brain to perform well in my career.  I found it interesting that because I was not seeking these types of medications, and in fact, I was refusing to take them, my doctors pushed them even harder.  It's as if they were pushing these narcotic pain medications on me BECAUSE I did not want to take them, but I have heard from others that simply asking for stronger pain medication has caused their doctors to believe that they are 'drug seekers' and thus should not have any medication prescribed at all (seems a little backwards to me, but that's a different story). 

Anyway, I first heard about kratom a few months ago due to the media coverage over the potential ban. At first, I assumed (from the misleading articles and propaganda) that this was just another dangerous drug that 'druggies' seek to get high.  I decided to dig a little deeper (and boy am I glad I did!).  I read through numerous websites that explained the potential benefits of kratom, including many forums and blog posts.  I realized that there are a LOT of people who truly believe that kratom has enhanced, or even "saved" their lives, in many different ways.  I quickly also realized that many of the people who swear by kratom have symptoms or problems that are almost identical to the ones that I was struggling with.

Although the promises of this miracle leaf seemed too good to be true, I decided to try some for myself.  At this point, I was sick and tired of feeling like I'm spending my life fighting one symptom after the other on a daily basis.  I had forgotten what it felt like to be "normal".  This is something that many people who live without chronic pain (and other chronic conditions) take for granted.  I know that before all of my issues started (in my early 20s), I definitely took my pain-free and worry-free life for granted.  

Fast forward to today (only about 2.5 months later) and I can honestly tell you that kratom truly has changed my life (already!).   I still vividly remember the feeling I had the first time I took kratom -  I was fully mentally aware, but I was calm, pain-free, and most importantly of all, "normal"!  With some guidance from people online who have been using kratom for many years, I have found a type and dosage that worked for me (and has continued to work since).  As a bonus side effect, I have completely lost my desire to have any alcohol.  I used to sometimes have two or three glasses of wine with dinner, or would feel the need to have a few drinks when out with friends (sometimes, overdoing it). Somehow, no one thought this was odd - it seems very common (and socially acceptable) that people use alcohol this way, yet it is passed off as normal behavior.  I have not touched a drink in 2.5 months!

I cannot believe that something that can help people in so many ways (and so quickly!) is being mislabeled as dangerous and essentially useless by some in the media (and of course, by regulators). It is important to remember that pain-sufferers, who would otherwise be hooked on dangerous and addictive opioids (with numerous side-effects), would be left in the dark if this ban went through, and would likely be forced to use the same medication they were happy to be rid of when they started taking kratom. 

I hope that after reading all of these comments from people who have had their lives changed for the better, the conclusion reached will not be a short-sighted one that seeks to ban this amazing, natural medicine. More research is definitely required in order to truly understand just how helpful kratom can be! Thank you for reading my comment.

documents.commentText:
Mr. Chuck Rosenberg Acting Administrator U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration 
8701 Morrissette Drive Springfield, 
Virginia 22152
November 29, 2016

Re: Docket No. DEA-442  Temporary Placement of Mitragynine and 7- Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I, Notice of Intent, 81 Fed. Reg. 59929 (Aug. 31, 2016)

Dear Acting Administrator Rosenberg, 

The action declared in DEAs August 31, 2016 Notice of Intent with regard to constituents in kratom leaf is an unprecedented use of the emergency scheduling authority to temporarily place an herb into schedule I of the CSA.  I support DEAs appropriate application of this emergency authority, which is regularly exercised by the agency, such that there are currently 20 substances listed in schedule I subject to temporary emergency scheduling (21 CFR 1308(h)). But these currently listed substances tend to be synthetic compounds, many of which are commonly known as designer drugs and are produced and marketed with no other purpose than as hallucinogens, illegal stimulants, and similar unlawful uses. However none of the substances currently listed (or to the best of my knowledge, ever listed) in schedule I through the temporary listing mechanism is a simple herb, and DEAs temporary placement of mitragynine and 7- hydroxymitragynine in schedule I will have the effect of placing kratom leaf itself on schedule I. This unprecedented application of the emergency authority for temporary placement of a substance on schedule I to an herbal ingredient with broad use is unacceptable. My view is that in situations involving an herb or other natural product DEA should reach out to herbal trade and professional associations prior to taking unilateral action that temporarily makes that herb unlawful. Indeed, in the present case there is an American Kratom Association that might have provided useful input to DEAs decision making process, as well as many learned and responsible individuals in the herbal field. Meeting or conferring with associations and groups is useful, appropriate and justified where such groups and associations are known to exist. 

On this basis, I respectfully requests DEA not to promulgate a final order temporarily scheduling mitragynine and 7- hydroxymitragynine into schedule I and to withdraw its August 31, 2016 Notice of Intent. Instead, I ask that DEA:

1)Consider the many comments that are being filed to this Docket by various organizations and individuals. 

2)Initiate the regular Docket No. DEA-442 September 30, 2016 - 5 - scheduling process for these substances, if, in fact, warranted by scientific and medical evaluation of all of the factors that are required under the CSA to be considered in the regular scheduling process.


Sincerely,
Yasoda Mensah, M.S.
Director, Three Leaf Farmden and
Trifolia Natural Products and Botanicals

documents.commentText:
I'm against adding Mitragyine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, aka, Kratom to the Schedule 1 of Controlled Substances. Banning Kratom expands the war on drugs, while I overwhelmingly support ending it.
 

If Kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, innocent people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars. Prohibiting Kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose, deny our access to natural pain relief and provide an avenue for Big Pharma to benefit once again from our lack of choice in the matter.
 

DEA, Please support the wishes of your American public. We believe placing Kratom into a Schedule 1 drug category is completely unnecessary as it has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S without incident of overdose or death. 
Side effects of Kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. Evidence supports Kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement so making it a Schedule 1 drug will certainly shut down many promising scientific studies that will help relieve these conditions.

Again, please support the wishes of the majority of responsible Americans who deserve to have a choice when it comes to their own pain and suffering.

documents.commentText:
I am 62 years old, and retired after thirty years of working for the San Diego Community College District.  I have had chronic pain in my leg for 25+ years. I have done everything the medical professionals has prescribed along with what was considered alternative medicine -  analgesics, pain medications, muscle relaxers, cupping, electro therapy, physical therapy, chiropractic, acupuncture & massage. The doctors had me on Desparmine (anti depressant), Flexril, Soma, and Motrin along with Hydrocodone.  The only drug that really seemed to help was hydrocodone. I only take it when I am in extreme pain - driving long distances, standing or walking more than a couple hours at a time. However, I do not take it until I am in a high level of pain because of the addiction problems related to hydrocodone. Because of this, I am in moderate pain a great deal of the time. My son told me about Kratom, after hearing about it on a podcast, and it has been a godsend. I am able to take it on a regular basis so I am not in constant pain. It has definitely improved my quality of life without any side effects that I can discern.   

I recently drove to Palo Alto from San Diego to visit family.  On a trip of that distance I would normally take 3 hydrocodone due to the pain in my leg.  I took one dose of Kratom (5 capsules) and was able to reduce my intake of hydrocodone to 1.5 tablets.  A 50% decrease in the hydrocodone I normally take. In the future, I will take more Kratom and see if I am able to drive that distance without any hydrocodone at all. I am not comfortable driving while on hydrocodone but in the past that was the only way I would be able to make the trip. I feel that I now have a safe alternative that has been used for thousands of years. While taking Kratom I do not have the side effects I get while taking hydrocodone, like jitters or nausea, and I have to worry about addiction. Kratom has proven to be a safe alternative in my life.  I truly appreciate my quality of life due to Kratom. I am able to hike, sit in theaters, drive long distances, stand in line at festivals, farmers markets - things people take for granted.  

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me.

Sincerely, 

Michelle West

documents.commentText:
Please do not ban Kratom; The US suffers from too many addicts and not enough recovery programs...points:
*Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
*If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up
*Privatization of prisons has incentivized locking up vs. rehab/recovery of buyers/users of illegal substances
*The war on drugs has failed to reduce the demand for drugs, and the drug lords profits continue to soar
*Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and 
*evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement, ie. rehabilitation.
*Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit
*all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
*Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
*Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.
*as long as this is legally available it can be taxed and the income generated can be used for new rehab facilities.
* promoting legalization of this along with expansion of legalization of recreational & medical marijuana and other pharmaceuticals will allow their regulation, taxation, and a booming economy from sales for all states participating
* this removes revenue from drug lords and makes neighborhoods safer for all... remove the customer base, remove the "sales men", remove the drug lords, re-allocate DEA $ to rehab facilities.
Improve life for all of us who have never used, and never plan to use, but know addicts and know people who live in poverty and are subjected to cross-fire deaths of loved ones and other violent side effects of the awful trade.

documents.commentText: I am a community pharmacist with a major drug chain. I  see the effects of the opioid epidemic every day that I practice. Let me tell you something you already know. There is a major prescription drug problem in this country. This problem is largely a product of prescribers overprescribing dangerous medications in large doses month after month. A community practice recently started drug testing their patients for whom they prescribed 100s of tablet a month. These patients refilled their prescriptions every month without fail. This practice ended up discharging over 100 patients from their practice because their test came up negative for the drugs they were prescribed. This means that one small practice can produce over ten thousand tablets a month. Most of these are being redirected to the black market no doubt. I can tell you that many people in the grips of drug addiction do not want to be a slave to their addiction. To think that you are going to ban a substance that could have a chance of curbing and controlling someone's addiction without any research to its benifishial effects is very concerning. If you are still in the business of looking out for the American public do not ban kratom. documents.commentText:
I strongly believe that the active alkaloids in Kratom do not belong on the schedule 1 list and that banning the plant would cause far more harm than good.

I work on product development, web design, and IT for a small company that publishes fishing maps and atlases. I began using Kratom about 6 years ago. Over the years it has been an invaluable resource. My first experience came when I was quite depressed. I had no health insurance, was afraid to talk about my problems, and felt like I had no where to go for help. Kratom helped pull me out of a deep pit and was incredibly helpful in getting me back to being a productive member of society. 

Kratom is not a drug, it is not an opioid, and it is not synthetic. It is a naturally occurring plant in the same family as coffee that is much more similar to coffee or tea than to other drugs or opioids. Like chocolate, exercise, and a number of other common substances, Kratom acts on the opioid receptors. Because of this, it has been largely misunderstood to be an opiate with addictive properties and the potential for overdose and abuse. It unfortunately has also been sold in some head shops alongside synthetic marijuana and bath salts, which has lead some to believe that it is somehow related to these substances and will have effects that are very different than what it actually does. To me and the thousands of other people who use Kratom or have used it in the past, hearing about the intent to schedule Kratom was like hearing that coffee would be banned. I am incredibly thankful that the large number of people who safely benefit from Kratom use, as well as a number of journalists, public figures, 51 Congressman, and 9 Senators (crossing party lines) were able to express their shock over the ban and delay the emergency scheduling. 

Kratom is a plant that has a long history of safe use in the United States. Thousands of people across the country have used it daily to manage pain, help with anxiety and depression, and to put an end to addictions to heroin and pharmaceutical opioids. If Kratom is banned, many of these people will be unable to afford an alternative substance to effectively manage their pain or will be forced to turn to highly addictive opioids. The United States is unfortunately facing an opioid and heroin epidemic, and for many people, including a close friend and several others in my hometown, Kratom saved them when they had nothing else.

I completely understand the concern of the DEA when a new substance seemingly appears out of nowhere, but the concern over the safety of the public in the case of Kratom is completely unwarranted. In my experience and those of the other Kratom users that I know and have heard from, Kratom is no more addictive than coffee and has little potential for serious abuse. People routinely get headaches and irritability from caffeine withdrawal and there will always be cases of students overdosing on caffeine pills, but we understand that overuse by some individuals is not a good reason to make it illegal for responsible adults to consume caffeine. The case is the same for a huge number of substances that we accept: Tobacco kills 500,000 annually, and alcohol contributes to thousands of drunk driving deaths, overdoses, causes birth defects, and is a factor in rape, domestic violence, and assault every day. Our nation banned alcohol due to it's adverse effects, but soon found that the prohibition created it's own string of serious problems, was largely ineffective, and curtailed the rights of responsible adults. Like anything, it is possible for Kratom to be misused, but the risks are nowhere near as severe as those involved in the use of completely legal substances. Kratom has a high LD 50, and because the body will induce vomiting to prevent over-ingestion it is incredibly unlikely that one would die as a result of Kratom overdose without the assistance of pharmaceuticals or illegal drugs. When the initial intent to schedule was announced, concern was expressed over 660 calls to poison control centers related to Kratom over a 5 year period and 15 deaths As Forbes points out, "To put kratom risks in perspective, poison control centers received 6,843 reports of young children ingesting single-load laundry pods in just the first seven months of 2016." And refer to the reported deaths in a separate article, "&14 of which also involved other, more dangerous drugs."

Kratom poses no serious threat to public safety, and a ban will do far more damage than allowing it to remain legal. Scheduling would prevent further research, would turn me and thousands of good people into criminals, would interfere with the right of adults to responsibly use safe substances, and would add fuel to the opioid epidemic by causing people to turn to dangerous and addictive drugs, boosting the black market, and removing an option for those wishing to break free from addictions to dangerous drugs.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA and other drug/health-related agencies exploring this issue. 

Please carefully consider that Kratom has a long history of responsible use in mitigating pain and anxiety. Many of the instances of "Kratom-related poisonings" that I have read involved other substances and were used at non-therapeutic doses. According to the US FDA, acetaminophen (Tylenol) is responsible for 980 deaths every year (1) and yet it has been available without prescription since 1959 (2). The list of legal-yet-toxic substances goes on and on.

Every drug, food, or substance has effects and side-effects. What is important is to weigh the actual data-driven benefits and the drawbacks in an unbiased forum and to educate consumers as to those benefits and caveats.

I respectfully request that you attempt to remain unbiased during your investigation of this evaluation. I imagine that there is considerable pressure from the pharmaceutical lobby not to give up any of its market share to this natural analgesic. 

In closing, please consider what is best for the public and remember that an estimated 100K people die annually from taking legal medication as prescribed (3). Everything has risk, so please keep this an educational, health-related issue and not a criminal one.

Respectfully,
US Citizen 



1) https://www.propublica.org/article/tylenol-mcneil-fda-behind-the-numbers  (CDC numbers show 300 direct deaths per year)
2) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracetamol
3) http://health.usnews.com/health-news/patient-advice/articles/2016-09-27/the-danger-in-taking-prescribed-medications

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am a 33-year old writer, editor, and contract lumberjack. I also help take care of my ailing 91-year old grandmother who is suffering from dementia and is unable to move on her own without assistance.

I've spent most of my life struggling with anxiety, PTSD from childhood abuse, and chronic depression. I've lost and hurt people I love dearly due to my problems. All doctors have ever done is put me on medications that have made me even more erratic and in the long run caused more harm than good. Half the time, these doctors won't even listen to me about my problems because our healthcare system is broken. I've tried everything under the moon.

I came across this plant one day by sheer accident and decided to give it a try since I've had more success with herbal supplements than any pharmaceutical drug on the planet - and they are drugs, some of them are the worst you can imagine.

Since I started supplementing Kratom I've been able to work. I've been able to help my family. I've felt like I had hope in my life for the first time in 20 years. I'm finally a productive member of society. If this plant is scheduled in any way, shape, or form, people like me are going to suffer beyond repair. I would rather be dead than go back to my life before Kratom. There has to be a time when people matter more than profits, and that time is now.

There is absolutely no real evidence that this plant can cause the kind of harm that these foolish studies are trying to claim. It's insulting to my intelligence and everyone else. I've experienced absolutely no side effects besides nausea over a period of two years using this supplement. This is propaganda at it's worst and it's absolutely appalling when people can go get drunk and kill people every single day, while cigarettes kill daily, and while this country is battling the worst opioid epidemic in history. Scheduling a supplement that can help so many people, is not only immoral, it is plain evil.

This supplement has helped so many people from all walks of life be a more productive member of society.

I pray that the people in charge will do the right thing just this one time. Restore some faith in the FDA, the DEA, and our government. Because right now, there is none left. 

Thank you for your time and your consideration. I implore you to do the right thing.

documents.commentText:
My name is Angela Parker. I'm a 37 year old  mother of a 9 year old son. He is an amazing little boy & I am so very blessed to have watched him grow to be this perfect tiny human.

That's the reason I wanted to reach out to you and try to explain what Kratom means to me. Please Allow me to have a few moments of your time , I will try to be brief,  as I know you are very busy.

There was a time not to long ago that  I was depressed, practically disabled and just empty inside. I was broken, damaged and had given up on life.
I couldn't see the light at the end of the tunnel. It started after I was prescribed pain medicine after a major surgery. Over the course of a year I had been on 4 different strengths and 3 different types of narcotics . I was a walking half functioning zombie. A dark cloud lingered over me day and night. I rarely ate, I hardly slept and had to literally make myself shower and get dressed. I didn't enjoy playing with my son anymore, I couldn't even help him with his homework. I wasn't able to clean our home or grocery shop on a regular basis. 
 I was short tempered with my family & friends & before long, they saw the negative changes and desperately tried to convince me to get help. 

Before this I was outgoing, friendly and bubbly my whole life. Doctors & medicine couldn't bring me back to that place. I couldn't help myself and didn't care enough to push any harder to get well.  my family insisted I see another therapist because they were scared seeing me like that. 
I was Diagnosed with depression, anxiety, mood disorders & ADD.
 My physical health was deteriorating fast. Already Having Lupus & chronic migraines, I suffered every day of my life in debilitating pain.
I suffered with Chronic kidney infections, bladder infections & even sepsis. I lost one kidney at 21 and spent most of my life On antibiotics & pain meds. I never had energy so was prescribed can Ritalin. The side effects of all these drugs caused horrible reactions. I spent years In and out of hospitals & had to have multiple surgeries,  eventually having my gall bladder removed last year & abdominal tumors & abdominal cysts removed. After 6 more long months of and so many different medications failing, I gave up on ever being happy , pain free & active again. 

Im ashamed to say that I eventually broke & I ended up over dosing in an attempt to stop the suffering. I had hit rock bottom and had no where left to go. I saw that my son was hardly with me because I wouldn't properly care for him so my mom and dad had Tyler 80% of the time and the other 20% time with me was  supervised. That was The turning point in my so called life was when a random stranger in group therapy told me how she used suffer & be destructive just like I was until her doctor suggested an all natural plant to her. She was saved , given her life back and began to pay it forward by giving talks in support groups , online forums and even at pain clinics. I was skeptical but yet I was so desperate & willing to try anything that I agreed. 
I researched this plant, Kratom and found so many success stories that I knew I had to give this a chance, for my son, my family and for myself. I found all the information , support and knowledge I needed and made the first step towards recovery. 
I can't tell you how grateful I am that I got another chance at life and my son finally has the mother & life he deserves. I Am happy & feel alive again. documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am a graduate student working on a Masters Degree in neuroscience at the University of British Columbia. As a research scientist I think it is extremely important to do controlled experiments on any substance that has the potential to be helpful - either as a medicine, or as a research tool. 

We know that people who have  opiate addictions seemed to find relief from these cravings with Kratom. Not only opiate addicts, but also alcohol addicts. It has been reported that not only can this help to relieve addiction, but can also control pain. All of this is speculative and NEEDS to be researched. 

We also know that biology creates specificity with receptor-ligand connections better then anything in the lab. This is why researchers will use natural toxins and receptors to activate/silence/block pathways in the brain and body to answer questions about how things work, rather than using synthetic drugs. Nothing is more specific than what evolution has designed.

This is why it would be irresponsible to remove this substance from the ability to be researched and possibly prescribed/used by those who may need it. Many more questions need to be asked and research needs to be done to answer them. We cannot let pharmaceutical companies continue to monopolize the drug market. There is a reason that these plants have existed for such a long amount of time, we now have the ability to know why. Knowledge is power, lets not cripple our power.

Hello,

My name is Bryan Scarborough and I am an engineer.  I'm graduating from the Petroleum Engineering master's program at University of Oklahoma this December. Since then, I have continued to use kratom to relieve minor anxiety and I consider it a blessing.  I'm healthy, doing great at school and work, and looking forward to a positive future.  

Please consider the comments of people like myself, the research studies on kratom's medicinal potential, and the statistics (or lack of statistics) on actual kratom deaths (no other drugs).  I truly believe this is in the best interest of public health.

I'm writing today to share with you how much this beautiful plant has helped me in my life. 

In 1998 I severely herniated a disc in my back at work. I have a very low income and could not afford proper medical treatment for it and it became a chronic injury. Several times a year I would become fully immobile. Even worse, I lived with a constant low to medium level of pain and discomfort. My quality of life was greatly compromised and my emotional health suffered because of it.

Pharmaceutical pain medication terrifies me as I've seen it take over and destroy many lives with profound addiction. Yet I needed relief. After some research I came across Kratom, and many testimonials from people who had used it for pain relief. I sought it out and what I experienced was nothing short of a miracle. 

The kratom immediately eased my pain and discomfort. With it came a lifting of the dark mood I had come accustomed to. I felt connected again with a joy for life that I hadn't felt since a child. What it offers is not a high or an intoxication, but more a balancing. My performance and mental clarity is not dismissed in any way.

At its worse when I took too much once, I only felt a transitory dizziness, sleepiness and nausea. It passed quickly and presented no true physical hazard. I've never experienced an unpleasant physical or mental side effect after years of use. The claims of addiction are very overstated and at its worse parallel those of a regular coffee habit.

Its very affordable and remarkably easy to use. Its a very gentle and generous plant and it's my strong feeling that all humans on this planet have a birth right to benefit from it if they choose. It has helped so so many achieve the quality of life they desire. Because of its medicinal properties I'm a better worker, friend, partner and member of society. This plant is only positive and suggesting it be prohibited is in itself an absurd crime against humanity!

Your wisdom in delaying the ban on kratom has given me so much hope and admiration for the DEA, now I have nothing but respect for your ability to listen, learn, and act appropriately, Thank you so much for hearing the voice of the people!
My name is Matt, and I'm 25 years old. I work at Barnes and Noble where I love to connect people with new books and ideas which can change there life.
Before finding kratom I was a functioning alcoholic and I barely made it to work because of the daily hangovers which plagued my waking life. Each and every day was a struggle to resist the urge to drink,  every method of quitting failed me. From AA to naltrexone, to anabuse all these provided only a stronger urge to drink and fill the genetic predisposition to drown in a bottle of alcohol. I was on the verge of giving up and letting myself drink until I  died. 
But then something miraculously happened to me. While talking with a new friend about any supplements which had helped him maintain his sobriety he mentioned a plant named kratom. I didn't have much confidence in his testimonies, because it sounded to good to be true. After nearly 6 years of trying everything under the sun I wouldn't believe that a simple plant could alter a persons addictions so drastically. But I decided to trust this persons unrelenting enthusiasm about Kratom and buy some at a local sore in downtown Denver, because hey, I had run out of options and knew my mind and liver were running quickly out of time.
3 capsules of kratom later the urge was gone. I felt normal, I felt functional, I felt the curse of my families Irish alcoholic history had been washed away and redemption was at hand. Freedom never felt so good, I jumped around the house thanking god for giving me a second chance at life. 
Six months of sobriety all thanks to this miraculous plant. I have become a fully functional member of society and a drastically better, son, boyfriend, employee, and citizen. I wake up everyday now refreshed, rested, with no hangover and that is such a blessing. I can drink in moderation again with kratom and celebrate birthdays or weddings as a responsible consumer of alcohol again without getting drunk. With the monkey of addiction off my back I can pursue my dreams and contribute to society as every responsible person has the right to. 
            I hope this story is only one of countless others which you have read, reflected on, and used to make a final decision. The benefits are too great and the consequences to drastic to ban this plant for American citizens who deserve justice and the pursuit of happiness. Please don't make kratom a scheduled compound!!!!

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am writing in regards to the Drug Enforcement Agency moving to place "Kratom" on the list of Schedule 1 drugs. I am in agreement with this decision. Our country is facing an opioid addiction crisis. Having previously worked for the Wisconsin State Legislature, and currently working for a family practice clinic in Madison, WI I have dealt with this issue from a variety of angles. While I understand that Kratom is not technically an opiate, it affects the same receptors and causes the same effects on the body. 

Skimming through other comments and doing research online it is clear that many people do not understand the true nature of this substance, or the fact that it is exceptionally similar to heroin, morphine, or any other opioid. They feel like they are making a better, healthier decision, which could really be leading them down a path to addiction. Working as an RN I am very aware that there are people who require daily pain medication to live. However, these medications are risky and require the oversight of a provider. It is not safe to self-treat with medications sold over the internet or on the street without any sort of regulation or guarantee of purity. We tell patients consistently to refrain from buying prescription medications from disreputable sources, and I believe that allowing Kratom to be sold with no regulation would go against best practice and best policy. 

Doing research into this drug, there are many stories about the substance being used to wean people off of opioids. If this is valid and this substance would be able to help people wean off opioids and become independent of all substances (not just replace heroin with Kratom) than the medication should be made available through safe channels at reasonable costs. Recently the FDA has agreed to approve a trial of MDMA (ecstasy) to treat post-traumatic stress disorder. If Kratom is effective in treating addiction than it will be able to hold up to a similar clinical trial. 

I have family members who suffer with opioid addiction. I have seen first-hand what it can do to a person and the effect it can have on their lives. I also know how misinformation on the ability to get addicted to prescription pain killers has increased the abuse of these drugs. While I realize that placing this drug on the Schedule 1 list will not do much to decrease addiction it is a preventative measure to help keep the drug away from our citizens and not exacerbate the problem we are already facing. I am open to research if there is a demand and people are willing to pay for and/or participate in clinical trials of the substance. However, I believe that it is also in the best interest of our nation that this move be made to protect citizens from believing the substance is a "safe, natural, alternative" to heroin or other opioids. Obviously, having heroin or ecstasy listed as Schedule 1 has not stopped them from getting into the hands of people across the country. However, it does mean that the majority of people know that the drug is dangerous. 

The hope is that education programs and new regulations on narcotics and prescribing practices will help curb the opioid epidemic. Doctors, nurses, legislators and activists across the country are hard at work finding creative solutions to help those addicted and to prevent others from becoming addicted. The last thing we need as we clamp down on one drug is to introduce another and allow it to remain legal and unregulated. For these reasons I agree with placing Kratom on the Schedule 1 list until such a time that it is determined to have a safe, medicinal purpose.

documents.commentText: I've suffered from GAD, OCD, and bipolar depression since I was sixteen. Being inside my head is miserable, so at a young age, I began using drugs. My first experience with opium was a revelation. For the first time in nineteen years I felt truly happy. I entered into a relationship with a junky, and later became one myself. I got clean through relocation, but every second of every day was spent thinking about opium, wishing I could get my hands on some. Eighteen months later, I found a connection for hydrocodone. For the past two and a half years I have spent every spare dollar, even those I could not spend, on chasing the dragon. At my worst, I was taking eight pills a day just to maintain the habit. As a functioning addict, I had a full time job I could not take time off of to go through the painful, miserable experience that is opiate withdrawal. On top of the physical discomfort, the emotional withdrawal would cause me so much anxiety and mania that I would often come close to suicide. At that point, I would break my vow of sobriety and go buy more pills. I tried the twelve step program, it didn't work and just depressed me more by letting other people's problems into my own issue ridden life. I then moved across the country for the summer to get away and detox. I was sober for three months, but I looked for pills every single day. When I finally drove home, instead of going straight to my apartment after a two day drive, I went an extra hour and a half out of my way to get pills. My dealer, who had never shied away from making his desires for me known, began to grow more confident in his advances and finally tried to elicit sexual favors in exchange for pills. I was in a terrible position and knew I needed an out. Serendipitously, one of the libertarian Facebook pages I followed posted an article about the DEA planning to classify kratom as Schedule 1. I had never heard of this plant or its benefits prior to the posting. I spent the next several hours reading reviews from former addicts about the wonders of kratom. I hurried to my local head shop and purchased my first few grams. My life is so much better because of it. I did not experience a single symptom of withdrawal even a week after taking my last pills. Not only that, but my desire to get more pills had completely dissolved. My dealer contacted me thrice that week, and I didn't bother to text him back. I am now six weeks sober and have no wish to take another opiate, not because I'm afraid of where I'll end up if I do, but because I don't need the high. It's as if my brain has been rewired and my addiction eliminated. I now use kratom simply as an antidepressant and anti-anxiety treatment since it gives me the slight happiness boost I longed for that prescribed medication never has. I am happier than I ever have been because of this plant. I implore you to please take this into account, to listen not to the pharmaceutical companies who want to continue shoving opiates down the nation's throats for profit, but to the US citizens like me who have gotten their lives back. I want everyone in the world to have the option to use kratom for whatever reason. There's no high, no cognitive impairment, nothing to make this drug something you need to regulate. It's about the same level of dangerous as a B12 vitamin. Please make the right decision by the American people and leave kratom alone.

documents.commentText: I am a 57 year old male who is an ordained minister. I first discovered Kratom in early 2004 while looking for an alternative to narcotic pain medication for treating chronic lower back pain and arthritis. At that time it was relatively unknown in the US and identified as being from the coffee family. I began using Kratom at that time and found that it actually was helpful for pain relief with none of the side effects of opiod pain meds. It is not a substance that has ever resulted in my being intoxicated. In smaller amounts it is mildly stimulating at best similar to coffee. In higher doses it may be somewhat relaxing, however I can emphatically state it is not at all comparative to prescription drugs I have used in the past such as opiods, tranquilizers, sedatives, etc..- I have seen this misinformation in the media and unless it is somehow being tainted with other substances or drugs plain kratom is nothing like those drugs. It has been almost 13 years of my using kratom, and the past 7 include regular and almost daily doses. I am very active and also extremely health conscious. I have regular medical check ups and lab work done every six months for thyroid/cholesterol as well as liver/kidney function and all tests have been in normal range. I have had two shoulder surgeries in the past 5 years and used kratom rather than opiod medication throughout the recovery. I must really emphasize that kratom does not impair you and something like Benadryl has a much more sedating effect than kratom in my experience. Although the significant benefits of Kratom are considered mostly anecdotal I have seen it proven to be nothing short of miraculous in saving several people I know personally from long term and severe addictions when no other treatments had been successful. It saved their lives. Please do not schedule this drug as planned. It has benefitted myself greatly but even more importantly it has actually saved, and will save the lives of so many others, especially with the current opiod crisis in this country.

documents.commentText:
Good morning, my name is Jared Williams, I'm 33 years old, a college graduate, a father and very active in my community. I'd simply like to take some time to express my opinions and two positive experiences I've had with Kratom. First, two years ago I found out I was allergic to acetaminophen and aspirin apparently. It's not severe but I do get hives when taking Tylenol, Advil, Aspirin, Ibuprofen, among other painkillers. Either way, occasionally I get pretty bad migraines and my Doctor actually recommended trying Kratom to prevent serious migraines from interfering with my work and family time. I gave it a shot and it has helped tremendously. I have never had the urge to abuse it or use it for recreationally; I only use when I get a bad headache and it immediately eliminates the pain without making me feel impaired or fuzzy. Also, I realized that taking Kratom 1 - 3 times a week has helped me with my IBS, apparently it's an excellent source of fiber...who would've known! 

Another more important experience I also witnessed firsthand was Kratom's ability to assist people in overcoming addiction to prescription painkillers like Oxy and Vicodin. Two of my good friends fell on hards times and both of them fell victim to the abuse of prescription painkillers. One of these friends was addicted to Oxy for over 8 years and the other was an addict of Hydrocodone and Vicodin for approximately 4 years. After I did some research on Kratom and after speaking with my Doctor I learned that Kratom can help people overcome opiate addiction. I told my friends about this over a year ago and I can proudly say that as of this year they are both completely drug free. The reason I write this is because one of these friends actually sent me a text two days ago and all he wrote was "Thank you, Kratom has saved me." After hearing that I knew I had to share my experience on this form. One of the two friends takes Katom about 3 times a week to battle urges, and the other is completely off any type of assistance, not even needing Kratom. These two friends had trouble communicating in public without opiates in their system, they both looked sick and lost the color in their skin, but as of this last year with the assistance of Kratom they're now very active, one of the two went back to college and the other is very successful in his line of work; to sum it up...they have their lives back! So I'm just sharing my story, and I know Kratom has helped several others with addiction, anxiety, ADHD, etc. It would be a shame to see this plant banned, I can guarantee we'd see the opiate use increase and I can't imagine someone going to jail or getting arrested for something like Kratom. That's my story and I thank you for your time and for hearing me out. Happy Thanksgiving and Merry Christmas.

Schedule I drugs, substances, or chemicals are defined as drugs with no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse.

This is not true for Kratom, it has been shown numerous times in reports from users to help recovering Opiate addicts, treat pain, combat depression and anxiety, and much more. Bruce Lane

documents.commentText:
Here is my story
I am a thirty-five-year-old mother of two young energetic wonderful children, a loving wife, a dance teacher, a web designer and a nature lover. And I am able to keep up with the intense demands of my life, because of the plant Kratom. 
Before I started supplementing with Kratom, I was going downhill fast.  Ive suffered from major depressive disorder and chronic pain my whole life, which only got worse post-partum. I had many days a month where I couldnt get out of bed, endless crying, obsessing about death, so very sad that I couldnt keep up with the needs of my beautiful children. I felt cursed, and wondered if life was supposed to be so damn hard, so impossible. I was so grateful to have my children, but at the same time, I felt so much guilt and shame because I could barely function. I wouldnt wish that feeling on anyone. 
A little over a year ago, I started supplementing with Kratom. And immediately my depression lifted, and my energy returned. The chronic aching pains that kept me from dancing and exercising, were instantly relieved. It was a miracle. I did not feel high. For the first time in years, I felt normal. 
My family and I are now thriving, I am a positive, happy person who works hard at everything I do, contributes to society and finally I am pursuing the things I love.

documents.commentText:
My name is Phil. I'm a 31 year old cab driver from Asheville, NC. I have a Bachelor of Arts degree from Beloit College. I have been consuming kratom--in the form of tea--for a little over a year and a half now, though I have known about it a lot longer. I used to be addicted to opiates for many years. It destroyed some of my relationships, and hindered my progress in life greatly. Since utilizing kratom, I have no more cravings, I have energy and zest for life, and I have not gone back to using opiates. I also have battled depression and anxiety throughout my life and this plant has helped with that as well. I'm going to keep this personal and not include scientific claims or research, but there is plenty of it out there, and most all of it is positive. The fact that this plant--this TEA--was even being considered as a schedule 1 illegal substance is absurd. Any negative or harmful influences on my life from it are scarce. 

I make a bottle of tea each day to drink throughout (like many people do with coffee). It gets me no more "wired" than caffeine does, and makes me feel no more "high" than the way I feel after having some dark chocolate or a good session of yoga. The biggest effect it has on me is with my mood. I'm generally content most of the time, and I'm able to be productive and better navigate life's ups and downs. This has all the effects found in numerous herbal supplements wrapped up into one nice little plant. I really do not want it taken away from me, and I think doing so will do more harm to society than it does good.

The opiate epidemic has been terrible for a long time now, and anything that can help ease its disastrous effects on families and society should be embraced, not shunned. People are not showing up dead in emergency rooms because of this plant. They are regaining their lives, being more productive members of society, and a bettering themselves--often with a smile on their faces. I fully support kratom, I will continue taking it as long as I have access to it, and I will fight for it to remain legal and accepted in society for the benefit of anyone who needs it.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am writing to urge you to sign the Dear Colleague Letter to the DEA. This letter expresses disapproval of the DEA's scheduling of kratom as a schedule I controlled substance, which calls for mandatory prison sentences for anyone carrying even a small amount of the tea. 

Kratom helps millions of people in the U.S. (not just junkies, but respectable and hard working citizens) deal with pain. Many millions of people who suffer from severe chronic pain have become addicted to prescription opiates, which is an incredibly serious addiction that many of them will never recover from. This issue would only be exacerbated by the scheduling of kratom. 

In my opinion, that is plenty good reason not to ban kratom, but of course, there is even more to it. Kratom is an incredible tool for overcoming addiction to both powerful opiates (prescription and otherwise) and alcohol. It's known, not only to be just as effective as methadone and suboxone, but also to be much easier to step down and get clean from. Not only that, but the relapse rate for those who recover using kratom is lower than for those who use methadone or suboxone. On top of that, methadone and suboxone are chemicals that are synthesized in labs and factories. It seems absolutely ridiculous to favor them over a type of tea that has been shown to work even more effectively.

I know a lot of this first hand. I became addicted to prescription opiates that were prescribed to me after a simple but painful procedure. They claimed that the amounts they were giving me were "standard for this type of procedure" yet it was plenty to get me hooked and in withdrawals (which are much worse than the post procedure pain) when I decided to stop. Keep in mind, I was taking the proper amount, however they did up my dosage as my tolerance developed. After doing research and learning about kratom, I gave it a shot, and it was an absolute lifesaver. I was able to switch to kratom entirely, and ween  off of it within a month, with absolutely no withdrawals, which meant I could still go to school, continue work, and keep on enjoying life. I now use it on occasion for pain, and I never feel the urge to start using again regularly, which addicts know, if you relapse on opiates even a little, you'll be back in the deep end before you know it. One of the greatest things about it is that, because of the dosage plateau, there really isn't much deep end. It is possible to become dependent, but most of the factors that contribute to serious addiction do not apply to kratom. The best example is the idea of "chasing the high", which is the reason addicts use more and more every time to feel as good as they did the last time. With kratom, even if you reach the dose ceiling, if you continue to use at that level, you will only develop more tolerance, and once the high is entirely non existent, there is no more incentive to continue to use. It really is a miracle opiate in that way. The DEA does not know how great it can be for those who truly benefit from it. I would still have that huge problem in my life if it hadn't been for kratom. If more prescription opiate (or even heroin) users made the switch, it would save hundreds of thousands of lives over the next 10 years.

The DEA claims they are trying to protect the public. I do not believe that for a second. The whole situation screams lobbying from big pharma, especially since patents were filed, shortly after the announcement of the ban, for several compounds that were synthesized from 2 of the effective alkaloids found in kratom, Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine. Kratom addiction itself takes much longer to develop than addiction from any other opiate that either exists on the streets, or is pushed by pharmaceutical companies. Not only that, but, according to the American Society of Addiction Medicine, 47,055 people died of opiate overdose in 2014, which works out to be about 5 deaths an hour! Of these, 18,893 of them were prescription opiates, which means 2 of those 5 per hour were caused by substances that are accepted by the DEA. Kratom, on the other hand, has never caused an overdose in all of medical history. It doesn't require much thought to realize that a ban of it would only make matters worse in this country. Please, do your own research, and make the decision that makes most sense to you.

Thank you,
Ryan McKay

To Whom It May Concern,
   My fiancee and I found Kratom in September of this year. My sister has fibromyalgia and she had been posting articles about the ban on Facebook. I wanted to know more about Kratom so she had told me about it. She uses Kratom daily to help with her pain from the fibromyalgia and hip pain as she is waiting on getting a full hip replacement at 37 years old. She will not take pain pills because she hates the way they make her feel but takes Kratom to get her through the day. She also has severe anxiety anytime she has to leave her house and Kratom makes it possible for her to function in public. 
   Her husband was an alcoholic and because of his alcoholism, they were on the verge of divorce. He had gone to rehab and when he got out, he started using Kratom to help with his alcohol withdrawals and mood swings. Kratom saved their marriage. 
   When we found out about this, I had already been researching ways to detox from opiates because my fiancee had become addicted to Percocets. He was shot in his arm while working as a tow truck driver 8 years ago. I was 8 months pregnant with our son at the time. He was set up, shot, and robbed by an 18 year old felon. It caused many issues afterward. He didn't regain complete use of his arm for a year after the shooting. He developed PTSD and severe, crippling anxiety because of it. It also messed up his back. He was taking 15 - 20 10mg Percocets daily for his back pain. He tried quitting the pain pills cold turkey and couldn't handle the withdrawals. Kratom saved him and our relationship. He now can work again and is off of Social Security Disability. It not only helps his pain, but his anxiety is under control. He has been off of pain pills for two months now. 
   I also have back pain and take Kratom when I can no longer function through the pain. Kratom does not make you high. I have yet to experience any type of euphoria that people claim it provides. It only gives me a sense of calm and relaxation. Please do not take this natural pain and anxiety away from our family.

My name is Brandon Achten and I'm 37 years old from Louisiana. I have battled opiate addiction for over 15 years.
