documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

Let me begin by saying that kratom has helped me turn my life around. I am a 24 year old white male with a college degree and a full time job. In the early years of college my girlfriend and I started using her leftover oxycodone after her surgery. It took about a year but after that we were full addicts. As I went through college my addiction got worse and I almost failed to graduate. After college I spent a year in the same city with my addiction in its worst stages. A friend introduced me to kratom, and it alone is the reason I am clean today. Kratom alleviated most of my withdrawal pains and made the experience much more bearable. To make a long story short, I am now nearly 2 years clean from opiates. I still have kratom around to help me out when I get cravings, and it works well to subside those. I have also been prescribed benzodiazepines for my social anxiety (for 3 years), and since taking kratom I have been able to reduce my dose of benzos by almost half. 

I want to emphasize that while I take kratom to alleviate craving symptoms and in place of benzodiazepines, kratom has never given me a "high".  There is a mood boost I would associate with caffeine. Kratom works to help my pain, my anxiety, and my cravings, but does not affect me physically or mentally the way opiates used to, or benzodiazepines can. I believe that having acces to kratom has the potential to save and improve thousands of lives. So many people die from overdoses in this country, and I feel that if they only knew about kratom, their situations can be greatly improved. 

I sincerely hope that all of this information is taken into account when you make your decision.

Thank you,
Will Hooper

documents.commentText:
Hello,

	I was told Kratom is under consideration for banning and making it illegal, so I am sharing my thoughts with you. 

	I am a 50 year old photographer with a wife and 15 year old child. I began using Kratom about 3 years ago as a pain aid. I had herniated a few discs in my lower spin and had severe pain. I was prescribed narcotics, oxycodone for the most part from my doctor. They worked for the pain but put me in a stupor and compromised my alertness. In addition I became dependent on them. After doing research I found people were using Kratom to avoid opiate pain killers and used it to temper the withdrawals of discontinuing them as well. I ordered a small quantity of different varietals and found one that seemed to work for my system and symptoms. I do not respond to Advil, Aspirin or Tylenol at all but Kratom will alleviate my pain easily. I suspect this herb is on the chopping block because it cuts out the need for be pharma who must be lobbying to have it labeled illegal in order to keep up their profits. I have used this for 3 years daily now and have had no side effects. I feel great as a result and if you go to my website you can see that I am a highly functional professional. I do not consider this a drug, I have experienced, pot and some other mild drugs in my past growing up in the 70s, I know what drinking is like and honestly this is nothing like a drug or drinking, I am fully alert on kratom never feel the need to take more and do not withdrawal from it. I have heard a couple news stories of people seeking medical attention from it but I suspect the ingested a version from a head shop somewhere that was not pure. If you do anything you should classify it as you would an herbal remedy like st johns wort and let it sell in cvs and whole foods, at least this way it will be pure. Get it passed through the FDA and approved, it beats this epidemic of opiate abuse we have in this country. 

	As a second thought. I am aware there are paraphernalia shops out there selling Kratom in pre-packaged capsules. I have purchased some of these and suspect they are not what they claim to be. I have almost always purchased my Kratom from one source online in bulk and made my own capsules. I think the various street shops selling Kratom packets dont know what they are selling. I suspect these store bought items are mixed with other things such as synthetic marijuana and such. I do not do drugs and have disliked any I tried, this herb is NOT harmful at all. I have heard of people overdosing and having issues needing medical attention. I cant imagine this being caused by Kratom, I am sure there is something else going on causing this reaction. 

	I would suggest looking at it as an herbal supplement like Ginko, Ginseng and some of the other bottled herbs sold in Whole Foods etc, this is how Kratom should be treated. It is far far far weaker than any NyQuil product in terms of sedation, far less intoxicating than alcohol, and even less dangerous than aspirin. It is an herb with digestive benefits as well. I have no doubt that it has some properties that make the user feel a little happier, but why on earth would you consider that a problem. I have consumed and average of 40 grams a month daily for the last few years, if there were any side effects I would know it by now. Please dont take this away from me, my only other option is a combination of anti-anxiety medication, depression medication and pain killers. I have taken those too before Kratom and they ruined my life and relationships, they are highly addictive and impossible to stop  taking. Xanax is the worst, Wellbutrin and Effexor withdrawals made me want to die, opiate pain killers are mind numbing and zap my energy. Kratom is the perfect solution for all of these things, it is far less potent, not dependent and kind on the system. 

	Please do not take this one thing away from me that helps me get through my day. 


All my best,

CHRISTOPHER K KOLK
www.christopherkolk.com
ckolk@mac.com
917-673-4091

I am a husband and I am a father to my 5 children. I am not a junkie and I dislike that I need anything to get through the day, especially if it is medicine that will harm me. Kratom has been effective in relieving my pain and has helped to keep my liver count to a safe number, according to my primary doctor. Kratom should remain available. documents.commentText: Your comment is an opportunity to oppose to the DEAs proposal to make the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine schedule 1 controlled substances. This would put kratom -- a plant consumed safely in the U.S for decades and world-wide for millennia, and one that helps millions of people -- on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. This makes no sense to me as I have been taking kratom for almost two year and have been healthy in all aspects of my life. I am an owner of a successful small business and am motivated on a daily basis. Kratom has assisted me in this motivation and keeps me in a great mood. Before kratom I had high anxiety and it was so bad to the point in which I had to get counseling. Once I started taking kratom my anxiety went down and has stayed down immensely. I have been taking the same dosage for the 2 years that I have been taking kratom and have never felt the need to take more. Kratom comes from the same family as the caffeine tree and from my personal experience has similar effects to this. My main question is if caffeine can be legal and socially accepted then why are we rushing to put such a high illegal status to another plant from the same family without further researching it. Making it illegal will prevent any further research from being able to be conducted. These alkaloids have been shown to work in a similar method as opiods without the HIGHLY dangerous effects of respiratory depression or physical addiction (which leads to heavily dangerous withdraws when coming off of). Looking at the situation from a 3rd person view makes the scheduling of this plant appear completely absurd and unproductive. The scheduling of this plant is unfair to the people and will lead to even more distrust in our already distrusted government.

documents.commentText:
Thanks for reviewing our comments before making a very consequential decision as to whether or not to put kratom on as a scheduled substance. 

When I heard it was going to be put into the schedule 1 substance category, I was shocked. 
I've taken kratom for about 5-6 years now (3 or so years daily) for crippling anxiety and I've said and will continue to say that kratom is one of the best things to ever happen to me.
Before I started taking kratom, I'd skip classes, avoid responsibilities, avoid friends and socializing with people in general. Since I started taking kratom years ago, when I have been taking classes, I have shown up almost every day. And for the first year ever, actually was able to obtain six 4.0s and a 3.9, 3.6 and a 3.2 in the 9 classes I took in the last year I took of college to prove it. I no longer experience the extreme anxiety that has plagued my life. 

If kratom becomes an illegal substance, I have no idea what I'll do. As I see it, I'll have two options, neither are good. 
1. Seek out a psychiatrist for highly addictive benzodiazepines, which come with far more side effects and are far more dangerous, having a much lower LD50. 
or 
2. Seek illegal opiates, which needless to say, would also be highly addictive and also come with more side effects and a MUCH lower LD50 making them far more dangerous. 

Option number 2 might be likely for me, seeing as I'm already prescribed a controlled substance for ADHD and psychiatrists are very hesitant at prescribing controlled substances to begin with. 
But it is far more likely for those without health insurance. Regardless, neither is a positive outcome.

What's great about kratom, is since I've been taking it, I have never had to increase the dose once since I've started it. I have increased the frequency with which I dose, but I've found if I hit a certain dose, I become a bit nauseous. This is a widely reported symptom of taking too much kratom. And while not lethal, highly discourages the increase of dosage. I have a few friends who have hit that point and never increased the dose beyond it. 

It also doesn't appear to be highly addictive, as I've given friends samples of it, who have then tried it several other times, but no longer take it (to my knowledge). In fact, one of my friends I gave a sample to, actually used it to get off of his 2+ year addiction to morphine (I don't know how long he had been addicted to it, but I know it had been at least for a few years). His addiction had even led him to call the suicide hotline at one point.
When he told me about the withdrawals, I mentioned that kratom might be able to help with that since it has opiate-like properties, only it comes with far less withdrawal symptoms. I've personally taken breaks from it for 2 weeks-a month after taking it daily and the only withdrawal symptoms I had ever felt were a mild tingling feeling in my head for the first two days and slight restless leg syndrome for a week or two (but nothing that an aspirin and a dose of melatonin couldn't help with).
In fact, I've found caffeine withdrawal to be far less tolerable (massive headaches and depression the first few days, with fatigue, insomnia and constipation for 2-3 weeks). 
Two weeks after my friend had switched to kratom, he was free of his addiction and even stopped taking kratom as well. That was beyond what I was expecting, I had assumed he would just substitute his morphine addiction with kratom and possibly relapse back to morphine on multiple occasions (similar to what I've seen with friends and coworkers who have switched from cigarettes to E-cigs and vaporizers). 
I will provide my contact information in case you wish to speak with that friend. 

If kratom is put on the scheduled substance list, there's no doubt in my mind that it will lead to far more cases of the already epidemic levels of opiate addiction in this country. It will only snatch away or make it much harder to obtain the best alternative (as far as I know) to quitting opiates, seeing as methadone is also highly addictive and comes with the same withdrawal symptoms as opiates and opiate blockers interrupt a person's life and can lead to a person relapsing again, as it shoots a person straight into the peak of withdrawal. 

If kratom even becomes a schedule 2 or schedule 3, it will take years of FDA testing and marketing before it would become prescribed as a medication (and seeing as it's a plant, I'm not sure it could become a medication? Don't have enough knowledge on that part of it.). 
By making substances that are far safer to opiates illegal to consume, it only leads people who already have a predisposition to drug abuse and people like me who suffer from anxiety to seek out more accessible and cheaper substances. And in this case, the only more accessible and cheaper alternatives to kratom that act on opioid receptors are prescription opiates or heroin. 

Thank you for hearing me and the public out on this important issue!

Dear   Our Drug Enforcement Agency,                                  ,

I am writing to you from the bottom of my heart to let you know why Kratom needs more time under scientific light before being put right up there next to Heroin etc. 
I found Kratom while I  was searching for natural ways to detoxify my body that I dearly love from harmful opiates that were prescribed by my Dr.s' to help me with my chronic pain. I was in a couple motor vehicle accidents while away for college about 15 years ago. My name is Sarah  and born and raised on the Island of Kauai. I have had great parents and older brothers . My Mother was from Michigan and is  Retired  teacher and my Father is Hawaii born and a retired Union Carperter  and a Pilot for the Civil Air Patrol. I was raised right , to be kind to all,  to  follow society's laws and just be a kind responsible person.I recycle everything that I can to help our children have a better tomorrow. I do active volunteer beach clean ups as it is very much needed at some beaches in the and areas  and  I am a contributing member of society and do Outreach Clinics for people who have  trouble with hearing.
 I have never been convicted of any crimes, I currently have a license to purchase firearms to go  Hunting with my Dad and Brothers which requires an in depth  background check in all areas mentally and criminally.
  My Jobs consist of working with peoples personal financial portfolios  and that too require crystal clean background checks .
My current and regular 9-5 job position,  I work with many patients from young to old  in the Hearing Health Industry. I  work with very highly confidential paperwork  and with many officials that help run our state in different areas and I am trusted and take this job very, very seriously. 
I am pleading to you , Our Drug Enforcement Agency  to please just allow time for Scientist to catch up and do more testing of this  herb before it is banned .  There has been ZERO  Deaths  that is in result of Kratom alone. The Kratom Association ran by Susan Ash hired a  neutral independent toxicologist to review the cases they found with Kratom and confirmed that it was mixed with other drugs and therefore cannot rule that it was because of Kratom alone.  If this is the reason why , than we need to ban Alcohol and tobacco use since that causes much more deaths hourly than Kratom has in years.
Currently there are  different University's and Hospitals that are  showing  definite potential for Kratom  at helping with opiate withdrawals which can either reduce the use of very strong pharmaceuticals such as suboxone and methadone. If anything Methadone alone should be on a schedule 1 drug because of how many Americans are so physically and mentally hurt by it but it is only a Schedule 2 . We  couldn't get anyone to help our family friend get into a rehab because that was what he was addicted to and no one would take him in due to liabilities and lack of equipment to help him detoxify  safely. He needed to fly to California to do so and it cost  a lot of money for a single income family due to his addiction to Opiates and Methadone.  He was brought to life repeatedly and it is a travesty that we are doing this to a herb that has been around for centuries that can help us with the deaths from opiates by allowing people to help their addictions and use Kratom to taper versus Methadone which addicts mix with Benzodiapines  and then never get off drugs.  In Alabama , after they banned Kratom the deaths on opiates jumped up close to around 15,000 more deaths than the previous year.
For my pain relief  , with just a 1/2 tsp of Kratom 2 x a day , eliminated my use of Prescription Drugs and has definitely helped bring some happiness and blues skies to my days. It has changed my life and I believe Saved and Saves my life. When on strong pain relievers you no longer feel, you body and brain is shut down to so much beauty this world has to offer and I beg that you take a look at this and see how many people this helps. I am blessed to have the pain I have because while reading everyone else's testimonials , I feel blessed  that this is all I have to live with compared to other people.  Sad but so true.  Some people cannot even get out of bed even with their Prescribed Prescriptions  because of their diseases  but Kratom allows them to get up and live and be parents and teachers. Bottom  line We need your  help.
Thank you so much for allowing me to share my Kratom Story. I was not going to share it  but I feel that I too need to do my part and help put this subject in the light so it just doesn't disappear and lose its chance to save more lives. 
Sincerely,
Sarah

I have been an occasional user of Kratom for a few years, starting with its usefulness on long backpacking trips and traveling. Aside from my personal benefit, this plant serves a much greater purpose to society. Growing up in Tucson, AZ I have lost many friends to Heroin overdose. Most recently, my very best friend.

All we want is fairness in our culture and the freedom to seek natural, harmless remedies.

Thank you for hearing our voices.

documents.commentText:
TO WHOM I MAY CONCERN: 

I want to peacefully tell you (DEA and other ignorant folks), that your considerations for deciding to even place this herbal remedy as a scheduled substance is absurd. I wish I could speak without silence. However, I am an officer in the United States Military, likewise, a physician that holds a DEA license to prescribe schedule II and lower medication ,and this medication is guilty by association because it has been found in the past in the same places as spice.  I can tell you hold-heartedly that kratom is no different than your cup of coffee. In the past I have had behavior issues (ADHD) and anxiety.  As time has passed, the sitting and standing in contorted positions in the workplace has done a number on my back and knees. I am tired of poisoning my kidneys and liver with NSAIDS and tylenol to get through my day. I had no interest to become a slave to big pharma narcotics and wasn't allowed to join the cult of medical marijuana do to my job. Which never sat right with me anyway. What I have noticed with this substance is I no longer drink coffee, nor do I drink alcohol, and I do not think I have ever more "even keel" as I am now. It is safe, almost self-regulating. you consume too much you vommit and you don't feel like any for a few days. If you decide to mix with alcohol you will projectile vommit. when discontinuing after a long period of use. It's like quitting cofffee. You don't feel right, but you can still work without consequence.  Reaction times are not decreased, and if anything, you have greater focus. Pretty much, drinking coffee without being jittery, with the added benefit of equal analgesia of taking 800mg motrin and 500mg tylenol. Oh wait, thats right, it's related to the coffee plant. hmmm I don't see you trying to regulate bayer aspirin, JnJ,  or SBUX. documents.commentText: As a rational, science driven person, I cannot in good conscience silently allow this medicine to slip into the realms of demonized substances without lending my own voice to the dissent. We are in the midst of an epidemic of opioid overdoses. Thousands of people are losing their lives each year and this is where we are choosing to put our focus. Fentanyl kills so many, followed by oxy, and when those poor individuals who have fallen into addiction are then prevented from accessing these medications they turn to heroine because they can get it. Even so, more people die from legally prescribed drugs than all of the illegal narcotics combined. Still, you have chosen to focus on a plant medicine that has no attributable deaths and could, in fact, help those people struggling with the life and death consequences of true opioid addiction. This is madness. Even if you were to attribute the few suicides that have been linked to kratom, you would be ignoring the full graveyards of those who have taken their own lives while on SSRIs and other legally prescribed psychoactive medications. Please consider your actions. An all encompassing ban on kratom could have severe, damaging consequences in real peoples lives. I have tried kratom a handful of times and it's more innocuous than any of the hyperbolic accounts, and I have been prescribed vicodin on several occasions. These two substances are not even within the same league. By pushing for schedule 1 status you would also prevent research in to a very promising substance that has the potential to help millions of people. This ban would have severe and lasting consequences. People have been safely using this plant for well over a thousand years while there were over 47000 overdoses on opioids in 2014 alone according to the CDC. I am an upstanding citizen and I stand against this insane action.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has been a miraculous discovery for me.  I suffer from moderate to severe depression, anxiety, and lethargy (probably due to the other two).  I also have had tendonitis since my teens and began developing arthritis in my back, along with severe IBS (irritable bowel syndrome) in my early 20's.  Needless to say I sought relief from myriads of different solutions, from cannabis (lived in California after high school) to muscle relaxers and antidepressants from my doctor. Well, the antidepressants nearly ruined my life in a few different ways (causing blackouts, etc.) but when I found kratom it was like a coffee that also fixes my other ailments.  I no longer needed any antidepressants, no cardio-toxic NSAIDs, I just had a cup of tea in the morning and 1-2 in the evenings and all of those ailments went away.  Kratom can be somewhat habit forming, but much less so than pharmaceuticals, and the "withdrawal" effects are incredibly mild and easily masked with over the counter items.  The same cannot be said for any of the other remedies I tried (except NSAIDs of course).  Kratom has allowed me to be more present in life and does not get me "high."  it is comparable to a strong cup of coffee (no jitters) or if i take a large dose, similar to kava kava or valerian - something no one would ever try to illegalize if they understood.  Just because kratom can (in certain doses) interact with the opioid system does not put it in league with what we call opioids- that's like saying valerian root or lemon balm are as bad as liquor, xanax, or GHB - that's obviously a fallacy.

Please do not ban this substance.  I have seen people quit debilitating drug habits, opioids and others, with this herb, and though it may sound like switching one vice for another, I assure you it is not.  If something helps you but doesnt interfere with your life the way "real drugs" do, it's time to put it on the pile with coffee and valerian root.  You can bet opioid use will sky-rocket in the event of a kratom ban.  That's not a threat - i hate opioids as do many other kratom users, but it's just a fact that some folks require it to keep from relapsing into actual drug addiction.  Please consider all of these factors before making your decision.

I dont think anyone is opposed to some light regulation: manufacturing standards, extract quality/potency standards and/or limits, and age restriction.  Just please allow responsible adults the freedom to consume something other than coffee or synthetic pharmaceuticals

I am a male in my mid 20s. In college I had two unrelated surgeries 4 months apart (broken bone repair and appendicitis). I was prescribed 40 hydrocodone for the first surgury and with the first day of taking the medication I felt myself falling in love with the high. It was unlike anything else I had ever experienced. Prior to this I had hardly used any narcotic substances other than alcohol. I weaned myself off the pills so that I could still function in course work but I would still take them recreationally. I had even looked into buying extra pills off of a friend however before I made the purchase, I got appendicitis and was given a 50 pill prescription for oxycodone. The feeling was even better than the hydrocodone but the cravings were stronger. It scared me that my first thought in the mornings would be to take a pill to get that high back. I had the self awareness to realize what was happening and quit but the cravings for the opiate high still persisted. I was eventually shown Kratom by a friend who had used it to kick their own opiate cravings. It was perfect. Kratom took off the edge of cravings while still allowing me to function and best of all, when it wore off I didn't feel any cravings for it or opiates. 

I hardly crave opiates anymore and only use Kratom once a month or less, mostly for pain.  Kratom is simply something that sits on my shelf that I take occasionally to curb residual opiate cravings (That are much rarer since discovering kratom) or for injuries from sports. It doesn't impair my ability to function and I can still study after taking it. Kratom saved me from falling victim to opiate cravings and addiction from pills I was given legally.

documents.commentText:
To the DEA, pertaining to the legal and unrestricted sale of Kratom, which contains mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine. My name is John Ellison. I am a Print Production Specialist, and live in Manchester, CT. I am 61 years old. I am being treated of an Anxiety disorder, chronic neck pain (due to a broke neck in 1997), and chronic knee pain due the the destruction of my left knee resulting from a catastrophic fall. I discovered Kratom when I thought about taking up smoking and to start drinking again (after over 10 years of abstinence) after several unfortunate events that caused a series of panic attacks and resulted in pain increase in my neck and knee. While in the smoke shop I noticed Kratom on their shelves and asked about it. They gave me a web address to look at, since they were not sure themselves about what Kratom could do for me. I followed up with the research and decided to try it. The results were astonishing; pain in my neck and knee subsided; my urge to drink and smoke disappeared; my high anxiety dwindled and I felt more mentally energetic, with a strangely positive outlook. Since there was no other reason to suspect all of these results from medication (I am not on depression medication), I had to believe it was the Kratom. I have decided to make Kratom part of a healthy lifestyle and I am VERY grateful that I did not return to drinking. In closing I have to say the the mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine in Kratom does not feel like a drug, nor does it have the negative side effects that come with even an over the counter pain medication. Also, it does not have the negative side effects of depression medication, or alcohol. Kratom should remain widely available to the public as an uncontrolled herbal alternative. I am actually pleading with you not to make it a schedule 1 controlled substance. I have included the web links I referred to when researching Kratom for my own use:
ensobotanicals.com/kratom/
www.greenleafkratom.com/kratom-strains-explained/

In closing; Kratom has provided me with safe pain and anxiety relief. There is nothing else like it that does not carry negative side effects. Please keep it legal and available.

Sincerely,  John Ellison

documents.commentText:
I would like to make these specific comments on this policy:

    Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Please do not implement this dangerous and backward looking policy.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

I am 43 years old.  My name is Dawn Grace.  I have a Masters Degree in Community Counseling.  I also have done case management in the mental health field.  I have never been accused or been found guilty of a crime.  I have never taken illegal substances.  I am a mother of two wonderful young adults.  I chose to add Kratom as a daily regimen about 2 1/2 years ago.  It took me over 9 months of research and asking questions to determine to try it.  I have Fibromyalgia,  Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, Depression and a multitude of health issues.  The prescribed medications and other vitamins/herbs and supplements/plants I had tried did not give me the results I needed.  Due to severe pain, fatigue and other symptoms I am unable to work and I wanted to at least be able to do small chores and interact with my family basically do things people can take for granted.  None of the prescribed medications or other vitamins/herbs and supplements/plants were able to do that.  Kratom allows me to have a semblance of life.  I can do things we take for granted such as get out of bed, take a shower, read a book, watch TV with my family, do small chores when my body allows it, take a 10 minute walk, drive my car to store for a quick in and out for an item, decreased my depression and so many other things.  I still cannot work but at least I can do something.  I have never had any side effects from Kratom.  I do not have any withdrawals if I choose not to take Kratom. To see if I would have any withdrawals after taking Kratom for six months I stopped for two weeks.  I had no withdrawal symptoms.  I have never been addicted to any substance including alcohol or cigarettes.  Kratom was able to give me some life back and if I hadn't gotten any results I would have stopped taking it.  There is no danger to the public with Kratom.  It's a natural plant not a synthetic.  It is not a drug.  I use plants, herbs, vitamins, and essential oils for my daily regimen.  Essentially Kratom gave me hope when there was none.  I am no longer considering ending my life because I couldn't handle my symptoms from my illnesses and the many losses I have had in my life since becoming ill.  I would like the opportunity to continue to use plants for my health.  Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
To whomever this may concern,
I am writing today not for myself, but on behalf of a friend who previously struggled with an opiate addiction. Before seeking traditional treatment, Kratom was his first defense against withdrawals. Although many may dispute Kratom is addicting itself, the withdrawals are on par with caffeine withdrawals. In other words, this is not a dangerous drug. In fact, it has numerous health benefits when used appropriately and for certain conditions like pain relief. Kratom certainly does not fit in with the proposed scheduling. If you do a quick youtube search of people on Kratom, you'll find that they are completely themselves. I'm sure you've probably seen Kratom users in public and not noticed. This is because it is not psychoactive. At best, it's a mood enhancer. Again, I urge you to please reconsider. 

Thank You

documents.commentText: I am legally disabled nurse and have been on opioids to control pain.  I have fibromyalgia, stenosis of the neck and spine as well as degenerative disc disease and herniated discs of the neck and spine. I have severe fatigue and weakness. I found kratom by searching for a natural way to help my pain. Depending on what strain I use it also helps with fatigue, depression, anxiety and PTSD of those I am also diagnosed with. I prefer the green strains because they seem to cover all of my issues.  I drink approximately 2-3 grams of tea in the morning to get me mobile. I've seen no withdrawal symptoms from Kratom as I have had to go without it due to money. When I was on opioids withdrawal was an issue.  The pain clinic is far too expensive and I don't want to be addicted to anything. Plus the kratom works far better than anything else I have been given.  There is no "getting high" just relief. It's not that type of medicine.  I'm grateful for it.

documents.commentText: My husband and I have both had back surgery and we have had 7 other surgeries combined between the two of us. I am currently waiting for 4 MORE surgeries and have multiple autoimmune disorder. My hips, ankles and hands hurt all the time. My back hurts on a regular basis even though I had corrective surgery and I have an autoimmune disorder called Cramp Fasciculation Syndrom. This is where all my muscles cramp randomly even when I am doing nothing but resting. It is extremely painful when it happens and I am left quite sore for days afterward even after I take my meds to reduce the spasms. I have brought this all up so you are aware of what I struggle with every day. I have pain medication that I can take, but they make me tired, grumpy and I can't concentrate very well. Kratom is a go to for me when I don't want to go through withdrawal and when I just need to take the edge off my pain without doping myself up and ruining my entire day. It often will give some pain relief without the groggy, grumpy and unfocused side effects. Please don't take this away too. There are very few alternatives to pain killers, if any, for people like me. People that will always have to take something to reduce the chronic pain and Kratom can do that during my "not so bad" days. For me, although I will always be in some level of pain, having Kratom as an alternative is a God send. I don't have to take nearly as many pain killers and it makes me feel like I have a lot more days where I can feel "normal". Again, please don't take my alternative, often more safe for me and those around me, natural medicine away from me. It doesn't hurt anyone around me, it doesn't make me groggy, grumpy or spacey. I feel I should be able to buy Kratom just like I would buy willow bark for tea because it has the foundations of aspirin in it, or many others that help me, but have no affect on anyone else. So many options are taken away from the 'free' people when this should be a choice for me to take, not the government. If you're going to ban something or put limits on something or make it difficult to attain, do it on alcohol. Something that we can buy over the counter, but causes so many deaths...alcohol can deffinitely affect more than just one individual. If you're going to put anything into a class one, alcohol should go there, not Kratom. This just feels like another way that the government 'controls' how an individual wants to live in their daily lives. It makes me feel repressed and contolled. Like my decisions on how I treat myself are in the governments hands and not my own, where it SHOULD be. Let the American people choose how to live their own lives, the way it has always supposed to have been.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W 

I am a 56 year old responsible adult on disability due to Fibromyalgia, Chronic Pain, Chronic Fatigue, Psoratic Arthritis, IBS, Depression and Anxiety. I have had these conditions for 10 years, so I  have tried everything to help my conditions. This is my story.

I was prescribed Methadone, Oxycodone, Tramadol, Ambien,  Lexapro, Valium, Gabapentin, Simvastatin and Tramadol to be taken daily. This was just my most recent cocktail of toxic medications. I have been on every antidepressant and medications in the last 10 years.  I would sleep 14 hours a day most days, unable to do anything. I would fall asleep at the wheel driving 140 miles round trip to my pain management clinic. I had numerous car accidents because of the medication. I came down with a severe case of Palmar Plantar Pustulosis (PPP).  PPP is a form of Psorisis where you have pus filled blisters on your hands and feet. I had it on my feet so bad, that the blisters burst opened, oozed, cracked and bled. The blisters were even under my toenails. I could barley walk and when I could, I cried in pain.  I had this condition for 2 full years and had a add a Dermatologist to my monthly visit in the 140 mile trip.  Between my therapist, pain management doctor, dermatologist and all the medications listed earlier, plus the creams and pills for my feet, I was spending close to $300.00-$400.00 a month.

Due to my health problems, I was fired in 2013 and had to file for disability.  In April 2015, I no longer had any insurance and could not afford new insurance. My pain management doctor basically wouldn't taper my medications unless I could pay the full office visit, which I could not. When I called my pain management Dr.'s office as I was worried going off all those toxic medications cold turkey would be dangerous, the office simply told me I would not die. My only option was to stop all the medications . 

Going off all the opiate medications was unbearable. It was pure agony and I was seriously considering taking my life. I didn't sleep except for 2-3 hours a day for 3 full months.  The only thing at the time that was wonderful, was that after 2 weeks of stopping all medications, my feet completely cleared up and to this day PPP has not returned. My spouse and primary doctor were astonished and that led us to believe that  my PPP was due to all the toxic medications I had been on over the last years. My Fibromyalgia and other conditions returned full force.

I found out about Kratom, a natural supplement in June 2015 on a Chronic Pain board after I told my story.  She private messaged me and gave me the information and I researched it and decided to give it a try.  If it hadn't been a natural plant, I would not have taken it. My spouse and myself were amazed at how well it worked  for me.  It gave me a clearer mind, eased my anxiety, pain and fatigue away for several precious hours and I started living again. I wasn't sleeping all the time, I wasn't so whacked out on pharmaceutical medications. The most I felt was the effects of a good cup of coffee. It eased my muscle pain so I could sleep at night without feeling as if I was sleeping on a bed of rocks and tossing and turning all night. It was also inexpensive and I could afford it. I have used the same amount as I had a year ago.  I could walk my dog without almost collapsing, I could spend time with family and friends again after not leaving the house for almost 3 years. It literally gave me my life back, as it has for so many others.

Please do not take away my quality of life by making Kratom any other thing except for what it is, a natural plant and supplement.  I do support keeping it for age 18 or 21 and older, however, I can't see any one wanting to use it for recreational purposes as it doesn't give the user any type of reward or high.  I also support taking it out of head shops, gas stations or any other retailer that promotes it as recreational.  I fully support keeping it online and through legitimate herbal and supplement businesses that follow guidelines. My greatest fear is that I will no longer have access to a supplement that gives me back my quality of life, lets me be with family or have the price marked up so much that I will no longer be able to afford it as both my spouse and myself are on Social Security and have limited funds.  

The economic fallout will also be great if Kratom is drastically changed from a supplement to banned substance. From the farmers in less fortunate countries to the mom and pop businesses that have put their life savings in chasing their dream and opening herbal store fronts or online businesses. We are also in an opioid epidemic that we are drastically losing, we cannot afford to have a plant related to the coffee plant placed in the same category as hard drugs.

Sincerely,

Judy Steffen

documents.commentText:
Hello DEA,

I'm a 28-year-old administrator with a public university in Texas. I've used kratom to help with normal aches and pains related to an athletic schedule.

There seems to be next to no evidence that kratom actually hurts people, or has any harmful effects whatsoever. There needs to be substantial evidence that it's a problem before you make a substance illegal. The default position can't be to ban something because we're not sure. Let's become sure, then decide what to do, please. If someone on psych meds kills himself, and happens to have had a drink of coffee too, you wouldn't use that as evidence to ban coffee. But one of the fifteen commonly cited cases was exactly that (with kratom instead of coffee). 

Add to that its positive effects, which seem to be real, benign, and fairly difficult to abuse - and you have something that definitely needs to be studied for its possible aid to society. 

Please consult the public in a more meaningful way before making major decisions on our behalf in the future. 

Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir / Ma'am,

I do not agree that this beneficial substance should be classified as a Class 1 illegal drug. It should be researched prior to just simply banning. There are no negative side effects, no lethal dose, and no addictive properties. When there is a natural occurring plant that can replace current synthetic drugs, the answer is not to shut it down without thought. not to mention the fact that the drugs this plant could replace cause thousands of deaths a year due to overdoes and the extreme levels of addiction they come with. I do not use the substance, and never have because i do not need it. But seeing how it has been beneficial to many, especially those trying to get off Oxycontin, how can we label Kratom as a Class 1 substance. This is a plea to look into and research, because once it is classified as schedule one, the red tape to make it legal again is very long.

Hello, I am a mid-twenties male and American citizen who consumes kratom every day, and have been doing so for several years. I have been taking kratom since I broke my foot a few years ago, and kratom has made the experience of my foot healing far more comfortable. I have foot pain that can make it very unpleasant to walk or climb a ladder, which are two things I must do for my very active job. I manage a warehouse with over $6 million dollars of inventory, and I need to be on my feet all day long in order to help my coworkers and myself flourish. Kratom allows me to work with no pain, and no intoxicating effect. It is not a drug in the traditional sense of the word, it is more akin to a cup of coffee. I have taken kratom every day at my highly competitive and public workplace and if I seemed intoxicated I would have been fired long ago. I operate forklifts and other heavy machinery while on Kratom and I am in complete control of my actions while doing so.

When I go on vacation I typically leave my kratom at home, and I suffer no withdrawal effect even though I am taking kratom at least 5 days a week at my job. The only thing that returns is my foot pain. 

I was born in America and have lived here all my life. I have never been arrested or accused of a crime. I do not consume any illegal drugs or illicit substances. And yet I am writing you this message anonymously due to my fear and concern over the scheduling and ban of kratom. I do not want to become a criminal. I do not deserve to become a criminal. All I want is to do my job pain-free. Thank you for reading this.

I am opposed to kratom being a scheduled substance. Kratom should not be scheduled. I have seen the difference it has made in my wife's life. I have heard from co-workers and numerous others how much better their quality of life is after finding kratom. Even before my wife and I were married, nearly 20 years ago, she's always lived in pain and had very limited options in what she could use to help her because of allergies or undesired effects (feeling "high", nauseated or itching and even unable to function). While kratom may not fix her conditions and it doesn't get rid of them,  kratom does give my wife such an incredible better quality of life and she's able to accomplish more then she ever has been. I can see how much of a difference and positive impact  Kratom has made in my wife's life and I can't imagine anyone taking that away. I do not think that any adult should ever be denied access to kratom tea. It has such a huge positive impact and so many people lead much better quality lives. I don't want to see my wife go back to living with so much pain and discomfort when this all natural leaf helps. documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern, 
My name is Mark Shaver. I am 49 years old, I am a dad of four, married, a teacher (special education--will finish my masters this spring in fact) and an ordained pastor with a Masters of Divinity from Denver Seminary. I graduated Magna Cum Laude from the University Northern Colorado in 1989, and with Honors from Denver Seminary in 2001. Ive been teaching and preaching since 1989. 
I also have used kratom for the past 3 years. 

My reasons for taking kratom have been for the simple fact that I use it for a supplement to ease my back pain. From an accident I suffered several bulging discs, have sciatica, and previously was prescribed tramadol, morphine, oxycontin, and methadone. ALL of these drugs ended up causing severe side effects including but not limited to chronic constipation, lethargy, incontinence, erectile dysfunction, MORE pain, and addiction. I could not stand what was going on, and I ended up on methadone finally as a last resort as I was about to file for disability due to the pain levels I had incurred. I did not want to live anymore as well. 

I did research online and found that kratom had been used safely in Thailand and in east Asia for hundreds of years and decided to try that, as a last resort, for my pain and to get OFF of the methadone. Within 6 weeks I was off all methadone, I began to feel better, had NO side effects of any sort--and was able to go back to work as a teacher after almost 8 years of being what amounted to bed-ridden and only doing Sunday services for my small church. 
I will finish my Master's in Special Education this year. This is due to kratom giving me my life back. I cannot imagine what would happen if I had to go back to opioids for pain. For myself it is simply a supplement that has helped so much in so many ways it is indispensable for my life. 
The bottom line for myself is that without the use of kratom, I would not have went back to work full time as a teacher. I would not have entered a program to get another Master's degree. I would not be working, and as well my personal life was deteriorating from the stress on my marriage as well. I am able to coach baseball, tutor kids after school, be a husband, have intimacy with my spouse--I would be living a totally different life. My quality of life--in and of itself--would be a shambles. 
What good would it do me to have all these degrees, this amount of experience in working with both adults and children--if I was bed-ridden or stuck on the couch watching Oprah? Nothing. What good would it be to be married, with four beautiful children who need their father--if he is in so much pain you can't go to their games, help coach them--to BE there? Nothing. This is why for myself and for so many others the talk of banning this herb is so ridiculous and the ignorance as well, of who uses the plant, has been such a source of anger for me. We are NOT a bunch of "druggies" but professionals, people with a higher quality of life, productive citizens--for which the pharmaceuticals used on our bodies were not working and for which did not lead to healing. That has not been the case with kratom for myself and many others. As a supplement it allowed me to heal, maintain a level of pain that was not debilitating, and it did it without the side effects of opiods and the addiction that comes with them.

documents.commentText:
Dearest DEA,
I assume that your intentions are good.  I also know that since you are somehow both the creators and the enforcers of the law that you have a blatant conflict of interest.  Because I am willing to assume that your intentions are good, I will set aside the conflict of interest issue for now, even though your budget and your jobs depend on having (creating?!) illegal drugs to go to war against.  I will also momentarily set aside the obvious fallacy that one cannot wage a war on drugs, one can only wage a WAR ON PEOPLE, and those people are the citizens of this supposedly FREE COUNTRY. (Sorry for 'yelling,' but all caps is the only mode of emphasis this platform allows me.)
To the point - ironically, I had never heard of Kratom until I read that you were going go summarily give it a Schedule 1 listing without any due process or public comment.  I'm honestly pleasantly shocked that you backed off on that.  Holy cow, maybe we don't live in a completely dystopian future yet.
Getting back to the point - when I read about the plans to schedule Kratom I thought, "Wait, why haven't I heard of this plant?  It sounds awesome!" So, impulsively, I went ahead and ordered some.  
A little background - I'm someone who has struggled with mild to moderate depression my whole adult life, I have a tendency to drink too much, I generally don't sleep well and I never have.  I have bad knees.  I had my first knee surgery when I was only 13 years old.  So I have aches and pains even though I'm only 46.
Here's my report: For the last two months or so I took 1-2 teaspoons of Kratom powder every day.  One in the morning, one in the afternoon.  It's been a great experience.  I've slept better and had more energy than I can ever remember.  My knees bother me less, and I have very little urge to drink.  I've lost some weight as a result.  
That's all good and well, but here's the really important part.  Two weeks ago I went out of town for a week and took no Kratom with me.  I felt NO withdrawal symptoms. NONE.  Sure, I didn't feel as great and I didn't sleep as well, but it was just back to how I felt before I had ever heard of Kratom.  I felt no worse.  None whatsoever. 
Based on my experience, I honestly believe that coffee is more addictive.  If I go two days without coffee I get a horrendous headache.  A week without Kratom, no problem at all.
I understand the concern that there is a risk of abuse.  I haven't tried taking enough of it to see what the concern is, but fair enough.  I would like to point out however, that there is a ton of room for abuse with sugar, tobacco and alcohol, and all of those substances are legal despite the massive toll that they take on our society.  Massive! Still legal!
 I also understand the concern that Kratom products may be impure, laced, etc.  Well, news flash - so is most of our food and supplements. I often read reports that the supplements bought in places like Walmart often contain NONE of the product what they are being sold as being.  I might be on my own on this one, but I would love to see the FDA start to regulate ALL supplements in a positive and non-onerous way to ensure that people are getting what they are paying for.  That would be awesome and beneficial.  But telling me that this plant is not ok b/c a few people took it and then freaked out and called the poison control center is absurd. 
Putting Kratom on the Schedule 1 list would end pretty much all research into these potentially game changing chemicals.  We have an out of control opiate addiction issue in this country.  Bundling Kratom into that and making it more illegal than prescription opiates is absurd.  Kratom has the potential to be part of the solution, not part of the problem.  If you want to crack down on something, crack down on these legal drug pushers in the pharmaceutical industry that are making massive profits killing our people. Please.
Just be reasonable for once. We aren't children. This is supposed to be a free country.  Kratom isn't killing people, prescription drugs are. Get your heads on straight and do your jobs in a way that actually helps people, not hurts and criminalizes them.
Thank you for listening.

I, am writing to inform you that I oppose regulation of kratom by the DEA. 

I have used kratom for about three years effectively  controlled sugar levels as a prediabetic with a genetic disposition to diabetes.  As a mild sedative and sleep aid, kratom does the job without hangovers or judgement impairment, in my experience.

The trend in the country is towards deregulation of marijuana both medicinal and recreational. To over-regulate another plant contradicts the trend and may very well create a black market in kratom.  Research into the benefits of specific chemical components of kratom is desirable but should not be a prerequisite to use. Continued use in larger population can provide valuable epidemiological data that experiments do not. Finally, with the massive health issues - lethal viruses, antibiotic resistant bacteria, Alzheimer's in an aging population, should this be  priority?

I summary, given the lack of scientific knowledge about kratom, its low danger rate, its ling history of use on the planet, and the potential for increased crime, why not leave well enough alone and cease efforts to classify kratom as a drug and especially as a class 1 drug.

documents.commentText:
I suffer chronic back pain that has caused me misery for years.  I have visited doctors, tried exercise and tried various treatments.  Realizing that pain management would be a long-term necessity in order to be able to be fully functional, mentally and physically, both at home and at work, I sought various forms of pain relief.  I tried various non-opiate solutions that were ineffective.  Learning that the degree of my pain would require opiates by conventional methods and knowing the long-term nature of the issue,  I knew that if I went down the path of consuming true opiates, I would very likely become physically addicted to them; and also, I expected that kind of pain relief could interfere with my work.  Hearing the horror stories of opiate addiction, I decided I would avoid becoming an opiate addict at all costs!

So, I set out to try some alternative method that would relieve pain, not cause physical addiction and permit me to be fully functional in the daytime.  Upon reading some scientific research suggesting that it was not physically addictive due a unique method of action as well as learning of a long track record of relatively safe use as an ethnobotanical in some cultures, I decided try it.  I found that it was precisely what I needed:  It relieved pain, I was able to maintain a significant degree of mental clarity and it was not physically addictive.  At first, I was concerned it was highly psychologically addictive.  However, I discovered that not to be true with time:  Occasionally, I would venture out to try new techniques of relieving pain and there were sometime months of doing so without any dramatic challenge.  Upon stopping, I did initially have a feeling like the feeling of not getting my morning coffee like something I would like to have but would do well-enough not having it.  The psychologically addictive aspect of it was mild and manageable, especially factoring for its immense benefits.  Despite my trying alternate techniques at time, I have found kratom to be the most consistently effective.  Without kratom, I expect that I would have become an opiate addict with time, entirely physically addicted and very strongly psychologically addicted.  I would loose my freedom of mind and body.  As it stands now, kratom aids me but does not rule me.  I consider it a blessing from God that such a thing can exist that's so powerfully beneficial and yet so relatively benign.

Kratom may need to be government-regulated so that only adults are permitted to consume it and to ensure a consistent, good quality product.  However, with all due respect, appreciating the best efforts to prevent harm to humanity, the only proper word to describe treating kratom as if it has no medical benefit and would only be abused, is "unawareness" of reality.  It's not only unawareness for the countless anecdotes that should not be dismissed but for the scientific research already available on the subject indicating numerous, novel potential medical benefits.  It's important to leave a legacy that future generations will be proud of and see its wisdom, not something that will need to be reversed at a later time by wiser descendants.  The correct path of how to treat kratom is to to regulate it as something useful so that humanity can get the maximum gain possible from the product,  increasing humanity's freedom to choose self-healing.  Surely, there are many truly malicious synthetic substances, killing many and truly having only minimal medical benefit (if at all) that really need the DEA's attention.  However, kratom is highly beneficial for practical purposes.  Were kratom to be treated a scheduled substance, God forbid, what happened in Alabama recently would happen elsewhere:  You would see more people becoming opiate addicts when they have no alternative means of relieving pain.  On the flip side, if kratom is regulated, we will see humanity improve and progress and if directed at stopping true opiate addiction, save lives.

Typically, when nature's gifts are rejected, it creates a void in human existence and increases humanity's suffering,  Please acknowledge kratom as the gift of the God we trust and treat it with respect.  As commendable leaders , help this nation be guided on a path to use this product with reason and responsibility.  By that path, we and future generations will see the wisdom of the decisions that were made here.  Let us be able to count the many lives that were saved through preventing a dangerous opiate condition plus account for the immense suffering averted through making kratom available to humanity.
